paragraph.text: Subject to subsection (c) of this section, after the suspension or extension under paragraph (2) of this subsection expires, if the Commission has not entered a final order, the new rate or change in rate proposed by the public service company takes effect.

If a proposed new rate or rate increase takes effect before the Commission enters a final order in the proceedings, if practicable, the Commission may order the public service company that proposes the rate to keep a detailed and accurate account of:

subparagraph.text: all amounts received under the new rate or rate increase; and
the persons on whose behalf the amounts are paid.

paragraph.text: After the proceedings conclude, the Commission may require the public service company to refund with interest, to each person listed under paragraph (1)(ii) of this subsection, the part of the new rate or rate increase that the Commission finds unjustified.

If a refund is not practicable, the public service company shall charge off and amortize the difference between the operating revenues under the rate charged and the operating revenues that would have been obtained from the same volume of business from the final set rate, through a temporary rate decrease for the period that the Commission sets.

subsection.text: The Commission may set a temporary rate for any public service company that is higher or lower than the rate previously in effect.
The Commission may set a temporary rate after hearing only if the Commission finds that:

paragraph.text: pending a final rate proceeding, the rate in force is not a just and reasonable rate; and
the temporary rate is necessary in the interest of justice in view of the length of time that must elapse before a final order may be entered.

subsection.text: If the order involves a temporary rate increase, and refund to the consumer is practicable, the public service company shall post a bond, with security and in an amount that the Commission approves, payable to the State and conditioned to ensure prompt refund with interest to each consumer of each amount received by the public service company from the consumer above the final rates that the Commission sets.
Any temporary change in rate shall equal the amount found by the Commission to be higher or lower than a just and reasonable rate.

paragraph.text: The temporary change in rate under subsection (d) of this section shall remain in effect for an initial period of not more than 9 months.
The Commission may order the temporary change to be extended by not more than 3 months.

If the final rate set is higher than the rate set in the order for a temporary rate, the public service company may amortize and recover over a period that the Commission sets, through a temporary increase over the final rate set, the difference between the operating revenue obtained under the order for a temporary rate and the operating revenue that would have been obtained from the same volume of business from the final rate set.
If the rate in the order for a temporary rate is higher than the final rate set, the Commission shall order a refund, charge off, or amortization under § 4-204(c) of this subtitle.

subsection.text: At any time, the Commission may investigate and determine the fair value of the property of a public service company used and useful in providing service to the public.

paragraph.text: The valuation:

subparagraph.text: is not final until the Commission:

sub-subparagraph.text: serves on the public service company a copy of the order setting the proposed valuation and the method used to set the valuation; and
allows a reasonable time in which to file a protest; and

subparagraph.text: is final if a protest is not filed within the time specified in the order.

paragraph.text: If a timely protest is filed, the Commission shall enter a final valuation by order after hearing.

subsection.text: All final valuations are prima facie evidence of value in proceedings under this division.

This section applies only to a gas company, electric company, or telephone company whose gross annual revenues, for the most recent calendar year for which data are available, are less than 3% of the total gross annual revenues of all public service companies in the State during the same calendar year.

paragraph.text: When the Commission suspends a proposed new rate for a company subject to this section that is based on the existing authorized fair rate of return, the Commission promptly shall institute proceedings to determine if additional revenues are required to allow the company to earn the existing fair rate of return authorized in the previous base rate proceeding.
The Commission shall:

subparagraph.text: serve each of the parties to the previous base rate proceeding of that company with a copy of the suspension order; and
order the company to publish a display advertisement about the proposal in newspapers of general circulation in its service area.

paragraph.text: Proceedings under this section shall:

subparagraph.text: account for revenues, expenses, and rate base in the same manner that the Commission employed in determining a just and reasonable rate in the previous base rate proceeding; and

exclude consideration of any increase in the rate of return, any change in rate structure, or any change in an accounting approach to any item pertaining to revenues, expenses, or rate base inconsistent with that used by the Commission in determining a just and reasonable rate in the previous base rate proceeding on the company.

paragraph.text: In proceedings under this section, the Commission may use a more recent past test period than that used in the previous base rate proceeding for the company.
The Commission shall enter a final order as to the revenue requirement determined under this section within 90 days after the proposed new rate is filed.
The final order shall:

subparagraph.text: authorize a new rate distributing any change in the revenue requirement proportionally among the ratepayers without change in the rate structure; and
state whether further proceedings shall be held.

paragraph.text: If, in the final order, the Commission decides to conduct further proceedings under subsection (c) of this section, the final order may provide for refund, consistent with the provisions of § 4-204(c) of this subtitle, of any difference between the new rate authorized under this subsection and the rate the Commission sets under subsection (c) of this section.
If the Commission decides to conduct further proceedings under subsection (b) of this section, the Commission, after a hearing, may:

subparagraph.text: modify the rate structure;
lower the authorized fair rate of return; or
modify the accounting approach to an item that pertains to revenues, expenses, or rate base.

paragraph.text: The Commission shall take any action under this subsection within 120 days after entry of a final order under subsection (b) of this section.
This section does not apply to a proposed new rate that is filed:

subparagraph.text: less than 1 year after a previously proposed new rate under this section is filed; or
with a request for temporary rates under § 4-205 of this subtitle.

A company may not file a proposed new rate under this subtitle if any proposed new rate filed by the company under this section is pending, or a new rate filed by the company under this section has been in effect fewer than 90 days.
This paragraph does not preclude a company from filing a proposed new rate for a new service if the proposal does not affect the authorized rate of return.

paragraph.text: Unless the Commission provides otherwise, this section does not apply to a proposed new rate that is filed more than 3 years after the Commission enters a final order authorizing the existing fair rate of return in the previous base rate proceeding.

subsection.text: This section applies to a public service company that:

paragraph.text: provides gas or electric services;
is subject to a cost allocation manual approved by the Commission;

subparagraph.text: engages in an unregulated business activity; or
has a subsidiary that engages in an unregulated business activity; and

paragraph.text: does not meet the standards for rate proceedings provided for under § 4-207 of this subtitle.
A public service company subject to this section shall file an independent audit opinion prepared by an entity approved by the Commission on the earliest of:

subparagraph.text: once every 2 years; or
when the public service company:

sub-subparagraph.text: files a request for a change in its base rate under this subtitle; or
has a major change in its corporate organization or structure as determined by the Commission.

paragraph.text: The independent auditor shall:

subparagraph.text: examine:

sub-subparagraph.text: compliance by the public service company with policies and procedures of the public service company’s cost allocation manual;
proper allocation of costs to an affiliate of the public service company in accordance with the manual; and
appropriate charging of costs and transactions relative to the manual to the public service company and its affiliates; and

subparagraph.text: identify adjustments that should be made:

sub-subparagraph.text: to the manual consistent with prior Commission rulings; and
to the public service company or to an affiliate of the public service company relative to the examination of the allocation of costs and charging of costs and transactions.

subsection.text: The cost of the independent audit opinion filed under subsection (b) of this section shall be borne by the stockholders of the public service company.

With respect to the net capital costs associated with the relocation underground of utility lines and facilities in connection with projects required by § 8–401 of the Land Use Article, the Commission shall:

paragraph.text: set the amount of the monthly surcharge required to support the costs and determine which customers of the applicable utility are subject to the surcharge;
include in the rate base the related net capital costs; or
adopt another method to apportion the costs appropriately.

subsection.text: A utility may not be required to pay more than 50% of the net capital costs of a relocation project.
A county or municipal corporation may appropriate money for a relocation project from appropriate federal, State, and local funds it receives for this purpose.
Notwithstanding § 4-101 of this title or any other law to the contrary, the Commission may regulate a telephone company through alternative forms of regulation.
The Commission may adopt an alternative form of regulation under this section if the Commission finds, after notice and hearing, that the alternative form of regulation:

paragraph.text: protects consumers by, at a minimum:

subparagraph.text: producing affordable and reasonably priced basic local exchange service, as defined by the Commission; and
ensuring the quality, availability, and reliability of telecommunications services throughout the State;

paragraph.text: encourages the development of competition; and
is in the public interest.

subsection.text: An alternative form of regulation may include:

paragraph.text: price regulation;
revenue regulation;
ranges of authorized return;
rate of return;
categories of services; or
price indexing.
In this subsection, “operating ratio” means the relationship of common carrier expenses to common carrier operating revenues.
In considering proper revenue under subsection (b)(3) of this section, the Commission shall determine a fair and equitable operating ratio.

subsection.text: In setting a just and reasonable rate for common carriers, and classifications, regulations, and practices relating to common carriers, the Commission shall consider, among other factors:

paragraph.text: the inherent advantages of transportation by common carriers;
the need, in the public interest, of adequate and efficient transportation services by common carriers at the lowest cost consistent with furnishing these services; and
the need of revenues sufficient to enable common carriers to provide these services under honest, economical, and efficient management.

subsection.text: The Commission shall establish pilotage fees and charges for pilotage services to vessels at a just and reasonable rate.
The Commission shall give notice and hold a public hearing on each rate proposal as provided in this article.
In determining a just and reasonable rate, the Commission shall consider:

paragraph.text: the draft, dimensions, and tonnage of the vessel piloted;
the difficulty and inconvenience of the particular service and the time and skill required to render the service;
the time required to render pilotage service at other United States ports and the fees and charges for the service;
the public interest in maintaining efficient and reliable pilotage service; and
other factors relevant to the determination of a just and reasonable rate.

subsection.text: A pilot may not demand or receive a different compensation for providing pilotage service than the rate set by the Commission under this section.

The Commission shall impose an assessment on the Association of Maryland Pilots based on assessment guidelines established for public service companies under § 2-110 of this article. The assessment imposed under this subsection may not be less than $25,000.
All pilotage fees and charges provided by applicable law shall remain in effect until changed by the Commission.
The Commission shall establish fees and charges for a licensed docking master to provide docking services in the Ports of Maryland at a just and reasonable rate.
The Commission shall give notice and hold a public hearing on each rate proposal as provided in this article.
In determining a just and reasonable rate, the Commission shall consider:

paragraph.text: the draft, dimensions, and tonnage of the vessel;
the difficulty and inconvenience of the particular service and the time and skill required to render the service;
the time required to render docking service at other United States ports and the fees and charges for the service;
the public interest in maintaining efficient and reliable docking service; and
other factors relevant to the determination of a just and reasonable rate.

subsection.text: A docking master licensed under Title 5.5 of the Business Occupations and Professions Article may not demand or receive a different compensation for providing docking services than the rate set by the Commission under this section.
The Commission shall impose an assessment on the association based on assessment guidelines established for public service companies under § 2-110 of this article.
All fees and charges provided by applicable law shall remain in effect until changed by the Commission.
In this section, “jurisdiction” means a county or municipal corporation.
This section does not apply if rates for sewage disposal service are specified in a contract between the jurisdictions that supply and receive the sewage disposal service.
The Commission shall set only the rates for sewage disposal service that one jurisdiction supplies within the taxable limits of another jurisdiction:

paragraph.text: on written application by the jurisdiction that receives the service; and
in the same way as rates are set for sewage disposal companies.

subsection.text: In this section, “jurisdiction” means a county, sanitary district, or municipal corporation.
This section does not affect §§ 35-138, 35-140, 35-141, and 35-145 of the Code of Public Local Laws of Baltimore County.
The Commission shall set only the rates for water that one jurisdiction supplies within another jurisdiction:

paragraph.text: on written application by the jurisdiction that receives the water; and
in the same way as rates are set for water companies.

subsection.text: This section applies to any municipal corporation in Talbot County that supplies water to an area outside the boundaries of the municipal corporation.
On written application, the Commission may grant the applicant a certificate of authority to establish a service area outside of its boundaries and to supply that service area with water.

section.text: As it considers necessary, and in accordance with the requirements of § 4-402 of this subtitle, the Commission may allow a gas company or electric company to establish a sliding scale to adjust costs of its fuel, purchased power, or purchased gas.

paragraph.text: This section applies to:

subparagraph.text: electric fuel rate adjustment clauses;
purchased power adjustment clauses; and
purchased gas adjustment clauses.

paragraph.text: This section does not apply to a small rural electric cooperative.

subsection.text: A gas company or electric company that directly passes on to its customers changes in fuel costs, costs of purchased power, or costs of purchased gas shall verify and justify the adjusted costs to the Commission each month.
The Commission shall order a company to charge off and amortize, by means of a temporary decrease of rates, any charge the Commission finds is unjustified because:

paragraph.text: the company failed to show that the charges were based solely on increased costs of fuel, purchased power, or purchased gas;
the company failed to follow competitive practices in procuring and purchasing fuel, power, or gas; or
the company failed to show that its practices in procuring and purchasing fuel were reasonable.

subsection.text: At least once every 12 months, the Commission shall conduct a public evidentiary hearing on any changes in costs that a company directly passes on to its customers under this section.
In its utility operations, a public service company may not:

paragraph.text: sell, render services, or furnish a commodity until the public service company files and publishes its rate schedules in accordance with § 4–202 of this title; or
demand or collect:

subparagraph.text: compensation that differs from compensation specified in its rate schedules that are in force at the time of the demand or collection; or
a charge that violates this division.

subsection.text: A person may not assist, allow, or attempt to assist or allow the actions prohibited under this section by any means, including false billing, false classification, false weighing, or false report of weight, even if a public service company or its personnel consents to or connives with the prohibited action.

section.text: In an action by a public service company to collect a charge, the public service company may not recover any amount if, in the transaction that is the subject of the action, the public service company demanded a rate greater than that lawful under this division when the charge was made.

subsection.text: This section does not apply to service rendered or commodities furnished:

paragraph.text: to the officers, employees, pensioners, and immediate family members of the officers, employees, and pensioners of a public service company;
to the United States, the State, or a local government;
to provide relief in cases of general epidemic, pestilence, flood, or other similar calamity;
in the case of common carriers, to transport:

subparagraph.text: personnel of another common carrier that reciprocates for personnel of the transporting common carrier;
hospital patients;
indigent, destitute, and homeless individuals;
persons exclusively engaged in charitable work;
residents of federal or State veterans homes, including those about to enter a home or those returning from a home;
railway mail service employees and baggage agents;
post office, customs, and immigration inspectors;
newspaper vendors;
property for exhibition carried to or from fairs and expositions;
employees of sleeping car companies, express companies, telegraph companies, and telephone companies doing business along the line of the common carrier;
persons and property incident to or connected with contracts for construction, operation, or maintenance of the plant of the transportation company, to the extent provided in the contracts;
individuals injured in accidents and physicians, nurses, or other necessary caretakers attending the injured individuals in transit;
children under the age of 5 years for no charge;
children under 12 years for half fare; or
persons at free or reduced rates that are otherwise authorized by law;

paragraph.text: in the case of common carriers, for the issuance of mileage, excursion, or commuter tickets;

to free steamboat excursion transportation from May through August of each year, from Baltimore City to any place in the State, in exchange for services rendered in advertising the excursion business;
to obtain essential data by a method that uses a limited sample of customers, in connection with a rate structure study conducted under formal proceedings before the Commission; or
to telephone lifeline service provided to eligible subscribers under § 8-201 of this article.

subsection.text: For any service rendered or commodity furnished, a public service company may not directly or indirectly, by any means, including special rates, rebates, drawbacks, or refunds:

paragraph.text: charge, demand, or receive from a person compensation that is greater or less than from any other person under substantially similar circumstances;
extend a privilege or facility to a person, except those privileges and facilities that are extended uniformly to all persons under substantially similar circumstances;
discriminate against a person, locality, or particular class of service; or
give undue or unreasonable preference to or cause undue or unreasonable prejudice to a person, locality, or particular class of service.

subsection.text: After providing notice and an opportunity for interested parties to be heard, the Commission may adopt regulations that prescribe standards for safe, adequate, reasonable, and proper service for any class of public service company or gas master meter operator.
The standards adopted under subsection (a) of this section shall best promote, in the opinion of the Commission, the security or convenience of:

paragraph.text: the public;
those employed in furnishing services; and
those to whom services are rendered.

subsection.text: The Commission may:

paragraph.text: enforce the standards adopted under this section; and
by order, as the Commission considers necessary, require changes and additions in the service of any public service company or gas master meter operator, including:

subparagraph.text: repairs or improvements in plant;
increase in motive power; and
change in schedule or manner of operations.

subsection.text: The Commission may:

paragraph.text: as it considers reasonable and proper, order a common carrier to issue mileage, excursion, school commuter, passenger commuter, or joint interchangeable mile tickets for all or part of the common carrier’s route in the State; and
require any two or more common carriers, whose lines form a continuous line of transportation or whose lines could form a continuous line of transportation by means of switch connection, to:

subparagraph.text: establish through routes and joint rates;
provide for the manner of securing the through routes or paying the joint rates; and
apportion the through routes and joint rates between the affected common carriers.

subsection.text: This section:

paragraph.text: is subject to § 7-208(f) of the Transportation Article; and
does not limit § 5-101 of this subtitle.

The Commission may require a public service company to continue any service that the public service company renders to the public under any franchise, right, or permit, after any applicable expiration date.
Unless authorized by the Commission, a public service company may not discontinue or abandon a service under a franchise, right, or permit.

The Commission may authorize a public service company to discontinue or abandon a service under a franchise, right, or permit if the Commission finds that the present or future public convenience and necessity allows the discontinuance or abandonment.
Denial of authorization to discontinue or abandon a service under a franchise, right, or permit does not preclude subsequent reapplication.

Whenever the Commission authorizes the abandonment or discontinuance of a franchise, right, or permit, as a whole or in part, that involves any service to or from a suburban community, the Commission:

subparagraph.text: shall consider all applications to acquire the franchise, right, or permit to render the service; and
shall grant the application to the best qualified applicant.

paragraph.text: An abandoned or discontinued right that extends between mid-city and suburban termini shall continue to extend between the mid-city and suburban termini if the abandoned or discontinued right:

subparagraph.text: as acquired by the abandoning or discontinuing public service company or its predecessor, extended from mid-city to suburban termini; or
was operated between the mid-city and suburban termini during most of its existence or for an aggregate of at least 15 years.

subsection.text: The Commission may authorize the acts described in §§ 5-202, 5-203, and 5-205 of this title and § 6-101(a) of this article if it finds that the authorization is consistent with the public convenience and necessity.
Authority that the Commission grants under §§ 5-202 and 5-203 of this title does not:

paragraph.text: revive a lapsed franchise;
validate an invalid franchise;
enlarge or add to the powers and privileges of a franchise; or
waive a forfeiture.

section.text: The Commission shall require each gas company, electric company, and telephone company to exempt the dwelling units of subscribing individuals who are at least 60 years old from any cash deposit requirement, if the subscriber does not owe any past-due bill to that public service company.

Before a license or permit may be issued under this article to an employer to engage in an activity in which the employer may employ a covered employee, as defined in § 9-101 of the Labor and Employment Article, the employer shall file with the issuing authority:

paragraph.text: a certificate of compliance with the Maryland Workers’ Compensation Act; or
the number of a workers’ compensation insurance policy or binder.

subsection.text: A public service company may not exercise a franchise granted by law except to the extent authorized by the Commission.
A public service company may not exercise a franchise unless it files with the Commission:

paragraph.text: a certified copy of its charter; and
a statement by its president and secretary, signed under oath, that the appropriate local authorities have provided the required consent for the exercise of the franchise.

section.text: Without prior authorization of the Commission, a public service company may not:

paragraph.text: assign, lease, or transfer a franchise or a right under a franchise;
enter into any agreement or contract that materially affects a franchise or a right under a franchise; or
abandon or discontinue the exercise of a franchise or a right as a whole or in part.

subsection.text: Subject to § 6–101 of this article, without prior authorization of the Commission, a public service company may not purchase, acquire, take, or hold any part of the capital stock of another public service company that operates in Maryland.

paragraph.text: This subsection applies to corporations that operate in Maryland.
Except as provided in paragraph (5) of this subsection, without prior authorization of the Commission, a public service company may not:

subparagraph.text: assume or guarantee an obligation or liability with respect to stocks, bonds, securities, notes, or other evidence of indebtedness that is payable as a whole or in part to any person more than 12 months after the date of issuance; or
issue stocks, bonds, securities, notes, or other evidence of indebtedness payable as a whole or in part more than 12 months after the date of issuance.

paragraph.text: Stocks, bonds, securities, notes, or other evidence of indebtedness described under paragraph (2)(ii) of this subsection shall be issued in accordance with §§ 6–102 and 6–103 of this article.
The Commission shall take action on an application for authorization under this section within a reasonable time after receipt.

Prior authorization of the Commission is not required for an assumption or guarantee under paragraph (2)(i) of this subsection or an issuance under paragraph (2)(ii) of this subsection made by a gas company, electric company, or telephone company whose gross annual revenues, for the most recent calendar year for which data are available, are less than 3% of the total gross annual revenues of all public service companies in the State during the same calendar year, if the gas company, electric company, or telephone company:

subparagraph.text: provides prior written notice to the Commission of the transaction; and
obtains approval of the transaction from the entity in another state that regulates the gas company, electric company, or telephone company.

subsection.text: This section does not apply to:

paragraph.text: a municipal corporation, sanitary district, or other unit of government;
an individual, for the construction of a water system or sewage disposal system for the individual’s personal or private use; or
a group of individuals for their joint personal or private use, unless the Commission finds that the joint use is for the purpose of generally serving a proposed new housing development.

subsection.text: Without the prior authorization of the Commission, a person may not construct a water system or sewage disposal system for public use.

paragraph.text: The Commission may authorize the construction of a water system or sewage disposal system for public use only on a finding that the construction of the water system or sewage disposal system is in the public interest.
In determining whether the proposed construction of the water system or sewage disposal system is in the public interest, the Commission shall consider:

subparagraph.text: the financing plans for the proposed construction; and
other pertinent facts and circumstances.

subsection.text: An applicant for authorization to construct a water system or sewage disposal system:

paragraph.text: shall fully disclose to the Commission the financing plans for the construction; and
has the burden of proof to satisfy the Commission that the construction is in the public interest.
After a hearing, the Commission may revoke an authorization to construct a water system or sewage disposal system if the Commission finds that the revocation is in the public interest.
An order of revocation may be appealed in accordance with § 3-204 of this article.
Subject to action of the Commission under § 3-205 of this article, the filing of an appeal does not stay an order of revocation.
After the Commission issues an order of revocation, the water system or sewage disposal system may not be operated until the revocation is repealed by:

subparagraph.text: the Commission; or
the final disposition of an appeal from the order of revocation.

subsection.text: Without prior authorization of the Commission, a person may not transfer a controlling interest in a water company or sewage disposal company to another person.

The Commission may authorize the transfer of a controlling interest in a water company or sewage disposal company if the Commission finds that the transfer is consistent with the public convenience and necessity.
Except as otherwise provided by law, this section does not apply to a requirement or violation of:

paragraph.text: Subtitle 4 of this title;
Title 7, Subtitle 1 of this article;
Title 8, Subtitles 1 and 3 of this article; or
Title 9, Subtitle 3 of this article.

subsection.text: A public service company:

paragraph.text: shall comply fully with the requirements of this division; and
may not violate any provision of this division.

subsection.text: Except as provided in subsection (b) of this section, a public service company shall file with the Commission:

paragraph.text: an annual report for the preceding calendar year; and
special reports, information, contracts, records, and copies as required by the Commission.

subsection.text: Unless otherwise directed by the Commission, a public service company is not required to comply with subsection (a) of this section if the public service company is:

paragraph.text: a common carrier; or
a telephone company whose rates are not regulated by the Commission under Title 4 of this article.

subsection.text: The Commission may require a public service company that files documents under subsection (a) of this section to file the documents under oath.

section.text: A public service company shall furnish equipment, services, and facilities that are safe, adequate, just, reasonable, economical, and efficient, considering the conservation of natural resources and the quality of the environment.

paragraph.text: A public service company shall notify the Commission of any accident involving the public service company that results in:

subparagraph.text: personal injury requiring hospitalization;
property damage exceeding $50,000; or
loss of life.

paragraph.text: The public service company shall notify the Commission within 30 days after the day the accident occurs or within a period that the Commission prescribes.

subsection.text: The notice:

paragraph.text: shall be in a form that the Commission prescribes; and

may not be admissible in evidence, or used for any purpose against the public service company that provides the notice, in an action for damages arising out of any matter that is reported in the notice.

section.text: Except as otherwise provided in this subtitle or by other law, the provisions of this subtitle are not subject to the jurisdiction of the Commission.

subsection.text: This subtitle does not authorize a corporation to take or use property unless just compensation, as agreed on with the owner or awarded by a jury, has been paid or tendered to the parties entitled to compensation or paid into court.

This subtitle does not authorize the location of a public road on private property without the consent of the owner or the decision of the county commissioners or county council after notice and an opportunity to be heard as required by law for opening or altering public roads.

This section applies to a domestic or foreign corporation that is or may become engaged in the business of transmitting or supplying natural gas, artificial gas, or a mixture of natural and artificial gases.

Subject to subsection (c) of this section, a corporation described in subsection (a) of this section may acquire by condemnation, in accordance with Title 12 of the Real Property Article, rights-of-way or easements necessary to lay, construct, modify, repair, maintain, operate, and remove pipelines and appurtenances to pipelines for transmitting and supplying gas.

paragraph.text: Except as provided in paragraph (2) of this subsection, a corporation may not condemn rights-of-way or easements under subsection (b) of this section unless the corporation:

sub-subparagraph.text: transmits gas directly to local consumers in the State along the corporation’s proposed rights-of-way; and
offers to contract with those local consumers to supply them directly with gas on terms and conditions subject to the approval of the Commission; and

subparagraph.text: has certified to the State Department of Assessments and Taxation the name and address of a resident agent of the corporation in the State, service of process on whom shall bind the corporation until the appointment of a substitute is certified to the State Department of Assessments and Taxation.

paragraph.text: Paragraph (1) of this subsection does not affect the right of a corporation that was transmitting natural gas, artificial gas, or a mixture of natural and artificial gases for public use through one or more pipelines in the State on or before June 1, 1931, to condemn for public use necessary rights-of-way or easements for:

subparagraph.text: a pipeline or appurtenances to a pipeline in use on or before June 1, 1931;
any incidental relocations of a pipeline or appurtenances to a pipeline in use on or before June 1, 1931; or

any additional pipelines or appurtenances to pipelines along and on the same routes or along and on any incidental relocations of a pipeline or appurtenances to a pipeline in use on or before June 1, 1931.

subsection.text: This section does not affect the application of any provision of this article that applies generally or specifically to a corporation that is or may become engaged in the business of transmitting or supplying natural gas, artificial gas, or a mixture of natural and artificial gases.

paragraph.text: In this section the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Oil pipeline corporation” means a corporation of this State, any other state, or the United States, that is:

subparagraph.text: engaged in the business of transporting refined petroleum products by pipeline as a common carrier public service corporation; and
subject to the jurisdiction of either the United States Department of Energy (Federal Energy Regulatory Commission) or the Commission.
“Property” means real property in fee simple or any lesser right, interest, or estate that is necessary for the intrastate or interstate purposes of the oil pipeline corporation or both.
“Property” includes:

sub-subparagraph.text: privately owned property;
property owned by a public body; and
property devoted to public use if an acquisition under this section does not materially interfere with that public use.

subsection.text: An oil pipeline corporation that is operating an oil pipeline that existed in the State on or before July 1, 1978, may acquire by condemnation, in accordance with Title 12 of the Real Property Article, any property necessary to:

paragraph.text: operate those existing oil pipelines and appurtenances; or

construct and operate additional oil pipelines and appurtenances along, on, adjacent to, or incidentally deviating not more than 50 feet from the routes followed by the corporation’s existing rights–of–way.

subsection.text: The right to acquire property under this section may be exercised only in Anne Arundel, Baltimore, Carroll, Cecil, Harford, Howard, Montgomery, and Prince George’s counties and Baltimore City.

paragraph.text: An oil pipeline corporation shall restore to its original condition any property used for construction or maintenance of a pipeline.

subparagraph.text: Except as provided in subparagraph (ii) of this paragraph, the construction or maintenance of the pipeline and the restoration of the property shall be completed within 7 days after the start of the construction or maintenance on that parcel of property.

If weather conditions or the nature of the terrain make completion within 7 days unfeasible, the oil pipeline corporation shall complete the construction or maintenance of the pipeline and the restoration of the property within 30 days.

paragraph.text: The right to acquire property under this section may not be exercised unless the oil pipeline corporation, whether or not it is otherwise subject to the jurisdiction of the Commission, first obtains an order from the Commission finding the acquisition to be in the public interest.
Before the Commission makes a finding and issues an order under this subsection, the Commission shall hold a public hearing.
The oil pipeline corporation shall give written notice of the public hearing to all affected property owners.

subsection.text: This section does not affect any other law of the State that applies generally or specifically to oil pipeline corporations.

A railroad company or its authorized agent may agree with the owner to purchase, use, occupy, or divert the owner’s land, earth, gravel, stone, timber, streams, materials, or improvements that the company wants for the proper construction or repair of the railroad company’s roads or works.
The company may acquire the property by condemnation under Title 12 of the Real Property Article if:

paragraph.text: the company cannot agree with the owner of the property; or
an owner:

subparagraph.text: is a minor, is adjudged to be mentally incompetent, or is under any other legal disability to contract; or
is absent from the county in which the property is located when the company wants the property.

paragraph.text: A railroad company may change the location or grade of any portion of its road if the company finds the change is necessary for any reasonable cause, including to avoid:

subparagraph.text: inconvenience to public travel;
dangerous or difficult curves or grades; or
unsafe or unsubstantial grounds or foundations.

paragraph.text: A change of location or grade under this section shall follow the general route of the existing road.
A railroad company may enter on and take land and make surveys necessary to make the change in location or grade in accordance with Title 12 of the Real Property Article.
A railroad company is liable to the owner of the land on which the road was constructed for any damages caused by a change in location or grade of the road.
The amount of damages determined shall be paid to the owner or deposited into court.
An owner shall claim damages within:

subparagraph.text: 30 days after actual notice of the intended change has been given to the owner, if the owner resides on the premises; or
60 days after publication of notice in a newspaper in general circulation in the county, if the owner is a nonresident.

subsection.text: If a railroad company condemns land under this section, the condemnation is binding on the company, unless the company chooses to abandon the location within 30 days after making the condemnation.

A railroad company and the municipal corporation, public officer, or public authority that owns or has control of any road, street, alley, or other public way or ground necessary to locate any part of the railroad may agree on the manner, terms, and conditions allowing the railroad company to use or occupy the road, street, alley, or other public way or ground.

If the parties are unable to agree and the railroad company needs to use or occupy the road, street, alley, or other public way or ground, the railroad company may acquire the property by condemnation in accordance with Title 12 of the Real Property Article.

paragraph.text: A railroad company that lays track on any public street, road, alley, or other public way or ground is responsible for any damage done by the location of the track to private property on or near the public way or ground.
The owner of the private property shall bring a civil action for damages under this subsection within 2 years after the completion of the track.

subsection.text: A railroad company may not pass through Baltimore City without the consent of the Mayor and City Council.

section.text: The power of a railroad company to condemn land and other property under this subtitle includes the power to condemn, for railroad purposes, private crossings or ways and land and other property to provide substitute outlets.

Sections 5-405, 5-406, and 5-407 of this subtitle apply to all railroads operated by electricity, cable, or other improved motive power, whether the property proposed to be condemned is located in a county or Baltimore City, where streets and alleys have not been opened and occupied as city streets.

subsection.text: This section applies to:

paragraph.text: a telegraph company that has its principal office in the State;
a telephone company that has its principal office in the State;
a corporation formed as a Class 13 corporation under Article 23, § 28 of the Code of 1904; and
a telephone company that owns lines and provides local exchange or interexchange service in the State with the approval of the Commission.

subsection.text: A company described in subsection (a) of this section has the same power granted to telegraph and telephone companies by §§ 8-103, 8-104, 8-105, and 8-106(a) of this article and may:

paragraph.text: construct and lay lines underground or above ground on any route for which it is authorized to construct lines as a whole or in part; and

except as provided in subsection (d) of this section, acquire by condemnation, in accordance with Title 12 of the Real Property Article, any property or right that the company considers necessary for its purposes.
Before using either the surface of or the ground beneath the streets or highways of Baltimore City, the company shall obtain the consent of the Mayor and City Council.

This subsection does not apply to corporations that were in practical operation on June 1, 1910, and that had laid or constructed lines, pipes, mains, or other structures in Baltimore City, unless the corporations use new and additional streets and highways in Baltimore City for their lines, pipes, mains, or other structures.

subsection.text: This section does not authorize a telephone company described in subsection (a)(4) of this section that, as of September 30, 1993, did not have the power of condemnation granted to a telegraph company under §§ 8-103, 8-104, 8-105, and 8-106(a) of this article, to acquire property for communications towers or buildings.

section.text: A water company may acquire by condemnation, in accordance with Title 12 of the Real Property Article, any land or water rights that the company is authorized to acquire to lay pipes or construct its work, if:

paragraph.text: the company cannot agree with the owner of the land or water rights; or
an owner:

subparagraph.text: is a minor, is adjudged to be mentally incompetent, or is under any other legal disability to contract; or
when the company needs the land or water rights, is absent from the county or city in which the property is located.

paragraph.text: This subsection applies only to corporations that operate in Maryland.
Except as provided in paragraph (4) of this subsection, a public service company shall obtain authorization from the Commission before the public service company:

subparagraph.text: assumes or guarantees an obligation or liability with respect to stocks, bonds, securities, notes, or other evidence of indebtedness of any person that is payable wholly or partly more than 12 months after the date of the assumption or guarantee;
issues stocks, bonds, securities, notes, or other evidence of indebtedness that is payable wholly or partly more than 12 months after the date issued; or

lends money to an affiliate, as defined in § 7–501 of this article, at rates or on terms that are significantly more favorable to the affiliate than the rates or terms that are otherwise commercially available to the affiliate.

paragraph.text: An issuance under paragraph (2)(ii) of this subsection shall conform to §§ 6–102 and 6–103 of this subtitle.

Prior authorization of the Commission is not required for an assumption or guarantee under paragraph (2)(i) of this subsection or an issuance under paragraph (2)(ii) of this subsection made by a gas company, electric company, or telephone company whose gross annual revenues, for the most recent calendar year for which data are available, are less than 3% of the total gross annual revenues of all public service companies in the State during the same calendar year, if the gas company, electric company, or telephone company:

subparagraph.text: provides prior written notice to the Commission of the transaction; and
obtains approval of the transaction from the entity in another state that regulates the gas company, electric company, or telephone company.

paragraph.text: Subject to the requirements of subsection (c) of this section, the Commission may authorize an act described under subsection (a)(2) of this section if the Commission finds that the act is consistent with the public convenience and necessity.
Authorization under this subsection does not:

subparagraph.text: revive a lapsed franchise, validate an invalid franchise, or add to the powers and privileges in a franchise; or
waive a forfeiture.

paragraph.text: This subsection does not apply to the formation of a holding company by a public service company in a corporate reorganization that involves an exchange of stock of the public service company for stock in the holding company.
In this subsection, a company controlling a public service company is deemed a public service company of the same class as the controlled public service company.
Without prior authorization of the Commission, a public service company may not take, hold, or acquire any part of the capital stock of a public service company that:

subparagraph.text: operates in Maryland; and
is of the same class as the acquiring company.

Except as provided in subparagraph (ii) of this paragraph, a stock corporation may not take, hold, or acquire more than 10% of the total capital stock of a public service company that operates in Maryland unless:

sub-subparagraph.text: the stock is acquired as collateral security; and
the Commission approves the acquisition.

subparagraph.text: The Commission may authorize a public service company of the same class to take, hold, or acquire more than 10% of the total capital stock of a public service company that operates in Maryland.

paragraph.text: A public service company may not be a party to a violation of this subsection.

Notwithstanding paragraph (2) of this subsection, § 6–105 of this subtitle shall apply, and the provisions of this subsection do not apply, to the acquisition, ownership, or disposition of any capital stock or voting securities of a company that controls, directly or indirectly, a gas and electric company.

Notwithstanding any other provision of this subsection, the Commission may authorize, in accordance with § 6–105 of this subtitle, the taking, holding, or acquiring of all or any part of the capital stock of a gas and electric company that operates in the State by a stock corporation or a public service company that is not of the same class as the gas and electric company.

subsection.text: This section applies only to public service companies that operate in Maryland.

The Commission shall authorize a public service company to issue stocks, bonds, securities, notes, or other evidence of indebtedness, payable wholly or partly more than 12 months after the date of issuance, if the Commission finds that the issuance is reasonably required for the public service company to:

paragraph.text: acquire property;
construct, complete, extend, or improve its facilities;
discharge or lawfully refund its obligations;
maintain or improve service; or

reimburse money, not secured by or obtained from the issuance, that is expended for a purpose described in item (1), (2), or (3) of this subsection within 5 years before the filing of an application with the Commission for the reimbursement.

The Commission may authorize a public service company to issue stocks, bonds, securities, notes, or other evidence of indebtedness, payable wholly or partly more than 12 months after the date of issuance, for the public service company to:

subparagraph.text: conform the aggregate capitalization of the public service company to the value of its property; or
subject to paragraph (2) of this subsection, pay a dividend in shares of the public service company’s own stock.

paragraph.text: An order of the Commission authorizing an issuance under paragraph (1)(ii) of this subsection shall state that:

subparagraph.text: concurrently with the issuance, the public service company shall transfer from surplus to capital an amount that the Commission determines under paragraph (3) of this subsection; and

a sum equal to the amount to be transferred has been expended from income or other money in the treasury of the public service company not secured by, obtained from, or reimbursed by the issuance of stocks, bonds, notes, or other evidence of indebtedness of the public service company for a purpose described in subsection (b)(1), (2), or (3) of this section.

paragraph.text: The amount that the Commission determines under paragraph (2)(i) of this subsection may not be less than:

subparagraph.text: the aggregate par value of the stock whose issuance is to be authorized; or
if the stock has no par value, the capital value of the stock.

paragraph.text: An authorization by the Commission under subsection (b) or (c) of this section shall be by order.
The order shall specify:

subparagraph.text: the amount of the issuance authorized; and
the purpose under subsection (b) or (c) of this section for which the issuance is reasonably required.

paragraph.text: Notwithstanding subsections (b), (c), (d), and (g) of this section, the Commission may approve the issuance of stocks, bonds, securities, notes, or other evidence of indebtedness in connection with the organization of a new public service company by the purchaser of the franchise or property of a public service company sold under judicial proceedings, mortgage, or deed of trust.

An issuance that the Commission approves under this subsection shall be in the amount that the Commission considers necessary fully to protect the rights and equities of the holders of the securities of the predecessor company.

subsection.text: A public service company’s application for authorization under this section of long–term debt in excess of $1,000,000 shall include a copy of any restrictive covenant attached to the debt.

paragraph.text: Except as provided in paragraph (2) of this subsection, this section does not prevent a public service company from issuing, without the prior consent of the Commission, notes that are:

subparagraph.text: for proper corporate purposes;
not otherwise in violation of the law; and
payable at periods totaling not more than 12 months after the date of issuance.

paragraph.text: Except as authorized under subsection (b) or (c) of this section, notes issued under paragraph (1) of this subsection may not be refunded directly or indirectly, wholly or partly, by an evidence of indebtedness running for more than 12 months.

subsection.text: This section applies only to public service companies that operate in Maryland.

paragraph.text: A public service company may not:

subparagraph.text: capitalize or issue bonds against or as lien on a contract for consolidation, merger, or lease; or
except as provided in paragraph (2) of this subsection, capitalize a franchise or the right to own a franchise.

paragraph.text: A public service company may capitalize a franchise or right to own a franchise in an amount not exceeding the amount, exclusive of any tax or annual charge, actually paid to the State or a political subdivision as consideration for the grant of the franchise or right.

subsection.text: The stated capital, as determined under Title 2, Subtitle 3 of the Corporations and Associations Article, of a public service company formed by a merger or consolidation of corporations may not exceed, solely by virtue of the merger or consolidation, the stated capital of the corporations merged or consolidated plus any additional sum paid in cash.

paragraph.text: This subsection does not apply to the capitalization of a franchise to be a public service company.
Notwithstanding any other provision of this article, the Commission may approve the capitalization of tangible and intangible property of:

subparagraph.text: a newly chartered public service company; or
a public service company organized or reorganized by the purchaser of the franchise and property of its predecessor at a sale under judicial proceedings, mortgage, or deed of trust.

paragraph.text: Capitalization under paragraph (2) of this subsection shall be in the amount and form that the Commission considers reasonably necessary to enable the public service company to obtain the capital necessary to establish itself as a going concern.

section.text: Any contract, assignment, transfer, or agreement for transfer or purchase of stock in violation of the provisions of this article is void.

subsection.text: In this section, “affiliate” has the meaning stated in § 7–501 of this article.

paragraph.text: The General Assembly finds that:

subparagraph.text: existing legislation requires the approval by the Commission of the acquisition by one public service company of another public service company’s stocks and obligations, but does not require the Commission’s approval of these acquisitions by persons not engaged in the public utility business in the State; and

an attempt by a person not engaged in the public utility business in the State to acquire the power to exercise any substantial influence over the policies and actions of a public service company that provides electricity or gas in the State could result in harm to the customers of the public service company, including the degradation of utility services, higher rates, weakened financial structure, and diminution of utility assets.

paragraph.text: The General Assembly declares that it is the policy of the State to regulate acquisitions by persons that are not engaged in the public utility business in the State of the power to exercise any substantial influence over the policies and actions of a public service company that provides electricity or gas in the State in order to prevent unnecessary and unwarranted harm to the customers of the public service company.

subsection.text: This section applies to the acquisition of an electric company, gas and electric company, or a gas company that operates in Maryland.

paragraph.text: A gas and electric company, at the same time as a filing by the company or within 10 days after receipt by the company, shall provide the Commission with a copy of any document regarding the acquisition of voting securities of the gas and electric company or any company that owns or controls the gas and electric company, filed or received by the company, that is filed with:

subparagraph.text: the Securities and Exchange Commission;
the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission;
the Nuclear Regulatory Commission;
the Department of Justice;
the Federal Trade Commission; or
any successor agency.

paragraph.text: The Commission shall provide the gas and electric company with the same confidentiality and other protections provided by the federal agency with which the filing was made.

Without prior authorization from the Commission, a person may not acquire, directly or indirectly, the power to exercise any substantial influence over the policies and actions of an electric company, gas and electric company, or gas company, if the person would become an affiliate of the electric company, gas and electric company, or gas company as a result of the acquisition.

For the purposes of this subsection, a person may not be considered to have acquired, directly or indirectly, the power to exercise any substantial influence over the policies and actions of a gas and electric company if the person:

subparagraph.text: after any acquisition of voting interests of a company that owns or controls a gas and electric company, directly or indirectly, owns, controls, or has the right to vote, or direct the voting of, not more than 20% of the outstanding voting interests of a company that owns or controls a gas and electric company; and
does not have the right to designate more than 20% of the board of directors or other governing body of a company that owns or controls a gas and electric company.

paragraph.text: Paragraph (2) of this subsection may not be construed to apply to the acquisition of any voting interests of a gas and electric company.

If a person that acquires voting securities of a company that owns or controls a gas and electric company after the acquisition actually exercises substantial influence over the policies and actions of a gas and electric company, the Commission may order compliance with, and take any actions authorized by, other provisions of this article with respect to the gas and electric company.

subsection.text: An application for authorization under subsection (e) of this section must include detailed information regarding:

paragraph.text: the applicant’s identity and financial ability;
the background of the key personnel associated with the applicant;
the source and amounts of funds or other consideration to be used in the acquisition;
the applicant’s compliance with federal law in carrying out the acquisition;
whether the applicant or the key personnel associated with the applicant have violated any State or federal statutes regulating the activities of public service companies;
all documents relating to the transaction giving rise to the application;
the applicant’s experience in operating public service companies providing electricity;
the applicant’s plan for operating the public service company;
how the acquisition will serve the customers of the public service company in the public interest, convenience, and necessity; and
any other information that the Commission may specify by regulation or order.
The Commission promptly shall:

subparagraph.text: examine and investigate each application received under this section; and
undertake any proceedings necessary or convenient to review the application in accordance with Title 3 of this article and issue an order concerning the acquisition.

paragraph.text: The Commission shall consider the following factors in considering an acquisition under this section:

subparagraph.text: the potential impact of the acquisition on rates and charges paid by customers and on the services and conditions of operation of the public service company;
the potential impact of the acquisition on continuing investment needs for the maintenance of utility services, plant, and related infrastructure;
the proposed capital structure that will result from the acquisition, including allocation of earnings from the public service company;
the potential effects on employment by the public service company;
the projected allocation of any savings that are expected to the public service company between stockholders and rate payers;
issues of reliability, quality of service, and quality of customer service;
the potential impact of the acquisition on community investment;
affiliate and cross–subsidization issues;
the use or pledge of utility assets for the benefit of an affiliate;
jurisdictional and choice–of–law issues;
whether it is necessary to revise the Commission’s ring fencing and code of conduct regulations in light of the acquisition; and
any other issues the Commission considers relevant to the assessment of acquisition in relation to the public interest, convenience, and necessity.

If the Commission finds that the acquisition is consistent with the public interest, convenience, and necessity, including benefits and no harm to consumers, the Commission shall issue an order granting the application.
The Commission may condition an order authorizing the acquisition on the applicant’s satisfactory performance or adherence to specific requirements.

paragraph.text: If the Commission does not find that the acquisition is consistent with the public interest, convenience, and necessity, including benefits and no harm to consumers, the Commission shall issue an order denying the application.
The applicant bears the burden of showing that granting the acquisition is consistent with the public interest, convenience, and necessity, including benefits and no harm to consumers.

subparagraph.text: Except as provided in item (ii) of this subparagraph, the Commission shall issue an order with respect to the application no later than 180 days after the filing of the application for authorization.

Unless the Commission finds, based on good cause, that the 180–day period should be extended for an additional 45 days, failure of the Commission to issue an order within the 180–day period shall be considered to be an approval of the acquisition by the Commission.

subsection.text: Nothing in this section prohibits dissemination by any party of information concerning the acquisition if the dissemination does not otherwise conflict with federal or State law.
In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Control” means the possession, direct or indirect, of the power to direct or cause the direction of the management or policies of a person.
“Financing lease” means a lease that, during the noncancelable lease period:

paragraph.text: covers at least 75% of the economic life of the property; or

has terms that assure the lessor of a full recovery of the fair market value that would normally be represented by the lessor’s investment of the property at the start of the lease and a reasonable return on the use of the assets invested, subject only to limited risk in the realization of the residual interest in the property and the credit risks generally associated with secured loans.

subsection.text: “Joint venture” means a joint business arrangement between a public service company and another person for mutual benefit, with the understanding that each will share in the profits and losses and have a voice in management.
“Long-term debt” means a debt due at least 1 year after the date of indebtedness.
“Parent” means:

paragraph.text: every firm, holding company, or other person that ultimately controls a public service company; or
any intermediary entity that controls a public service company.

subsection.text: “Person” includes an individual, corporation, estate, trust, partnership, association, two or more persons having a joint or common interest, or any other legal or commercial entity.
“Short-term debt” means a debt due within 1 year after the date of indebtedness.

“SIC code and short title” means a 4-digit industry Standard Industrial Classification code and short title listed in the most recent Standard Industrial Classification manual published by the Office of Management and Budget of the Executive Office of the President.
The Commission may classify the public service companies under its jurisdiction.
Two public service companies are of the same class, if they are both:

paragraph.text: common carrier companies;
electric companies;
gas companies;
gas and electric companies;
sewage disposal companies;
telegraph companies;
telephone companies; or
water companies.

section.text: The Commission may:

paragraph.text: establish a uniform system of records for each class of public service company; and
prescribe the manner and form in which a public service company shall keep records and enter particular items.

section.text: The Commission shall prescribe a system, a form of records, and a form of annual report for public service companies that conform as nearly as possible to the system and forms that any corresponding federal regulatory unit requires for public service companies of the same class in interstate commerce.

paragraph.text: This subsection does not apply to railroads.

Except as provided in subsection (b) of this section, each public service company shall file with the Commission an annual report containing information on its corporate structure, affiliations of its officers and directors, and debt holdings.

subparagraph.text: Notwithstanding any specific reporting requirements in this subtitle, the Commission may prescribe the contents of the annual report to be filed by a public service company whose gross annual revenues for the most recent calendar year for which data are available are less than 0.003% of the total gross annual revenues of all public service companies in the State during the same calendar year.

A small rural electric cooperative described in § 7-502(a) of this article may satisfy the reporting requirement by submitting to the Commission a copy of a report including the required information that the small rural electric cooperative submits to the rural utilities service.

subsection.text: Unless otherwise directed by the Commission, a public service company is not required to comply with subsection (a) of this section if the public service company is:

paragraph.text: a common carrier; or
a telephone company whose rates are not regulated by the Commission under Title 4 of this article.

subsection.text: The president, treasurer, or general manager of a public service company shall verify the company’s annual report under oath.
The Commission may:

paragraph.text: require a public service company to submit reports and information that the Commission reasonably desires;
prescribe the form, contents, and deadlines for the reports and information; and
require amendments or corrections to the reports within a set period.

subsection.text: A public service company shall file its annual report with the Commission within the time the Commission sets after the end of the year that the report covers.

paragraph.text: The Commission shall provide each public service company with a blank form of an annual report in time to allow the public service company to comply with subsection (a) of this section.

Unless the Commission notifies a public service company of a proposed change at least 6 months before the start of the year for which an annual report is due, the Commission may not change the form of the annual report in a way that requires the public service company to change the manner or form of its record keeping.

section.text: In addition to any other information that the Commission requires, the annual report of a public service company shall state:

paragraph.text: the amount and kind of:

subparagraph.text: authorized capital stock;
capital stock issued and outstanding;
authorized bonded indebtedness; and
bonds and other evidence of indebtedness issued and outstanding;

paragraph.text: receipts and expenditures for the year reported;
the amount paid as dividends and interest on bonds or other evidence of indebtedness;
the amount of salary paid to each officer, by name, and the amount paid as wages to employees;
the location of the public service company’s plants with a full description of each plant and franchise, stating in detail how each franchise was acquired; and
when applicable:

subparagraph.text: a monthly compilation of expenditures that were the basis for any fuel rate adjustment; and
an annual recapitulation of the information required under subitem (i) of this item.

subsection.text: A public service company shall list in its annual report the name and address, basis of control, and principal business activities of:

paragraph.text: the public service company; and
each:

subparagraph.text: parent;
subsidiary of the public service company;
organization the public service company controls; and
joint venture in excess of $1,000,000 in which the public service company is involved.

paragraph.text: For each principal business activity described in subsection (a) of this section, a public service company shall list and describe by SIC code and short title each industry in which the public service company’s activities generated, during the reporting year, at least 10% of gross revenues or $5,000,000.

The public service company shall compile the list described under paragraph (1) of this subsection in order of significance relative to the total activities of the public service company, based on the percentage of gross revenues generated within each industry.

subsection.text: For each corporation, partnership, or other business organization in which a public service company owns more than 5% of the outstanding voting securities or other ownership interests, the public service company shall, in its annual report:

paragraph.text: list the corporation, partnership, or other business organization; and
indicate the percentage that the public service company owns.
A public service company shall list in its annual report the name and address of:

subparagraph.text: each principal officer, director, trustee, or partner of the public service company and its parent; and
each individual exercising functions similar to that of a director, trustee, or partner on behalf of the public service company and its parent.

paragraph.text: For each individual described in paragraph (1) of this subsection, the public service company shall list:

subparagraph.text: the title and position with the public service company and any parent;
the title and position with any subsidiary of the public service company and any other company, firm, or organization that the public service company controls;
the principal occupation or business affiliation, if different than that provided in item (i) or (ii) of this paragraph; and
each affiliation with any other business or financial organization, firm, or partnership doing business with the public service company.

subsection.text: In its annual report, a public service company shall:

paragraph.text: list each contract, agreement, or other business arrangement exceeding an aggregate value of $1,000,000 between the public service company and any business or financial organization, firm, or partnership listed under subsection (a)(2)(iii) and (iv) of this section;

except for compensation related to a position with the public service company, list each contract, agreement, or other business arrangement with a value exceeding $2,500 entered into during the reporting year between the public service company and each officer and director listed in subsection (a) of this section;
for each contract, agreement, or other business arrangement described in paragraph (1) or (2) of this subsection, identify the parties, amounts, dates, and product or service involved; and
list the professional services performed for the public service company by each firm, partnership, or organization with which an officer or director of the public service company is affiliated.
Except as provided in paragraph (2) of this subsection, a public service company shall describe in its annual report each long-term debt of the public service company exceeding $1,000,000, including:

subparagraph.text: the name and address of the creditor;
the character of the debt;
the nature of any security;
the date of origin of the debt;
the date of maturity of the debt;
the total amount of the debt;
the rate of interest; and
the total amount of interest to be paid.

paragraph.text: If the long-term debt is in the form of bonds, debentures, or other widely held debt, the public service company shall list the name and address of the trustee, if available, in place of the name and address of the creditor.

subsection.text: In its annual report, a public service company shall:

paragraph.text: except for the accounts payable of the public service company, describe each short–term debt, including:

subparagraph.text: the name and address of the creditor;
the character of the debt;
the period of the debt;
the rate of interest;
the total amount of the debt;
the nature of any security; and
the date the debt was paid or shall be paid;

paragraph.text: describe, if involving aggregate payments exceeding $1,000,000, each financing lease, equipment trust, conditional sales contract, or major liability related to the capital assets of the public service company; and
provide a copy of any restrictive covenant attached to the debt described in item (1) or (2) of this subsection.

subsection.text: In its annual report, a public service company shall, if available:

paragraph.text: list the name and address of each holder of more than 5% of each issue reported under this section; and
identify the holder as a bank, broker, holding company, individual, or other person.

section.text: Except as otherwise provided by law, the provisions of this subtitle are not subject to the jurisdiction of the Commission.

subsection.text: A gas company incorporated in Maryland may:

paragraph.text: manufacture artificial gas;
sell or furnish any quantity of natural gas or artificial gas that may be required in any municipal corporation or county of the State;
lay pipe under the roadways or other public ways of any county or municipal corporation of the State to transmit natural gas or artificial gas; and
connect the pipe from the place of supply to any structure or object.
A gas company must have the consent of the governing body of the municipal corporation or county before laying any gas pipe in accordance with subsection (a) of this section.

The governing body of the municipal corporation or county may adopt reasonable regulations and conditions for the laying of a gas pipe, including regulations requiring the gas company to refill and repave any roadway or other public way under which the pipe is laid.

subsection.text: A gas company, whether incorporated in Maryland or another state, that is authorized by a governing body of a municipal corporation or county to lay or maintain pipe or other structures in a roadway or other public way or place shall obtain consent from the Commission before using the pipe or other structure to transmit and supply natural gas, artificial gas, or a mixture of natural gas and artificial gas.
This section does not:

paragraph.text: extend the duration of a franchise granted by the governing body of a municipal corporation or county; or
except as provided in this section, change the terms or conditions of the franchise.

subsection.text: An electric company incorporated in Maryland may:

paragraph.text: manufacture, sell, and furnish electric power in any municipal corporation or county of the State;
construct a power line to transmit power under, along, on, or over the roadways or public ways of any municipal corporation or county of the State; and
connect the power line from the place of supply to any other structure or object.
An electric company must have the consent of the governing body of the municipal corporation or county before laying or constructing any power line in accordance with subsection (a) of this section.

The governing body of the municipal corporation or county may adopt reasonable regulations and conditions for the laying of a power line, including regulations requiring the electric company to refill and repave any roadway or public way under which the power line is laid.

section.text: The formation, organization, and governance of electric cooperatives incorporated in Maryland are governed by Title 5, Subtitle 6 of the Corporations and Associations Article.

subsection.text: A water company incorporated in the State has the powers necessary for the purposes for which it is incorporated and may:

paragraph.text: acquire, possess, and use land, water rights, and other property for those purposes; and
lay pipes and construct works necessary or suitable to carry out its purposes.

A water company shall obtain the consent of the governing body of the municipal corporation or county before laying pipes or constructing waterworks in that jurisdiction under subsection (a) of this section.
The governing body of the municipal corporation or county may adopt reasonable regulations for the laying of pipes, construction of works, and operations of a water company.

subsection.text: This section does not authorize the incorporation of a water company to operate in Baltimore City.

paragraph.text: Annually, the Chairman of the Commission shall forward to the Secretary of Natural Resources a 10-year plan listing possible and proposed sites, including the associated transmission routes, for the construction of electric plants within the State.
