This section does not authorize a company to construct a bridge across any of the navigable waters of the State.

subsection.text: A line constructed under subsection (a) of this section is not a public nuisance and is not subject to abatement by a private party if the line does not interfere with or disturb:

paragraph.text: the public use of roads, highways, and bridges;
the navigation of the waters of the State; or
the convenience of a landowner more than is unavoidable.

section.text: Notwithstanding the provisions of § 8-103(b) of this subtitle, a telegraph or telephone company or a corporation authorized under § 5-410(a)(3) of this article is responsible for damage a person may sustain through the erection, continuance, or use of telegraph, telephone, or electric facilities.

subsection.text: If, within a reasonable time after due notice, a telegraph or telephone company or a corporation authorized under § 5-410(a)(3) of this article fails or refuses to remove telegraph, telephone, or electric facilities causing damage, the owner or possessor of land or a political subdivision may sue for damages.

paragraph.text: If the person filing suit for damages under this section prevails, the company may elect to pay damages for allowing the company to maintain the facilities permanently.

If the damages paid include damages for allowing the company to maintain the facilities permanently, the right of the company to maintain the facilities permanently shall be confirmed as if the right were granted by the parties to the suit.

subsection.text: To obtain an easement, the president and directors of a telegraph or telephone company or a corporation authorized under § 5-410(a)(3) of this article may apply to the circuit court of the county containing the land or bridge where the telegraph, telephone, or electric facilities will be placed to empanel a jury to appraise the loss or damage that will be sustained by the owner or possessor of the land or bridge.

subparagraph.text: The jury shall make a return and inquisition in writing that is signed and sealed by each juror.
The return and inquisition shall state the amount of the loss or damage.
The county sheriff shall return the jury’s inquisition to the clerk of the circuit court of the county.
The clerk shall file the inquisition with the court.

paragraph.text: Except as provided in paragraph (4) of this subsection, the court shall confirm the inquisition of the jury and the clerk shall record the inquisition at the expense of the company.
For good cause, the court may set aside the inquisition and direct another inquisition to be taken as provided in this section.

When the value of the loss or damage is paid or tendered to the owner of the land or the legal representative of the owner of the land, the company is entitled to the easement as if the owner of the land conveyed the easement to the company.
If the value is not received when tendered, it may be received at any time without costs by the owner of the land or the legal representative of the owner of the land.

subsection.text: Except as provided in subsection (b) of this section, the owner of timber growing along a telegraph or telephone line is not subject to an action for damages if:

paragraph.text: the telegraph or telephone line prevents the owner of the timber from cutting and felling the timber; and
in cutting or felling the timber, the owner damages the telegraph or telephone line.

subsection.text: An owner of timber is subject to an action for damages if, in cutting and felling the timber, the owner willfully and intentionally injures the telegraph or telephone line.
A telegraph company doing business in this State shall:

paragraph.text: receive telegrams from and for other telegraph companies and from or for any individual; and
except as provided in subsection (b) of this section, transmit telegrams received:

subparagraph.text: in the manner established by the rules and regulations of the telegraph company;
in the order received; and
with impartiality and good faith.

subsection.text: Subsection (a) of this section does not apply to a telegraph company that makes an arrangement with newspapers for the transmission of information of general and public interest out of the order received for the purpose of publication.
A telegraph company that violates subsection (a) of this section is liable to the person sending or desiring to send the telegram for:

paragraph.text: $100 for each instance of neglect or refusal to receive or transmit a telegram; and
the costs of the suit.
In this section the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Eligible subscriber” means an individual who is certified to a local telephone company by the Department of Human Resources as receiving:

subparagraph.text: assistance under Title 5, Subtitle 3 of the Human Services Article;
assistance from the electric universal service program under § 7–512.1 of this article;
assistance from the Maryland Energy Assistance Program under Title 5, Subtitle 5A of the Human Services Article;
State–funded public assistance benefits; or
Supplemental Security Income under Title XVI of the federal Social Security Act.

paragraph.text: “Telephone lifeline service” means local telephone services provided to eligible subscribers at a discount in accordance with this section.

subsection.text: At the direction of the Commission, a local telephone company with more than 10,000 subscribers shall offer telephone lifeline service to eligible subscribers subject to the following conditions:

paragraph.text: no other local voice telephone service may be provided to the dwelling unit of the eligible subscriber applying for telephone lifeline service; and
an inside wiring maintenance plan is not provided to the eligible subscriber.
An eligible subscriber may select a telephone lifeline service under either paragraph (2) or (3) of this subsection.
An eligible subscriber who selects telephone lifeline service under this paragraph:

subparagraph.text: shall receive:

sub-subparagraph.text: an individual residential local exchange access line; and
the first 30 residential local untimed messages each billing month at no additional charge;

subparagraph.text: shall be charged:

sub-subparagraph.text: 50% of the lowest applicable and approved federal and State tariff rates for the access line and included residential local untimed messages, minus any applicable waiver of federal tariff provisions for eligible subscribers, plus all applicable federal, State, and local taxes;
the full applicable tariff rates for all other residential local untimed messages; and
except as otherwise provided in subsection (d) of this section, the full applicable tariff rates for all other services; and

subparagraph.text: may not be provided any premium services, including foreign zone or foreign exchange service.

paragraph.text: An eligible subscriber who selects telephone lifeline service under this paragraph:

subparagraph.text: shall receive an individual residential local exchange access line with unlimited residential local untimed messages for a monthly charge of $10; and
may purchase up to two value–added services at the full applicable tariff rates.

subsection.text: The telephone company shall charge to an eligible subscriber 50% of the applicable filed tariff for:

paragraph.text: repairs to inside wiring; and
installation and connection of residential dial access service to one termination in the dwelling unit of the eligible subscriber.

subsection.text: The telephone company shall charge to the eligible subscriber all applicable federal, State, and local taxes and fees.

paragraph.text: A telephone company may not require payment of an order processing charge or line change charge to change an eligible subscriber to telephone lifeline service from any other class of residential telephone service.

A telephone lifeline service subscriber who no longer qualifies as an eligible subscriber may not be charged a fee to change from telephone lifeline service to any other class of residential telephone service.
A telephone company may not request a deposit to secure payment in connection with the initial installation or connection of telephone lifeline service.
An eligible subscriber applying for service may be denied service if the eligible subscriber:

subparagraph.text: has an outstanding unpaid net telephone debt of $100 or more for prior telephone service; and
has not established a reasonable payment plan to satisfy the debt.

paragraph.text: An eligible subscriber may not be denied service if the eligible subscriber has an outstanding unpaid net telephone debt of less than $100 for prior telephone service.

To the extent allowed by federal law, the Department of Human Resources shall provide to local telephone companies that offer telephone lifeline service monthly electronic access to a file containing a list of all individuals who receive assistance from any of the programs listed in subsection (a)(2) of this section.

To obtain access to the file, a local telephone company must enter into a memorandum of understanding with the Department of Human Resources that governs access to use, confidentiality, and retention of the file.
The grant of access to the file satisfies the certification requirement of subsection (a)(2) of this section.

The Commission may not authorize telephone company charges to be levied for directory assistance calls made by residential customers on the first two calls made to directory assistance from each residential service per monthly billing cycle.
The Commission may authorize charges on other directory assistance calls if the Commission finds, after notice and evidentiary hearing, that the charges:

subparagraph.text: protect consumers by providing affordable and reasonably priced directory assistance service;
encourage the development of competition; and
are in the public interest.

subsection.text: The Commission may not authorize telephone company charges to be levied for directory assistance on an individual who suffers from a physical or visual disability that precludes the use of a telephone directory.
The Commission may provide other exemptions from telephone company charges to be levied for directory assistance if the exemptions are just and reasonable.

paragraph.text: The Commission may not authorize mandatory telephone company charges based on a measured time period unit rate for local messages.
The Commission may study or evaluate mandatory telephone company charges.

subsection.text: If the Commission authorizes a telephone company to offer to residential customers the option of telephone charges based on a measured time period unit rate for local messages, the Commission also shall require the telephone company to offer to residential customers:

paragraph.text: the option of an unlimited number and duration of local calls; and
the option of a specific charge per local call, regardless of the duration of the local call.

subsection.text: A telephone company may not require the payment of an order processing charge or line change charge for a residential customer’s first change from local telephone service based on charges for measured time period unit rates, if the change occurs within 18 months after the date that the consumer elects this telephone service.
The Commission may not authorize a telephone company to charge for the distance of a call within a local calling area.
This section does not apply to:

paragraph.text: a unit of federal, State, or local government that uses an automated dialing prerecorded message machine for emergency purposes; or
a person who has a preexisting business relationship with, or the consent of, the person called.

subsection.text: A person may not use an automated dialing, push-button, or tone-activated address signaling system with a prerecorded message to:

paragraph.text: solicit persons to purchase, lease, or rent goods or services;
offer a gift or prize;
conduct a poll; or
request survey information if the results will be used directly to solicit persons to purchase, lease, or rent goods or services.

subsection.text: The sender of an automated dialing, push-button, or tone-activated address signaling call shall disconnect the prerecorded message machine from the recipient’s telephone line within 5 seconds after the termination of the call by either the person calling or the person called.
A person who violates a provision of subsection (b) or (c) of this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to a fine:

paragraph.text: not exceeding $1,000 for the first offense; and
not exceeding $5,000 for each subsequent offense.
In this section, “telephone solicitation” means an organized activity, program, or campaign to communicate by telephone with residents of Maryland in order to:

subparagraph.text: sell, lease, or rent goods or services;
attempt to sell, lease, or rent goods or services;
offer or attempt to offer a gift or prize;
conduct or attempt to conduct a poll; or
request or attempt to request survey information, if the results of the survey will be used directly to solicit persons to purchase, lease, or rent goods or services.

paragraph.text: “Telephone solicitation” includes the act of managing, directing, or supervising an individual engaged in telephone solicitation under paragraph (1) of this subsection.

subsection.text: This section does not apply to a unit of federal, State, or local government.

If the telephone service or equipment of a person engaged in telephone solicitation allows that person to choose to restrict or display the transmission of the person’s telephone number to the recipient of a telephone solicitation, the person may not:

paragraph.text: intentionally use any device or method to block the transmission of the person’s telephone number to a recipient; or
take any other action to prevent or control the transmission of the person’s telephone number to a recipient.

subsection.text: A person who violates this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to:

paragraph.text: for a first offense, a fine not exceeding $1,000; and
for each subsequent offense, a fine not exceeding $5,000.

subsection.text: This section applies to telephone directories distributed by, or on behalf of, a telephone company other than advertisement–based business directories.
A telephone company may not be required to distribute a telephone directory to an address in the State unless the property owner or an occupant requests the telephone directory.

paragraph.text: If a telephone company elects not to distribute a print telephone directory to a customer at an address in the State, the telephone company shall provide notice as to how the customer may request a print telephone directory.
The notice required under paragraph (1) of this subsection shall:

subparagraph.text: include a toll–free telephone number a customer may call to request a print telephone directory; and
be included:

sub-subparagraph.text: in each customer’s bill at least once each year;
on the telephone company’s Web site; and
in bold red print, on the front cover and the table of contents page of any print advertisement–based business directory distributed on behalf of the telephone company through September 30, 2016.

paragraph.text: If a customer requests a print telephone directory, the telephone company shall deliver the print telephone directory to the customer at no cost to the customer.

section.text: Except as otherwise provided by law, the provisions of this subtitle are not subject to the jurisdiction of the Commission.

subsection.text: A telephone company doing business in the State that has coin pay telephones located on outdoor sites shall provide a method to place calls to the operator without requiring the insertion of coins into the telephone.
The cost of providing the method of placing calls required in subsection (a) of this section is a reasonable and necessary cost of providing telephone service.
A telegraph company engaged in the business of transmitting communications by telegraph in the State and charging tolls for providing this service shall show conspicuously on each telegram delivered:

paragraph.text: under the caption “time filed”, the time the telegram was filed at the place of origin for transmission; and
under the caption “time received”, the time the telegram was received at the office from which it is to be delivered.

subsection.text: A telegraph company is liable for a fine of not less than $10 and not more than $200 for each telegram it delivers in violation of subsection (a) of this section.
In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Hold order” or “freeze” means a directive to retain:

paragraph.text: the telephone company or reseller selected by a customer until the customer provides express authorization for a change to another telephone company or reseller;

for telecommunications service options for which the telephone company or reseller imposes a charge, the telecommunications service options selected by a customer until the customer provides express authorization for a change of telecommunications service options; or

the person who bills the customer or the customer’s billing arrangement until the customer provides express authorization for a change of the person who bills the customer or the customer’s billing arrangement.

subsection.text: “Reseller” means a person who:

paragraph.text: provides telecommunications services to end-use customers by using the transmission facilities of another person, including wire, cable, optical fiber, or satellite or terrestrial radio signals, regardless of whether the reseller possesses its own switching facilities; or
bills an end-use customer or causes the customer to be billed for telecommunications service.

subsection.text: “Telecommunications service” means any service or product provided by a telephone company or reseller that is under the jurisdiction of the Commission.
This subtitle applies to a telephone company or reseller that provides intrastate interLATA, intraLATA, or local exchange carrier telecommunications service.
An act of a person or company that is acting as an agent or representative of a telephone company or reseller is deemed to be an act of the telephone company or reseller under this subtitle.

section.text: Each reseller that provides telecommunications service shall obtain authorization from the Commission in a manner determined by the Commission to provide those services in the State.

Unless the telephone company or reseller complies with authorization and confirmation procedures adopted by the Commission and by federal law and regulation, a telephone company or reseller may not, on behalf of a customer:

paragraph.text: change, or direct another telephone company or reseller to change, the customer’s telephone company or reseller;
select a telecommunications service option for which the telephone company or reseller imposes a charge; or
change the person who bills the customer or the customer’s billing arrangement.

subsection.text: This section applies to a telephone company or reseller that initiates an unauthorized change in violation of this subtitle in:

paragraph.text: a customer’s telephone company;
a customer’s reseller;
a customer’s telecommunications service options; or
the person who bills the customer or the customer’s billing arrangement.

subsection.text: A telephone company or reseller that is subject to this section is liable:

paragraph.text: to the customer, the customer’s previously selected telephone company or reseller, or both, as determined by the Commission, for all intrastate long distance charges, interstate long distance charges, local exchange service charges, provider switching fees, the value of any premiums to which the customer would have been entitled, and other relevant charges incurred by the customer in the first 30 days of the unauthorized change; and
to the customer’s local exchange provider for the change fees for the unauthorized change and reinstating the customer to the original telephone company or reseller.

subsection.text: When a customer, or a telephone company or reseller providing a new telecommunications service on behalf of the customer, makes a change in the customer’s telephone company or reseller, the telephone company or reseller providing the new telecommunications service shall provide a conspicuous notice to the customer, informing the customer that the change was made.

When a customer, or a telephone company or reseller on behalf of the customer, makes a change in the customer’s selection of a telecommunications service option for which the telephone company or reseller imposes a charge, the telephone company or reseller providing the new telecommunications service option shall provide a conspicuous notice to the customer, informing the customer that the change was made.

When a customer, or a telephone company or reseller on behalf of a customer, makes a change in the person who bills the customer or the customer’s billing arrangement, the telephone company or reseller providing the new billing service or arrangement shall provide a conspicuous notice to the customer, informing the customer that the change was made.
A telephone company or reseller that is required to provide notice under this section shall provide the notice by:

paragraph.text: inserting the notice on or with the customer’s first bill for which the change is effective; or
sending a separate notice to the customer within 30 days after the change takes effect.

subsection.text: A telephone company or reseller may not, on behalf of a customer, fail to make any change in a customer’s telephone company, reseller, or telecommunications service options, or in the person who bills the customer or the customer’s billing arrangement when the change order has been received in a manner that complies with federal and State rules and regulations. All such change orders shall be properly processed to assure that the order is completed and service will be provided by the new telephone company or reseller of choice within 15 business days of receipt of the compliant change order or as otherwise negotiated with the customer.

If the Commission determines that a hold order or freeze is necessary, the Commission may require a telephone company or reseller that operates the network facilities that control routing, selection, or billing functions necessary to implement the hold order or freeze to offer the hold order or freeze to the telephone company’s end-use customers or to the reseller’s end-use customers as a method of reducing incidents of unauthorized changes in a customer’s telephone company, reseller, or telecommunications service options, or in the person who bills the customer or the customer’s billing arrangement.

A telephone company or reseller that is required to offer a hold order or freeze shall implement the hold order or freeze in a nondiscriminatory and competitively neutral manner that does not give the telephone company or reseller an advantage over its competitors in the telecommunications market.
All regulations regarding the implementation of a hold order or freeze shall be consistent with the rules and regulations of the Federal Communications Commission.
To implement this subtitle the Commission may adopt regulations necessary to carry out the provisions of this subtitle that are consistent with federal law.
The regulations may include:

paragraph.text: procedures for a customer to confirm a change in the customer’s telephone company or reseller made by another telephone company or reseller on behalf of the customer;
procedures for a customer to confirm a change in telecommunications service options;
procedures for a customer to confirm a change in the person who bills the customer or the customer’s billing arrangement;
provisions for the disclosure to the customer of the terms of the services offered by a telephone company or reseller;
methods of enforcement; and
other provisions, not inconsistent with federal law, that the Commission considers necessary to implement this subtitle.

subsection.text: A telephone company or reseller may not fail or neglect to comply with this subtitle or with a regulation adopted under this subtitle.
For the purpose of enforcing the provisions of this subtitle, the Commission may:

paragraph.text: exercise any of the powers conferred under this division against a telephone company or reseller; and

in the case of a complaint filed against a telephone company or reseller, order the telephone company or reseller to make reparations to the complaining party in accordance with § 8–405 of this subtitle.

subsection.text: In addition to any other available penalty, the Commission may assess directly, after an opportunity for hearing, an administrative penalty on a telephone company or reseller that violates the provisions of this subtitle, or a regulation adopted under this subtitle, or federal law or regulation on unauthorized changes to a customer’s telephone company, reseller, or telecommunications service options, or to the person who bills the customer or the customer’s billing arrangement.
The administrative penalty assessed under this section may not exceed $1,000 for each violation associated with a specific access line in the State.
In assessing an administrative penalty under this section, the Commission shall consider:

paragraph.text: the nature, circumstances, extent, gravity, and number of violations;
the degree of culpability of the violator;
prior offenses and repeated violations of the violator; and
any other matter that the Commission considers appropriate and relevant.

subsection.text: An administrative penalty collected under this section shall be paid into the General Fund of the State.
The Commission may, after notice and public hearing, adopt policies and regulations governing the development of competition in the telecommunications services market.

Policies and regulations adopted by the Commission under this section shall be consistent with federal law, policies and regulations of the Federal Communications Commission, Title 4 of this article, and any other applicable provisions of Maryland law.

section.text: In this subtitle:

paragraph.text: “voice over Internet protocol service” or “VoIP service” means any service that:

subparagraph.text: enables real–time two–way voice communications that originate from or terminate to the subscriber end user’s location requiring Internet protocol or any successor protocol to Internet protocol; and
requires a broadband connection from the user’s location; and

paragraph.text: “voice over Internet protocol service” or “VoIP service” includes any such service that permits users generally to receive calls that originate on the public switched telephone network and to terminate calls to the public switched telephone network.

subsection.text: The Commission does not have jurisdiction over the regulation of VoIP service, including the imposition of regulatory fees, certification requirements, and the filing or approval of tariffs.
Nothing in this subtitle may be construed to:

paragraph.text: require or prohibit the assessment of 9–1–1 fees in accordance with § 1–310 of the Public Safety Article on VoIP;
require or prohibit the assessment of fees for telecommunications relay service under Title 3, Subtitle 8 of the State Finance and Procurement Article;
require or prohibit the payment of any switched network access rates or other intercarrier compensation rates that may be determined to apply;

relieve a company that is otherwise subject to § 8–201 of this title of its obligation to provide telephone lifeline service over local exchange access lines that are subject to the Commission’s jurisdiction;

exempt VoIP service from generally applicable State and federal laws relating to public safety, consumer protection, and unfair and deceptive trade practices, or to exempt VoIP service from the authority of the Division of Consumer Protection in the Office of the Attorney General; or
remove the Commission’s jurisdiction over circuit switched local exchange access service.

subsection.text: A company that moves a customer from a Commission–approved tariff service to VoIP service shall notify the customer that the Commission does not have jurisdiction over the regulation of VoIP service and that complaints about VoIP service may be filed with the Division of Consumer Protection in the Office of the Attorney General.
Each common carrier shall provide reasonable, proper, and equal facilities for the prompt interchange and transfer of passengers between its lines and the lines of every other common carrier.
A common carrier may not discriminate against other common carriers in transferring, receiving, or forwarding passengers to or from other common carriers.
A common carrier is not required to allow any other common carrier to use its tracks or terminal facilities.

section.text: Unless the Commission orders otherwise, a common carrier may not charge or receive an equal or greater compensation in the aggregate to transport passengers under substantially similar circumstances for a shorter distance than for a longer distance over the same line and in the same direction.

subsection.text: The Commission shall prescribe a form of tariff schedules for common carriers that is as nearly as practicable the same as that required by the Surface Transportation Board for the particular kind of carrier.
In addition to other information that the Commission requires, the tariff schedules of each common carrier shall show:

paragraph.text: all of the current rates, fares, and charges, including those specified in § 4-503 of this article, for the transportation of passengers within the State between:

subparagraph.text: each point on the common carrier’s route and all other points on the other routes it owns; and

each point on the common carrier’s route and all points on the route of each other common carrier that is shown in the schedule whenever a through route or joint rate is established between those points;

paragraph.text: the points between which passengers will be carried;
the classification of passengers;
the privileges or facilities granted; and
all rules and regulations that may change, affect, or determine any part of the aggregate of the rates, fares, or charges or the value of the service rendered.

subsection.text: Each common carrier that is a party to a joint rate shown in the tariff schedule of another common carrier shall file with the Commission evidence of acceptance of the joint rate, as required by the Commission.
Except as provided in subsection (b) of this section, a motor carrier permit is required for a passenger motor vehicle used in the transportation of persons for hire.
A motor carrier permit is not required for:

paragraph.text: a motor vehicle used exclusively for the transportation of pupils to and from public or private schools;
a motor vehicle operated for a period of not more than 3 months in any registration year in the transportation of persons employed at a cannery located in a county;
taxicabs;
public transportation for hire authorized to operate on the boardwalk in Ocean City;
a vanpool operation as defined in § 11–175.1 of the Transportation Article;
a local public transportation system established under a law enacted by the local governing body of a county or municipal corporation;

subject to subsection (c) of this section, a motor vehicle used by a privately owned transportation company exclusively to provide transportation system services under a contract with the governing body of a county or municipal corporation or with a unit of State government; or

shuttle bus service operated by the University of Maryland, College Park for students enrolled at the University of Maryland, College Park and, in exchange for payment by a municipal corporation in which the University of Maryland, College Park operates shuttle bus service, transportation service on the shuttle bus to residents of the municipal corporation.

subsection.text: A privately owned transportation company that provides transportation system services under a contract with the governing body of a county or municipal corporation or with a unit of State government shall obtain a motor carrier permit for motor vehicles that the company does not use exclusively to provide transportation system services under a contract with the governing body of a county or municipal corporation or with a unit of State government.

The public duties of a common carrier may not be imposed on a person with respect to a vehicle for which a motor carrier permit is required under this section, if the vehicle is not actually engaged in public transportation.
Except as provided in subsection (b) of this section, a motor carrier permit is required for a passenger motor vehicle used in the transportation of persons for hire.
A motor carrier permit is not required for:

paragraph.text: a motor vehicle used exclusively for the transportation of pupils to and from public or private schools;
a motor vehicle operated for a period of not more than 3 months in any registration year in the transportation of persons employed at a cannery located in a county;
taxicabs;
public transportation for hire authorized to operate on the boardwalk in Ocean City;
a vanpool operation as defined in § 11–175.1 of the Transportation Article;
a local public transportation system established under a law enacted by the local governing body of a county or municipal corporation; or

subject to subsection (c) of this section, a motor vehicle used by a privately owned transportation company exclusively to provide transportation system services under a contract with the governing body of a county or municipal corporation or with a unit of State government.

subsection.text: A privately owned transportation company that provides transportation system services under a contract with the governing body of a county or municipal corporation or with a unit of State government shall obtain a motor carrier permit for motor vehicles that the company does not use exclusively to provide transportation system services under a contract with the governing body of a county or municipal corporation or with a unit of State government.

The public duties of a common carrier may not be imposed on a person with respect to a vehicle for which a motor carrier permit is required under this section, if the vehicle is not actually engaged in public transportation.

section.text: A motor carrier permit may not be issued unless the Commission, after considering the number of vehicles the applicant will use, the rate the applicant will charge, the potential demand, the qualifications of the applicant, and any other factors that the Commission considers relevant, determines that the issuance of a motor carrier permit will be best for the public welfare and convenience.

subsection.text: Subject to subsections (b) and (c) of this section, the Commission may subject a motor carrier permit to terms and conditions that the Commission considers appropriate.
The duration of a motor carrier permit may not exceed 20 years.
The Commission may authorize seasonal motor carrier permits for a part of the year.

section.text: The Commission may suspend, revoke, or subsequently deny a motor carrier permit if the holder violates a provision of this division.

paragraph.text: A route or schedule of a motor vehicle for which a motor carrier permit is granted may not be changed or abandoned without written permission from the Commission.
The Commission may only grant permission under paragraph (1) of this subsection if the Commission finds that the public welfare and convenience are not prejudiced by the change.

Notwithstanding paragraph (1) of this subsection, the holder of a motor carrier permit may temporarily operate substitute or reserve vehicles, when necessary in an emergency, to maintain the required schedules over the holder’s route.

subsection.text: This subtitle does not limit the power of a municipal corporation to adopt reasonable traffic regulations, including the power to:

paragraph.text: designate streets; and
prohibit the use of certain streets or the parking of vehicles on those streets if the use or parking may threaten public safety or unduly congest traffic.

subsection.text: The owner and operator of an intrastate motor bus carrier shall prohibit the smoking of tobacco products while the bus is in public service.
A person may not smoke tobacco products on a bus of an intrastate motor bus carrier.
The Commission may adopt regulations to carry out the provisions of this section.
A person who violates a provision of this section is subject to a civil penalty not exceeding $25.
This section applies to a motor carrier providing transportation for hire by or through contract with a public authority, or a federal, State, district, or municipal transportation agency.
A motor carrier subject to this section:

paragraph.text: is also subject to §§ 5–101 and 5–304 of this article; and
except as provided in § 9–201(b)(7) of this subtitle, shall obtain a motor carrier permit under § 9–201 of this subtitle.

subsection.text: A motor carrier permit issued to a motor carrier subject to this section may be:

paragraph.text: subject to conditions under § 9–203 of this subtitle; and
suspended, revoked, or subsequently denied under § 9–204 of this subtitle.

subsection.text: Except as provided in this section, the provisions of this division do not apply to a motor carrier subject to this section.
This section does not apply to a motor coach that is licensed by the Commission to provide transportation of persons for hire.

A not-for-profit entity that owns and operates a motor coach with a capacity of at least 30 passengers and gross vehicle weight rating of at least 32,000 pounds shall obtain a license for the motor coach from the Commission.
The not-for-profit entity shall have the motor coach inspected for safety every 12 months by an authorized Maryland inspection station.
A motor coach that is licensed under this section and only provides service for or on behalf of a not–for–profit entity is not subject to tariffs or rate making under this division.

section.text: In this subtitle, “Maryland railroad company” means a railroad company organized under the laws of this State.
Except as otherwise provided by law, the provisions of this subtitle are not subject to the jurisdiction of the Commission.

paragraph.text: Except as provided in paragraph (2) of this subsection, a Maryland railroad company may locate, construct, maintain, and operate a railroad in the State if the railroad is not more than 100 feet wide at the graded surface.
A railroad may be wider than 100 feet if the Maryland railroad company determines that it is necessary for:

subparagraph.text: cuts and fills for a slope or embankment;
multiple sets of tracks; or
sidetracks, turnouts, depots, buildings, and other works connected with the operation of the railroad.

paragraph.text: A Maryland railroad company may acquire land and other property that it determines is convenient or necessary for the site of the railroad or for additions to the railroad by:

subparagraph.text: purchase, either in fee simple or any lesser estate, in accordance with law; or
condemnation under Title 5, Subtitle 4 of this article and Title 12 of the Real Property Article.

paragraph.text: A Maryland railroad company may acquire by purchase or gift lands near the railroad that it determines are necessary to secure the right-of-way or aid in the construction of the railroad.
Land that a Maryland railroad company acquires may be held or conveyed as determined by the board of directors of the Maryland railroad company.
Deeds and conveyances made by a Maryland railroad company shall be signed by the president of the company under its corporate seal.

subsection.text: This section does not authorize a Maryland railroad company to condemn, use, or occupy any part of a highway, including the space under or over a highway, without the consent of the proper authorities of the municipal corporation or county where the highway is located.

paragraph.text: A Maryland railroad company may cross or divert an unnavigable stream whenever it is necessary to construct a railroad.
A Maryland railroad company that diverts a stream is liable for damage caused by the diversion.

subsection.text: A Maryland railroad company may cross a canal or a navigable stream if the company:

paragraph.text: submits to the Board of Public Works a plan for the canal or stream crossing that includes the location and building plans of the bridge and other necessary fixtures; and
receives written approval from the Board of Public Works.

If the Board of Public Works disapproves a plan submitted by a Maryland railroad company or fails to approve the plan within 20 days after filing, the Maryland railroad company may apply to the circuit court of the county where the canal or stream crossing is planned or to another court of competent jurisdiction.
The court shall:

subparagraph.text: provide reasonable notice to the Board of Public Works;

for good cause shown, appoint a disinterested and competent engineer, who does not reside in a county through which the Maryland railroad company’s railroad passes and who, within 20 days of being appointed:

sub-subparagraph.text: shall examine the canal or stream crossing; and
shall establish a plan and any conditions necessary to cross the canal or stream in a way that will not impede navigation; and

subparagraph.text: examine the engineer’s plan and conditions for the canal or stream crossing, and unless good cause is shown, approve the plan and conditions.

paragraph.text: An order by the court approving the plan and conditions for the canal or stream crossing shall be sufficient authority for the Maryland railroad company to elect, use, and occupy the bridge.
Whenever necessary in the construction of a railroad, a Maryland railroad company may cross the tracks of another railroad company.
Crossings may be made at, over, or under grade.

subsection.text: If a Maryland railroad company is unable to agree on the terms for a crossing with the railroad company whose track is to be crossed, then the Maryland railroad company may condemn the easement of the crossing under § 5-405 of this article.

paragraph.text: A Maryland railroad company that constructs a crossing at grade shall:

subparagraph.text: at its own expense, erect a proper signal station at the crossing and keep a watchman there; and
give precedence to the trains of the railroad company whose tracks are crossed.

paragraph.text: A Maryland railroad company that constructs an undergrade or overgrade crossing shall construct the crossing so as not to interfere with the passage of the trains of the railroad company whose tracks are being crossed.
A Maryland railroad company may:

subparagraph.text: cross or divert a highway whenever necessary for the construction of a railroad;

at its own cost and expense, carry a highway over its track by an overgrade crossing, or under its track by an undergrade crossing if the Maryland railroad company considers that the highway crossing is dangerous; and

exercise the powers of condemnation, under Title 5, Subtitle 4 of this article and Title 12 of the Real Property Article, to acquire additional property and rights necessary to construct an overgrade or undergrade crossing.

paragraph.text: Whenever a Maryland railroad company crosses or diverts a highway, it shall, without necessary delay, return the highway to its former usefulness.
Overgrade and undergrade crossings shall be at least 20 feet wide, and the grades approaching the crossings may not be greater than a rise of 6 feet in one hundred.
The height of an undergrade crossing from the surface of the roadway shall be at least 14 feet.
When constructing the approaches to an overgrade or undergrade crossing, the Maryland railroad company may change the grade of the road or highway to be carried on the new crossing.
If the grade is changed under paragraph (3) of this subsection:

subparagraph.text: the grade change of the road shall be at the expense of the Maryland railroad company; and
the Maryland railroad company has the same rights and liabilities that county officials have in changing the grades of public highways.

paragraph.text: Except as provided in paragraph (2) of this subsection, whenever a Maryland railroad company constructs an overgrade or undergrade crossing, all grade crossings within 600 yards of the new crossing may be closed by the Maryland railroad company and another crossing may not be opened within 600 yards of the new crossing.
The prohibition against the maintenance and opening of a grade crossing within 600 yards of a newly constructed overgrade or undergrade crossing does not apply:

subparagraph.text: in a municipal corporation, without the consent of the mayor and council; and
in an unincorporated area of a county with a population of 2,000 or more people, without the consent of the local governing body.

section.text: If the right-of-way or location of any part of an unfinished railroad remains unused for railroad purposes for 10 years or longer, the right-of-way or location is deemed abandoned and may be purchased or condemned by a railroad company under Title 5, Subtitle 4 of this article and Title 12 of the Real Property Article.

subsection.text: Subject to § 6-101(c) of this article, a Maryland railroad company may acquire, own, hold, pledge, sell, dispose of, endorse, guarantee, or assume the stocks, bonds, and other securities of:

paragraph.text: a Maryland railroad company;
a railroad company of any other state; and
an inland, coast, or ocean transportation company.

subsection.text: A Maryland railroad company may own and operate a line of steamships or steamboats if they can be used wholly or partly, in connection with the business of the Maryland railroad company.
The presumption of negligence established in this section does not apply if:

paragraph.text: the damages or injuries were caused by a fire that occurred in or about a railroad terminal that receives, delivers, or tranships freight; and
the fire may have resulted from the negligence of an individual who works in or about the terminal but is not employed by or under the control of the railroad company.

subsection.text: Unless a railroad company proves that damages or injuries were not the result of any negligence on the part of the company, a railroad company is liable in a civil action for:

paragraph.text: injuries to livestock that occur on the company’s tracks; and
damages that result from a fire that originated from the company’s engines or cars.

subsection.text: A railroad that crosses or connects with another railroad may use the track or roadway of the other railroad, for up to 5 miles, to move locomotives, cars, and tonnage.

The rate of tolls that a railroad charges under this section for locomotives, cars, and tonnage may not exceed the rate per ton per mile, or proportionate part of a mile used, that the railroad charges for through freight per ton per mile.
A railroad company that violates this section is liable to an aggrieved party in a civil action for an amount not less than $500 and not exceeding $1,000 for each day of noncompliance.

paragraph.text: At least 30 days before making a determination, the local governing body of a county shall notify a railroad company that the county will consider the need to protect a railroad crossing over a public highway if:

subparagraph.text: the crossing is in the county but outside of a municipal corporation;
the crossing is at grade; and
the highway is believed to be of a character as to render dangerous the passage of locomotives and trains on it.

paragraph.text: A county shall give the notice by serving written notice on the superintendent or other agent of the railroad company in the county.
After the 30-day period, the local governing body of a county may determine that protection is necessary at the crossing.
The county shall notify the railroad company through its superintendent or ticket agent in the county that, within 60 days, the railroad company shall:

subparagraph.text: place a flagman or a system of electric alarm bells at the crossing to give timely notice to all persons using the crossing of the approach of trains;
erect safety gates at the crossing that shall be closed not less than one-half minute before the passage and during the passage of a train; or
change the crossing at grade to an undergrade or overgrade crossing.

subsection.text: If a railroad company does not comply with the requirements of a county under subsection (a)(4) of this section, the railroad company is subject to a fine of $25 per day for each day that the company is not in compliance.

paragraph.text: As other fines are collected, the local governing body of a county shall enforce the payment of fines imposed by subsection (b) of this section in the circuit court for the county.
The State’s Attorney of the county shall prosecute under this subsection when the local governing body of the county so directs.

subsection.text: Each safety gate at a grade crossing in the State shall have reflectors of sufficient size to ensure visibility at night.
The Secretary of Transportation shall adopt regulations to carry out this section.

A railroad company that does not comply with an order of the Secretary of Transportation to provide or maintain reflectors under this section is subject to a fine of $100 per day for each day that the company is not in compliance.

At each place where its tracks cross a public highway, a Maryland railroad company shall erect signs high enough to allow all vehicles to pass and with large and distinct letters that warn of the proximity of the railroad crossing and of the necessity to look for trains.
A Maryland railroad company that neglects or refuses to comply with the requirements of this section is liable for any resulting injuries to individuals or damages to property.

Unless the Commission orders otherwise, a railroad company shall have sufficient cars and motive power to meet all requirements that reasonably may be anticipated to transport passengers, property, and freight.

paragraph.text: If a railroad company does not have sufficient cars to meet the demand to transport freight in carload lots, the railroad company shall distribute available cars to shippers that apply.

Except for giving priority to transporting livestock or perishable property, a railroad company may not discriminate in any way, including preferences as to shippers, localities, or competitive or noncompetitive points, when supplying cars under this section.

subsection.text: This section does not affect the duties of a railroad company or the powers of the Commission regarding joint rates.
A railroad company shall receive freight cars of proper standard from other railroad companies at connecting points and haul the cars:

paragraph.text: to their destination; or
by the route billed, to the connecting point with the next connecting carrier.

subsection.text: Except on terms and conditions that the Commission establishes, railroad companies may not be required to interchange cars.
If safe to install, reasonably practicable, and justified by the volume of business, a railroad company, on the application of a shipper, shall construct, maintain, and operate on reasonable terms:

paragraph.text: a switch connection or a connection with a lateral line of railroad or private sidetrack owned by the shipper; or
a sidetrack and switch connection for the shipper on property owned by the railroad company.

subsection.text: The Commission shall regulate installation, maintenance, and compensation under this section.
A railroad company may terminate connections that it provides under this section if the Commission determines that the required conditions are no longer satisfied.
In this title the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Central Repository” has the meaning stated in § 10-201 of the Criminal Procedure Article.
“Criminal Justice Information System” has the meaning stated in § 10-201 of the Criminal Procedure Article.
“For-hire driver’s license” includes:

paragraph.text: a passenger-for-hire license; and
a taxicab driver’s license.
“Limousine service” means operating a motor vehicle for hire using a motor vehicle classified as a Class Q (limousine) vehicle under § 13-939 of the Transportation Article.
“Limousine service” does not include providing taxicab services or sedan services.
“Operate a motor vehicle for hire” means to transport or offer to transport a person in a motor vehicle in exchange for remuneration.
“Operate a motor vehicle for hire” includes:

subparagraph.text: providing passenger-for-hire services; and
providing taxicab services.

subsection.text: “Provide passenger-for-hire services” includes:

paragraph.text: providing limousine services; and
providing sedan services.

subsection.text: “Provide taxicab services” means to operate a motor vehicle for hire that, in addition to other services:

paragraph.text: is advertised or held out to the public as a taxicab or as providing taxicab services;
regardless of how or when engaged, provides for-hire service between points chosen by the passenger and for a fare that is based on the distance traveled, the time elapsed, or both; or
is engaged by the passenger for service between points chosen by the passenger that is provided through:

subparagraph.text: hail from the street or other location; or
request made at a taxi stand or other location where the motor vehicle is standing and waiting for a request for service.

subsection.text: “Remuneration” includes:

paragraph.text: a fare;
a fee;
a toll;
a gratuity; and
personal services.
“Sedan service” means operating a motor vehicle for hire using a motor vehicle designed to carry 15 or fewer individuals, including the driver.
“Sedan service” does not include providing taxicab services or limousine services.

subsection.text: “Taxicab driver’s license” means a license issued by the Commission to an individual that provides taxicab services.
This subtitle supplements other law relating to the operation and licensing of motor vehicles.
This title applies to any motor vehicle used in the transportation of persons in exchange for remuneration except:

paragraph.text: motor vehicles designed to transport more than 15 persons; and

transportation solely provided by or on behalf of a unit of federal, State, or local government, or a not-for-profit organization as identified in § 501(c)(3) and (4) of the Internal Revenue Code, that requires a criminal history records check and driving record check for its drivers, for clients of services including:

subparagraph.text: aging support;
developmental and other disabilities;
kidney dialysis;
Medical Assistance Program;
Head Start;
Welfare-to-Work;
mental health; and
job training.

subsection.text: Subsection (b)(2) of this section may not be construed to limit the application of this title or Title 9 of this article to a for-hire driver or other person who operates a motor vehicle for hire or provides transportation of persons for hire in addition to providing transportation services to clients of services listed in subsection (b)(2) of this section.
Notwithstanding subsection (b)(2) of this section:

paragraph.text: a not-for-profit organization that provides transportation for remuneration to clients of services listed in subsection (b)(2) of this section may be required to obtain a motor carrier permit under Title 9 of this article; but

a driver employed by the not-for-profit organization may not be required to obtain a for-hire driver’s license or other authorization from the Commission to perform transportation services solely under subsection (b)(2) of this section.

A driver employed or offered employment by a governmental unit or not-for-profit organization under subsection (b)(2) of this section shall apply to the Criminal Justice Information System Central Repository of the Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services for a State criminal history records check on or before the first day of the driver’s actual employment.

As part of the application for a State criminal history records check, the driver employed or offered employment by the governmental unit or not-for-profit organization shall submit to the Central Repository:

subparagraph.text: one complete set of the driver’s legible fingerprints taken on a form approved by the Secretary of Public Safety and Correctional Services; and
the fee authorized under § 10-221(b)(7) of the Criminal Procedure Article for access to State criminal history records.
In accordance with Title 10, Subtitle 2 of the Criminal Procedure Article, the Central Repository shall provide a printed statement listing the driver’s criminal convictions to:

sub-subparagraph.text: the governmental unit or not-for-profit organization; and
the driver.

subparagraph.text: If criminal history record information is reported to the Central Repository after the date of the initial criminal history records check, the Central Repository shall provide a revised printed statement listing the driver’s criminal convictions to:

sub-subparagraph.text: the governmental unit or not-for-profit organization; and
the driver.

paragraph.text: In accordance with regulations adopted by the Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services, the governmental unit or not-for-profit organization shall verify periodically a list of its drivers.
Information the governmental unit or not-for-profit organization obtains from the Central Repository under this subsection shall be:

subparagraph.text: confidential and may not be redisseminated; and
used only for the employment purpose authorized by this section.

paragraph.text: In accordance with § 10-223 of the Criminal Procedure Article, a driver employed by a governmental unit or not-for-profit organization may challenge the contents of a printed statement or revised printed statement issued by the Central Repository.

subsection.text: This subtitle does not limit the power of a political subdivision of the State to adopt reasonable traffic regulations such as:

paragraph.text: the designation of taxicab stands; and
the restriction or prohibition of cruising along a public street when the cruising would menace the public safety or unduly congest traffic.

subsection.text: Except as provided in subsection (b) of this section, a person may not operate a motor vehicle for hire in the State under a permit or authorization to transport passengers issued by the Commission or the appropriate local authority unless the person holds a for-hire driver’s license issued by the Commission.

paragraph.text: A county or municipal corporation may license taxicab drivers who drive taxicabs that are based in that county or municipal corporation if, at a minimum, the county or municipal corporation conducts a criminal record check and driving record check of each applicant for a license.
A taxicab driver licensed by a county or municipal corporation is not required to be licensed by the Commission.
An applicant for a for-hire driver’s license shall:

subparagraph.text: submit to the Commission a completed application on the form that the Commission provides;
state on the form that the applicant is applying for a passenger-for-hire driver’s license or a taxicab driver’s license;
pay to the Commission an application fee set by the Commission;
file with the application two recent photographs, of a size that may be easily attached to the license; and

apply to the Criminal Justice Information System Central Repository of the Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services for a State criminal history records check as provided in subsection (b) of this section.

paragraph.text: The Commission shall:

subparagraph.text: require a driving record check of the applicant;
attach one of the photographs to the for-hire driver’s license when issued; and
file the other photograph with the for-hire driver’s license application in the Commission’s office.

paragraph.text: As part of the application for a criminal history records check, the applicant shall submit to the Central Repository:

subparagraph.text: one complete set of the applicant’s legible fingerprints taken on forms approved by the Director of the Central Repository; and
the fee authorized under § 10-221(b)(7) of the Criminal Procedure Article for access to Maryland criminal history records.

In response to an application for an initial criminal history records check, the Central Repository shall provide to the Commission and the applicant a printed statement of the applicant’s State criminal record.

If criminal history record information is reported to the Central Repository after the date of the initial criminal history records check, the Central Repository shall provide to the Commission and the applicant or licensee a revised printed statement of the applicant’s or licensee’s State criminal record.

paragraph.text: In accordance with regulations adopted by the Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services, the Commission shall verify periodically a list of licensed for-hire drivers.
Information the Commission obtains from the Central Repository under this subsection shall be:

subparagraph.text: confidential and may not be redisseminated; and
used only for the licensing purposes described in this title.

As provided by this paragraph, an applicant for a for-hire driver’s license or a licensee may contest the contents of a printed statement or a revised printed statement issued by the Central Repository.

To contest the contents of a printed statement or a revised printed statement, an applicant or a licensee shall contact the office of the Secretary of Public Safety and Correctional Services, or the Secretary’s designee.
The Secretary of Public Safety and Correctional Services, or the Secretary’s designee, shall:

sub-subparagraph.text: convene a hearing within 20 workdays, unless subsequently waived by the applicant or the licensee; and
render a decision within 5 workdays after the hearing.

subparagraph.text: For the purposes of this paragraph, the record of a court disposition or a copy of the record certified by the clerk of the court or by a judge of the court in which the disposition occurred shall be conclusive evidence of the disposition.

In a case where a pending charge is recorded, documentation provided by a court to the Secretary of Public Safety and Correctional Services, or the Secretary’s designee, that a pending charge for a crime which has not been finally adjudicated shall be conclusive evidence of the pending charge.
Failure of the applicant or a licensee to appear at the scheduled hearing shall be considered grounds for dismissal of the contest.

In addition to a State criminal history records check under this subsection, and subject to Title 10, Subtitle 2 of the Criminal Procedure Article, the Commission may require an applicant to obtain a criminal history records check from the Federal Bureau of Investigation, through the Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services.
An applicant who is required by the Commission to obtain a criminal history records check from the Federal Bureau of Investigation under subparagraph (i) of this paragraph shall:

sub-subparagraph.text: apply to the Central Repository of the Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services for a national criminal history records check;
submit to the Central Repository one complete set of the applicant’s legible fingerprints taken on forms approved by the Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation; and
submit to the Central Repository the mandatory processing fee required by the Federal Bureau of Investigation for a national criminal history records check.

paragraph.text: The Commission may use a private agency to provide a background check on an applicant or licensee under this section, as determined by the Commission.

After the initial printed statement has been received from the Central Repository, the Commission shall issue a passenger-for-hire driver’s license or a taxicab driver’s license, as appropriate, to each applicant that meets the requirements of this title.
The passenger-for-hire driver’s license and the taxicab driver’s license shall be in the form that the Commission provides.
This subsection applies only in Baltimore City.

On or after July 1, 2002, an individual applying for a taxicab license or renewal of a taxicab license, shall submit proof of having successfully completed a course approved by the Commission that includes in the curriculum:

subparagraph.text: courteous treatment of passengers;
geography and map reading for the jurisdiction in which the taxicab services will be provided; and
tourist information for the jurisdiction in which taxicab services will be provided.

subsection.text: The Commission may deny an applicant a license or suspend or revoke the license of a licensee if the applicant or licensee has been convicted of a crime that bears a direct relationship to the applicant’s or licensee’s fitness to serve the public as a for-hire driver.
After an administrative review, the Commission shall deny an application for a license if the public convenience and necessity requires the denial because of:

paragraph.text: the physical or mental condition of the applicant; or
the criminal record of the applicant.
If an applicant’s application for a license is denied under subsection (a) of this section, the applicant may request a hearing by the Commission.
The Commission may have the license hearing officer conduct the hearing in accordance with § 10-110 of this subtitle.

subsection.text: If the Commission refuses to issue a license, the applicant may seek judicial review of the refusal under Title 3, Subtitle 2 of this article.
The term of a for-hire driver’s license is not less than 1 year and not more than 3 years, as the Commission sets.

paragraph.text: An applicant for a renewal of a for-hire driver’s license shall submit to the Commission an application on the form that the Commission provides.
The Commission may renew the for-hire driver’s license by appropriate endorsement on the license.

subsection.text: The Commission shall keep on file with the original application of a driver a complete record of:

paragraph.text: each for-hire driver’s license issued to the driver; and
any renewal, suspension, and revocation of a for-hire driver’s license issued to the driver.

section.text: The Commission may issue a temporary license and, if applicable, a badge to an applicant for a period not exceeding 30 days.

subsection.text: A for-hire driver shall have the for-hire driver’s license in the driver’s possession whenever operating a motor vehicle for hire.

paragraph.text: A for-hire driver may not deface, remove, or obliterate an official entry made on the for-hire driver’s license.
A violation of this subsection shall be punished by suspension or revocation of the for-hire driver’s license as provided under § 10-110 of this subtitle.

section.text: If a passenger elects to use a route where a highway or bridge toll charge occurs, the for-hire driver shall assess the passenger the cost of the highway or bridge toll charge.

paragraph.text: There is a position of license hearing officer.
The license hearing officer shall be appointed by the Commission.
The license hearing officer serves at the pleasure of the Commission.
The license hearing officer is entitled to compensation in accordance with the State budget.

subsection.text: The license hearing officer may hold a hearing involving a violation of this division or the Commission’s regulations:

paragraph.text: by a for–hire driver licensed by the Commission; and
except for a violation relating to rates, by a holder of a taxicab permit issued by the Commission.

subsection.text: The license hearing officer shall file with the Commission, and simultaneously serve on all parties, a proposed order and findings of fact.
The proposed order shall become final unless appealed as provided in § 3-113(d) of this article.

Whenever a for-hire driver’s license or taxicab permit is suspended or revoked, or a civil penalty is imposed on the for-hire driver or taxicab permit holder, the for-hire driver or taxicab permit holder:

paragraph.text: may request a rehearing in accordance with § 3-114 of this article; and
may seek judicial review under Title 3, Subtitle 2 of this article.

subsection.text: The Commission shall furnish to the permit holder a copy of the charges against a for-hire driver and the related decision of the license hearing officer and the Commission.

section.text: Notwithstanding § 2-110 of this article, the Commission may seek adequate funding in the State budget and employ adequate staffing in order to implement the responsibilities set forth in this title and Title 9, Subtitle 2 of this article.

subsection.text: There is a For–Hire Driving Services Enforcement Fund.
The Fund is a special, nonlapsing fund that is not subject to § 7–302 of the State Finance and Procurement Article.
The purpose of the Fund is to provide adequate resources for the Commission to enforce the requirements of this title concerning for–hire driving services.

paragraph.text: The Fund consists of assessments made on permits for vehicles regulated by the Commission to provide for–hire driving services in the State.

The Commission shall establish an assessment not exceeding $40 to be paid annually with respect to each vehicle permit to provide for–hire driving services, except for a vehicle permit to be used exclusively for employee van transportation to or from a designated work site.

subsection.text: The Fund is to be used solely for statewide enforcement activities of the Commission relating to taxicab services, limousine services, and sedan services.

section.text: This subtitle applies to a person providing taxicab services under a taxicab permit or taxicab driver’s license issued by the Commission.

subsection.text: A person must have a permit issued by the Commission whenever the person operates as a taxicab business in or from a point in Baltimore City, Baltimore County, the City of Cumberland, or the City of Hagerstown.

The provisions of this division relating to taxicabs or of any public local law relating to taxicabs do not limit the jurisdiction of the Commission over a taxicab business as a common carrier even if the taxicab business operates in a jurisdiction other than Baltimore City, Baltimore County, the City of Cumberland, or the City of Hagerstown.

paragraph.text: An applicant for a permit to operate a taxicab business shall submit to the Commission an application on the form that the Commission provides.
The Commission shall issue a permit if, after investigation, the Commission determines that issuing the permit would be best for the public welfare and convenience.

subsection.text: In determining whether to issue a permit, the Commission shall consider all relevant factors including:

paragraph.text: the number of taxicabs to be used;
the taxicab and other transportation services already available in the locality; and
the rate to be charged.

subsection.text: If it appears that a taxicab company is making an effort to mislead the public by imitating the name, design, or distinctive combination of colors of any taxicab already approved by the Commission, the Commission shall:

paragraph.text: reject the taxicab company’s application for a permit; or
revoke or suspend the taxicab company’s existing permit.

subsection.text: Each permit applies only to the particular taxicab designated in the permit.

paragraph.text: Each permit is subject to the terms and conditions that the Commission establishes.
The Commission shall set a term of at least 1 year for each permit.
The Commission may renew a permit in accordance with the standards set forth in § 10-203 of this subtitle.

subsection.text: If sufficient cause is shown, the Commission may amend, suspend, or revoke a permit.
A permit may not be assigned or transferred unless, after investigation, the Commission approves the assignment or transfer as best for the public welfare and convenience.
An applicant for an assignment or transfer of a permit shall submit to the Commission a written application that sets forth the purpose, terms, and conditions of the proposed assignment or transfer.
Each taxicab for which a permit is required shall have:

paragraph.text: the name of the taxicab permit holder of the taxicab permanently painted or affixed on one door on each side of the taxicab, in letters at least 2.5 inches high; and
the word “taxicab” appear conspicuously on the taxicab.
The Commission shall:

subparagraph.text: determine the form and style of a badge; and
issue to each licensed taxicab driver a badge with the taxicab driver’s license number on the badge.

paragraph.text: A licensed taxicab driver shall display the badge conspicuously in the interior of a taxicab whenever operating the taxicab.

subsection.text: A taxicab for which a permit is required may not be operated unless the permit holder:

paragraph.text: obtains from an insurer authorized to transact business in the State, a liability insurance policy that:

subparagraph.text: is approved by the Commission in all respects, including policy provisions, form, and amounts; and

insures the permit holder and taxicab driver against liability to a passenger or member of the public for property damage, personal injury, or death resulting from an accident in which the taxicab is involved; or

paragraph.text: deposits with the Commission a bond with a casualty or surety company authorized to do business in the State that:

subparagraph.text: is approved by the Commission in all respects, including provisions, form, surety, and amounts; and

is made out to the State as obligee for the use and benefit of passengers and members of the public, and undertakes to indemnify passengers and members of the public against property damage, personal injury, or death resulting from an accident in which the taxicab is involved.

Except as provided in subparagraph (ii) of this paragraph, a cancellation or revocation of an insurance policy or bond that is required under subsection (a) of this section may not take effect until 45 days after the date the Commission receives written notice from the revoking party.

Cancellation or revocation of an insurance policy or bond issued by the Maryland Automobile Insurance Fund may not take effect until 30 days after the date the Commission receives written notice from the Maryland Automobile Insurance Fund.

paragraph.text: At any time, if the Commission determines that the existing bond or insurance protection is inadequate, the Commission may require new or additional bond or insurance as a condition of operation.

subsection.text: In addition to other duties specifically imposed by this subtitle, while driving a taxicab, a taxicab driver:

paragraph.text: shall accept as passenger and convey where directed any orderly person, on request, unless previously engaged or unable or forbidden to do so by this section, other valid law, or regulation;
except when transferring a vehicle to or from repair facilities, have in the taxicab driver’s possession a manifest that contains:

subparagraph.text: the time and date issued, the expiration time, the taxicab driver’s name and badge number, and the taxicab number;
space for meter readings and the calculation of driver income; and
any other information considered necessary by the Commission;

paragraph.text: shall report each change of residence within 72 hours to the Commission;
shall answer promptly all communications and summonses received from the Commission;
shall deliver all fares and all other legal charges received to the permit holder if working on a commission basis;
may not operate a taxicab while the taxicab driver’s operator license or taxicab driver’s license is suspended;
may not allow any other person to use the taxicab driver’s badge or identification card;
may not allow any other person to drive the taxicab and return the taxicab to the permit holder’s garage on completion of the shift to which the taxicab driver was assigned;
shall proceed with passengers to destination by the shortest practicable route;
shall give a receipt for fares on request on an authorized form;
may not operate a taxicab for more than 12 hours of any continuous 24-hour period;
shall display in the interior of the taxicab at all times, while on duty, the identification card with photograph attached in the frame provided for the card and photograph; and
shall charge only the rate of fare or charge established by law.
When assigned to a taxicab, the taxicab driver is responsible for ascertaining that the taxicab is in good working order.

A taxicab driver may not tamper with rate cards, the meter, meter light, cable, speedometer cable, or any other equipment that is required to be in the taxicab by law or that registers fares and charges.

subsection.text: A taxicab driver shall make maximum use of service communications with the driver’s switchboard operator or dispatcher in order to keep the driver’s taxicab available for response to calls.

paragraph.text: A taxicab driver may not solicit the patronage of a person who is at the terminal of another common carrier or at an intermediate point along an established route of that carrier to use that common carrier’s service.
Paragraph (1) of this subsection does not prohibit or interfere with a response to a call for a taxicab whether the call is made by telephone or by signal from a pedestrian.
Taxicabs being operated in Baltimore City:

subparagraph.text: may transport a passenger from Baltimore City into Baltimore County and return to Baltimore County for the same passenger; but
may not solicit a passenger within Baltimore County at any time.

paragraph.text: This subtitle may not impede the operation of taxicabs between Baltimore City and Baltimore-Washington International Thurgood Marshall Airport in the manner allowed by law.
A taxicab may not carry more than the number of passengers designated on the rate card.
A child in a passenger’s arms is not counted as a passenger.
Only one person may occupy the front seat with the driver.
A taxicab may be used from a railroad station or other public place of special assembly to serve jointly not more than four passengers who are bound for the same, or approximately the same, location.
A passenger who has engaged a taxicab may not be compelled to share the taxicab with another person.
A taxicab driver may not refuse service in order to group passengers more profitably.

subparagraph.text: Except as provided in subparagraph (ii) of this paragraph, if a taxicab is occupied by several passengers bound for different destinations, each passenger or party shall be charged the fare recorded on the meter at the time of arrival at the passenger’s or party’s destination.
A party or individual passenger may not be charged more than the fare applicable at the established rate for transportation over the shortest and most direct route.

paragraph.text: A taxicab driver may not solicit another passenger while en route to the destination of passengers or parties initially occupying the cab.

subsection.text: A driver of a taxicab may not operate the taxicab:

paragraph.text: recklessly;
in an unsafe manner; or
