the principal owner of an eligible minority business enterprise is in not more than one certified business that is participating in the Commission minority business enterprise utilization program under this section.

The sheltered market program established in subsection (b)(11) of this section may not be used until all less restrictive remedies under subsection (b) of this section and race–neutral remedies, including assistance with bonding requirements, financing, or bidding procedures for small firms, have been used and determined to be ineffective.
If at least three certified minority business enterprises bid on a contract under the sheltered market program, the Commission shall award the contract to the lowest bidder.
If fewer than three certified minority business enterprises bid on a contract under the sheltered market program, the contract shall be awarded under subsection (b)(10) of this section.
A certifying agency shall determine bona fide minority group membership based on an individual’s claim that the individual is:

subparagraph.text: a member of a minority group; and
regarded as a member by that minority community.

paragraph.text: A certifying agency may determine that an individual’s claim under this subsection is invalid.

To be eligible for certification as a minority business enterprise and participation in a minority business enterprise utilization program under § 20–203 or § 20–204 of this subtitle, a business shall meet the standards under this subsection.

subparagraph.text: A minority business enterprise shall be an independent business.
A certifying agency shall determine whether a business is independent by considering:

sub-subparagraph.text: the date the business was established;
the adequacy of the resources of the business for the work required under the contract;
the degree to which financial, equipment leasing, and other relationships with nonminority businesses vary from industry practice; and
any other relevant factor.

paragraph.text: A minority owner shall have real, substantial, and continuing ownership and control of the business that goes beyond the pro forma ownership of the business as reflected in the ownership documents.

A minority owner shall have the customary incidents of ownership and share in the risks and profits commensurate with the ownership interests in the business as demonstrated by an examination of the substance rather than the form of the arrangements.
Recognition of the business as a separate entity for tax or corporate purposes is not necessarily sufficient for certification as a minority business enterprise.

subparagraph.text: A minority owner shall have the power to:

sub-subparagraph.text: direct or cause the direction of the management and policies of the business; and
make the day–to–day and major decisions on matters of management, policy, and operations for the business.

subparagraph.text: The business may not be subject to a formal or informal restriction, including a bylaw, partnership agreement, or charter requirement for cumulative voting rights, that prevents a minority owner from making a business decision without the cooperation or vote of an owner who is not a minority.
The business may not be operated disproportionately by the owners of the business who are not minorities.

If the management of the business is contracted out to an individual other than the owner, the individual who has the ultimate power to hire and fire the managers may be considered as controlling the business.
Minorities shall directly hold all securities that constitute ownership or control of a corporation for the purpose of establishing the corporation as a minority business enterprise.
Securities held in trust or by a guardian for a minor may not be considered held by minorities in determining the ownership or control of a corporation.

paragraph.text: A contribution of capital or expertise by a minority owner to acquire an interest in a business shall be real and substantial and may not include:

subparagraph.text: a promise to contribute capital;
a note payable to the business or owners of the business who are not socially and economically disadvantaged; or
participation as an employee and not as a manager.

subsection.text: In determining eligibility as a minority business enterprise, a certifying agency shall:

paragraph.text: closely scrutinize a newly formed business, or a business for which the ownership or control has changed since the date of the advertisement of the contract, to determine the reason for the timing of the formation or change;

carefully review a previous or continuing employer–employee relationship among present owners to ensure that an employee–owner has the management responsibilities and capabilities required under this section; and

carefully review a relationship between a minority business enterprise and a business that is not a minority business enterprise that has an interest in the minority business enterprise to determine if the interest of the nonminority business conflicts with the ownership and control requirements of this section.

subsection.text: The Office shall verify that a certified minority business enterprise listed in a schedule of participation is actually performing work and receiving compensation as established in the schedule.
To facilitate the Office completing its duties under subsection (a) of this section, a contractor shall:

paragraph.text: allow the Office to inspect any relevant matter, including records and the job site;
allow the Office to interview subcontractors and employees of the contractor;
if performing a construction contract, ensure that subcontractors:

subparagraph.text: are paid any undisputed amount to which the subcontractor is entitled as provided under § 15–226 of the State Finance and Procurement Article; and
comply with Commission regulations;

paragraph.text: include in the agreement with the certified minority business enterprise subcontractor a requirement that the subcontractor submit a monthly report to the Commission that:

subparagraph.text: identifies the prime contract; and
lists payments received from the contractor in the previous month and invoices sent to the contractor that have not been paid; and

paragraph.text: submit a monthly report to the Commission that lists:

subparagraph.text: unpaid invoices that are more than 30 days old received from certified minority business enterprise subcontractors; and
the reason payments have not been made.

On completion of a contract or before final payment or release of retainage, the Commission may require a general contractor on a contract having a minority business enterprise subcontracting goal to submit to the Commission a final report of all payments made to or withheld from minority business enterprise subcontractors.
The final report shall be in affidavit form and under the penalties for perjury.

paragraph.text: Each solicitation shall contain notice of the requirements of this subsection.
On a finding that a contractor is noncompliant, the Commission shall notify the contractor in writing of the findings and state the required corrective action.
A noncompliant contractor shall:

subparagraph.text: initiate the corrective action within 10 days after receiving the written notice; and
complete the corrective action within the time specified by the Commission.

subsection.text: If the Commission finds that a general contractor is in material noncompliance with minority business enterprise contract provisions and the general contractor fails to take the corrective action required by the Commission, the Commission may:

paragraph.text: terminate the contract;
refer the general contractor to the general manager of the Commission or the full Commission for appropriate action; or
initiate any other specific remedy identified in the contract.

subsection.text: By September 15 of each year, the Commission shall issue a report to the Montgomery County and Prince George’s County Senate and House Delegations to the Maryland General Assembly concerning:

paragraph.text: the implementation and administration of the minority business enterprise programs under this subtitle for the fiscal year ending on the preceding June 30; and
appropriate recommendations concerning the programs.
The Commission may conduct an impartial fact–finding study in connection with a minority business enterprise program for consistency with applicable law.
The Commission shall report the findings of a study completed under this subsection to the Montgomery County and Prince George’s County Senate and House Delegations to the Maryland General Assembly.

section.text: This subtitle shall be of no effect and may not be enforced after July 1, 2017.
In this subtitle, “program” means a local small business enterprise program.

subsection.text: By resolution or adopting regulations, the Commission may establish a local small business enterprise program.
The Office of Small, Local, and Minority Business Enterprise, established under § 20–202 of this title, shall administer the program.

section.text: The purpose of the program is to assist small businesses in Montgomery County and Prince George’s County by:

paragraph.text: establishing a sheltered market or other appropriate preference; or
facilitating the award of Commission construction contracts or procurement contracts for goods and services to small businesses in Montgomery County and Prince George’s County.

subsection.text: The Commission shall adopt:

paragraph.text: eligibility criteria for businesses to qualify for the program, including:

subparagraph.text: the criteria for a small business qualifying under the Small Business Preference Program as established in regulations adopted by the Department of General Services under § 14–203 of the State Finance and Procurement Article;
a requirement that:

sub-subparagraph.text: the business’s principal place of business be in Montgomery County or Prince George’s County; or
at least 25% of the total number of employees of the business be domiciled in Montgomery County or Prince George’s County; and

subparagraph.text: any other eligibility criteria that the Commission determines to be necessary or appropriate for the promotion of small businesses in the Commission’s service area; and

paragraph.text: administrative procedures for conducting the program.

subsection.text: A business may qualify as a local small business enterprise under the program without regard to the race, ethnicity, or gender of the participants in the business.
The Commission shall establish criteria for graduation from the program for a local small business that the Commission determines no longer requires the assistance or benefits offered by the program.
The Commission shall review the eligibility criteria and administrative procedures of the program each year to assess their effectiveness in furthering the purposes of the program.
In this section, “property” includes:

paragraph.text: land;
structures;
buildings;
streambeds;
waterways;
water rights;
watersheds;
water systems and parts of water systems; and
wastewater systems and parts of wastewater systems.

subsection.text: The Commission may acquire property for the construction, extension, maintenance, or operation of a project the Commission considers:

paragraph.text: necessary to carry out this division; or
in furtherance of this division.

subsection.text: If the Commission decides to acquire property within or outside the sanitary district in accordance with subsection (b) of this section, the Commission may acquire the property:

paragraph.text: in fee; or
as an easement.

subsection.text: If the Commission fails to agree on the terms of acquisition with the owner of any property, the Commission may condemn the property by filing a petition for condemnation in the circuit court for the county in which the property is situated, as provided for condemnation of land under the Real Property Article.
The Commission may condemn the interest of any tenant, lessee, or other person having an interest in property that the Commission decides to acquire.

paragraph.text: Except as provided in subsection (b) of this section, land used for cemetery purposes may not be condemned unless the Commission adopts a resolution declaring that it is necessary for the public health and safety to acquire the cemetery land, or an easement in the land, immediately by condemnation.
A resolution under this subsection may only be adopted on the affirmative vote of a majority of the commissioners from the county where the cemetery land is located.

The Commission may condemn public or private land used for cemetery purposes, or an easement in the land, without adopting a resolution in accordance with subsection (a) of this section if the land or easement is for the purpose of installing sewer lines or water lines.
Sewer lines or water lines installed on property condemned under paragraph (1) of this subsection shall be constructed underground and enclosed.

subsection.text: The land or easement to be acquired may not disturb:

paragraph.text: any existing grave, grave marker, or monument; or
any grave site:

subparagraph.text: the title to which has been transferred as a result of a bona fide sale or exchange; or
in which burial rights have vested or been transferred as a result of a bona fide sale or exchange.

section.text: If the Commission does not consider the property necessary for the operation of its water, sewer, or stormwater management systems, the Commission may sell, lease, transfer, convey, or dispose of any of its real or personal property on terms and conditions that the Commission considers advantageous.

paragraph.text: In this section the following words have the meanings indicated.
“High performance building” means a building that:

subparagraph.text: meets or exceeds the current version of the U.S. Green Building Council’s Leadership in Energy and Environmental Design (LEED) Green Building Rating System Silver rating; or

achieves at least a comparable numeric rating according to a nationally recognized, accepted, and appropriate numeric sustainable development rating system, guideline, or standard approved by the Secretary of Budget and Management and the Secretary of General Services.

paragraph.text: “Major renovation” means the renovation of a building where:

subparagraph.text: the building shell is to be reused for the new construction;
the heating, ventilating, and air–conditioning (HVAC), electrical, and plumbing systems are to be replaced; and
the scope of the renovation is 7,500 square feet or greater.

subsection.text: It is the intent of the General Assembly that, to the extent practicable:

paragraph.text: the Commission shall employ green building technologies when constructing or renovating a Commission–owned building not subject to this section; and
high performance buildings shall meet the criteria and standards established under the “High Efficiency Green Building Program” adopted by the Maryland Green Building Council.

subsection.text: Except as provided in subsections (d) and (e) of this section, if a capital project includes the construction or major renovation of a building that is 7,500 square feet or greater, the building shall be constructed or renovated to be a high performance building.
The following types of unoccupied buildings are not required to be constructed or renovated to be high performance buildings:

paragraph.text: warehouse and storage facilities;
garages;
maintenance facilities;
transmitter buildings;
pumping stations; and
other similar types of buildings, as determined by the Commission.
The Commission may request from the county where the proposed capital project is located a waiver from complying with subsection (c) of this section.

On receipt of a written request of a waiver under this subsection, with approval of the county executive, the county council of the county where the proposed capital project is located may issue a waiver under this subsection if the county council determines that the use of a high performance building in a proposed capital project is not practicable.

section.text: In this subtitle, “water supply, sanitary sewer, or stormwater management project” includes a:

paragraph.text: water main, sewer, or drain or appurtenance of a water main, sewer, or drain;
fire hydrant;
reservoir;
water purification plant;
tank;
pumping station; and
sewage disposal plant.

section.text: The purpose of this subtitle is to provide that in emergencies the Commission, in its discretion, may condemn land or interest in land under the optional procedure provided by this subtitle before or after construction of a water supply, sanitary sewer, or stormwater management system, or part of a system, has begun.
This subtitle applies only to land in Prince George’s County.

subsection.text: Subject to subsection (b) of this section and §§ 21–205 and 21–206(a) of this subtitle, the Commission may enter on and take possession of remaining land or interest in land described in item (2) of this subsection and proceed with the extension or construction of a water supply, sanitary sewer, or stormwater management project if the Commission:

paragraph.text: has acquired or is acquiring by purchase or other procedure, including the condemnation procedures provided for in the Real Property Article and Subtitle 1 of this title, at least one–half of the takings of land or interest in land required for the extension or construction of the project; and
determines that the remaining takings of land or interest in land are needed for the extension or construction of the project.

subsection.text: A building may not be taken under this subtitle.

paragraph.text: The Commission’s right to enter and take possession of land or an interest in land under this subtitle takes effect immediately after the filing of a written declaration of taking in the Circuit Court for Prince George’s County, accompanied by payment of the estimated fair market value of the land or interest in land, as required under § 21–206(a) of this subtitle.
A declaration of taking may be:

subparagraph.text: combined with a petition for condemnation, filed simultaneously with or as part of the same pleading; or
filed after a petition for condemnation.

subsection.text: A declaration of taking shall:

paragraph.text: include a statement as to the number of takings in land or interest in land necessary for the extension or construction of the water supply, sanitary sewer, or stormwater management project;

include a statement that the Commission has acquired or is acquiring by purchase or procedures other than the declaration of taking method at least one–half of the takings needed for the extension or construction of the project;
contain a description of the land or interest in land being taken;
name the Commission as plaintiff and the owner of the land or interest in land as defendant;
be docketed by the clerk of the circuit court, unless the petition for condemnation is on file or filed simultaneously with the declaration of taking; and
identify the qualified appraiser and specify the estimated fair market value of the land or interest in land being taken, as required by § 21–206(a) of this subtitle.

subsection.text: Notice of and service on the property owner of a declaration of taking shall be accomplished in the same manner as is required for petitions for condemnation.

If the Commission files the declaration of taking accompanied by the payment of the estimated fair market value required under § 21–206(a) of this subtitle, the date of filing shall be the operative date of the taking to determine:

paragraph.text: the fair market value of the land or interest in land taken; and
damages, if any, caused by the taking.

With the declaration of taking, the Commission shall pay to the owner of the land or interest in land, or to the Circuit Court for Prince George’s County for the owner’s benefit, a sum that the Commission estimates to be the fair market value of the land or interest in land being taken.

The Commission’s estimate of the fair market value of the land or interest in land being taken may not be less than its appraised value as evaluated by at least one experienced and qualified appraiser, whose qualifications as an appraiser have been accepted by a court of record of the State.

subsection.text: Payment of the estimated fair market value of land or interest in land under this section does not limit the amount that may be awarded with respect to the land or interest in land.

If the estimated fair market value of the land or interest in land is paid into the court under subsection (a) of this section, the property owner, on written request to the clerk of the court, may receive the sum paid without prejudice to any of the owner’s rights if the property owner agrees to pay back to the Commission the amount by which the sum paid exceeds the final award.

paragraph.text: If the Commission and the owner of the land or interest in land being taken are unable to agree as to the compensation and damages, if any, caused by the taking, the Commission shall institute condemnation proceedings in the manner required by the Real Property Article and the Maryland Rules.
The court shall hear and determine the condemnation proceedings as soon as practicable after the application to the court.

subsection.text: If the condemnation petition is not filed at the same time as the Commission pays the estimated fair market value to the owner or to the court for the owner’s benefit, the Commission shall file the condemnation petition not later than 30 days after receipt of notice from the property owner that a disagreement exists as to the compensation and damages, if any, caused by the taking.

paragraph.text: In this section the following words have the meanings indicated.

subparagraph.text: “District council” has the meaning stated in § 14–101 of the Land Use Article.
“District council” includes a designee or hearing officer appointed by the district council.

paragraph.text: “Regional district” has the meaning stated in § 14–101 of the Land Use Article.

subsection.text: An application for amendment to the zoning map of the regional district may be referred by the respective district council to the Commission for the Commission’s review and comment.

paragraph.text: The Commission shall review each application referred to it and shall report in writing on each application to the appropriate district council not less than 15 days before the regularly scheduled public hearing on the application.
The report shall include an analysis of the probable impact on existing and proposed sewer, water, or other Commission facilities in terms of:

subparagraph.text: treatment facilities;
sewer lines of both program and less–than–program size;
their respective design capacity and present volume flow to capacity relationship;
construction schedules; and
proposed projects under the 6–year capital improvements program or 10–year water and sewer plan.

subsection.text: With respect to an application referred to the Commission under subsection (b) of this section, the Commission shall provide supplemental information requested by the district council at least 15 days before the regularly scheduled public hearing on the application or within 15 days after the Commission receives the request, whichever is later.
On request of the district council, Commission staff shall appear before the district council to discuss information provided by the Commission under this section.

section.text: In this subtitle, “urban renewal authority”:

paragraph.text: means a unit of government that is engaged in urban renewal activity; and
includes:

subparagraph.text: the State;
Montgomery County;
Prince George’s County; and
any unit of government in Montgomery County or Prince George’s County.

section.text: If the Commission is paid or assured payment by an urban renewal authority for the Commission’s costs and expenditures in accordance with this subtitle, the Commission may cooperate with and assist the urban renewal authority in an urban renewal project undertaken by the urban renewal authority by abandoning, relocating, installing, constructing, or reconstructing water or sanitary sewer facilities in the urban renewal area.

subsection.text: If an urban renewal project or an act of the General Assembly that provides for an urban renewal program requires or results in the abandonment, relocation, realignment, raising, lowering, rebuilding, or removal of any water or sanitary sewer facility of the Commission, the urban renewal authority shall pay to the Commission the entire cost less any salvage value from the old facility.
An urban renewal authority may not allow any Commission structure to be removed, abandoned, or damaged in connection with an urban renewal project until:

paragraph.text: the urban renewal authority has paid the Commission; or
payment to the Commission has been assured to the Commission’s satisfaction, in accordance with this subtitle.

subsection.text: If an urban renewal project requires the construction of a new water or sanitary sewer facility by the Commission, the Commission may:

paragraph.text: construct the facility if:

subparagraph.text: the costs of the construction will be repaid through existing provisions for special assessments, including front foot benefit charges; or
the payment is made or assured by the urban renewal authority; and

paragraph.text: enter into agreements with an urban renewal authority providing for payment to the Commission over a period of time, with the terms of the contract and rate of interest determined by the Commission.

section.text: In this subtitle, “bond” means a bond, note, certificate of indebtedness, security, or other instrument evidencing debt issued and sold or offered for sale in accordance with law.

subsection.text: The Commission may issue bonds of the sanitary district in amounts necessary to carry on its work, including for:

paragraph.text: acquisition, design, construction, reconstruction, establishment, extension, enlargement, or condemnation of the water and sewer systems in the sanitary district or in an area where extension of the systems may be authorized by law;
acquisition of land or equipment for, or construction, remodeling, enlargement, or replacement of any office or operating building necessary to administer or operate the systems; or

design and construction of trunk sewers and sewers or portions of sewer lines required to relieve septic tank failures and for which no front foot benefit charges can be collected as determined by the Commission, and sewage pumping stations and sewage disposal facilities, including reimbursement to the District of Columbia or other federal authorities for any construction within the District of Columbia.
The Commission may issue bonds of the sanitary district for the acquisition of capital equipment in amounts necessary to carry on its work, including:

subparagraph.text: computer equipment;
laboratory equipment;
maintenance field and yard equipment;
office equipment;
telecommunication equipment; and
trucks and fleet vehicles.

paragraph.text: The bonds may be issued only to finance the acquisition of equipment:

subparagraph.text: with a useful life of 4 to 7 years;
that the Commission expects to finance over a period of 4 years or less; and
for which the Commission budgets accordingly.

paragraph.text: The principal of the bonds issued under this subsection shall be payable annually beginning not more than 1 year after the date of issue.
The bonds issued under this subsection shall mature not more than 4 years after the date of issue.

The aggregate amount of bonds issued under this subsection outstanding at any time may not exceed $15,000,000, subject to annual upward adjustment in accordance with the Consumer Price Index – All Urban Consumers (CPI–U), for the Washington, DC–MD–VA metropolitan area, over the base year 1997.

subsection.text: Except as otherwise provided in this section, bonds issued under this section shall be issued as serial bonds with the principal payable annually, beginning no later than 3 years from the date of issue.

paragraph.text: The bonds shall:

subparagraph.text: be issued in denominations determined by the Commission;
bear interest annually at rates the Commission determines to be advantageous to the sanitary district and in the public interest; and
mature no later than 40 years from the date of issue.

paragraph.text: The bonds may be:

subparagraph.text: registered or coupon bonds; or
registrable as to principal with interest represented by coupons.

paragraph.text: The interest on the bonds shall be payable semiannually.
Notwithstanding any other provision of law, the Commission may issue bonds that have a maturity of more than 1 year as fully registered bonds without coupons.
The Commission may determine the form of the bonds issued under paragraph (1) of this subsection for the purposes of:

subparagraph.text: qualifying the interest on the bonds for exemption from federal income tax; and
conforming to standards and practices for the registration and transfer of bonds generally followed by banks and trust companies acting as registrars and transfer agents of bonds, including:

sub-subparagraph.text: signing of bonds by facsimile signatures of Commission officers;
authentication of bonds by the manual signature of an officer of a bank or trust company signing as the registrar or transfer agent;
maintenance by registrars or transfer agents of records of owners of bonds;
complying with the standard record date system for payment of interest;
issuing bonds on the basis of book entries and certificates; and
complying with requirements for the form of bond that is acceptable to central depositories used in the marketing and trading of municipal bond issues.

subsection.text: The bonds of the sanitary district or of the Commission are forever exempt from taxation by the State and counties and municipalities in the State.
The bonds may be made redeemable before maturity at the option of the Commission at the prices and under terms and conditions that the Commission sets before the bonds are issued.

Except as provided in subsection (b) of this section, the aggregate principal amount of bonds outstanding at any time that will not reach full maturity within 5 years from the date of issue may not exceed the greater of:

paragraph.text: the sum of:

subparagraph.text: 3.8% of the total assessable base of all real property assessed for county tax purposes within the sanitary district; and
7% of the total assessable personal property and operating real property described under § 8–109(c) of the Tax – Property Article assessed for county tax purposes within the sanitary district; or

paragraph.text: the sum of:

subparagraph.text: 3.8% of the total assessable base of all real property assessed for county tax purposes within the sanitary district as of July 1, 1997; and

7% of the total assessable personal property and operating real property described under § 8–109(c) of the Tax – Property Article assessed for county tax purposes within the sanitary district as of July 1, 1997.

paragraph.text: In this subsection, “government obligation” means:

subparagraph.text: a direct obligation of the United States; or
an obligation unconditionally guaranteed as to principal and interest by the United States.

paragraph.text: To calculate the maximum debt authorized under this section, the aggregate amount of bonds outstanding is reduced by:

subparagraph.text: the amount held in the joint sinking fund account for the payment of principal of the bonds; and
the amount of any bond for which there is irrevocably deposited:

sub-subparagraph.text: cash; or

government obligations maturing as to principal and interest at times and in amounts sufficient to provide adequate and complete payment of the principal or redemption price and interest as required on the bond.

subsection.text: Except as otherwise provided by an act of the General Assembly of Maryland, the maximum debt level authorized under this section applies to any bond issued under an act of the General Assembly of Maryland enacted on or after July 1, 1997.

paragraph.text: The bonds shall be:

subparagraph.text: issued under the hand and seal of the Commission; and
guaranteed as to payment of principal and interest by Montgomery County and Prince George’s County.

paragraph.text: Each bond shall contain the following statement:
“The payment of interest when due and the principal at maturity is guaranteed by Montgomery and Prince George’s counties, Maryland”.
The bonds of the sanitary district shall be signed:

subparagraph.text: by the chair, secretary, and treasurer of the Commission; or
if authorized by the Commission, by any two commissioners.

paragraph.text: The official seal of the Commission shall be impressed on a bond of the sanitary district.
For bonds issued for the purposes described under § 22–102(a)(1) and (2) of this subtitle, the Commission may authorize:

subparagraph.text: any of its officials to sign a bond by facsimile signature; and
a facsimile of the official seal to be printed on the bond.

paragraph.text: For bonds issued for the purposes described under § 22–102(a)(3) of this subtitle, the Commission may authorize:

subparagraph.text: any of its officials to sign a bond by facsimile signature, provided that the bond is manually signed by at least one official; and
a facsimile of the official seal to be printed on the bond.

subsection.text: Within 20 days after the bonds are presented by the Commission for signing, the guaranty or endorsement by Montgomery County and Prince George’s County shall be signed on each of the bonds on behalf of each county by the county executives of Montgomery County and Prince George’s County, or by the county executive’s designee, by facsimile or manual signature as the county executive determines.

The liability under the guarantee for each county is in the same proportion that the assessable base of that part of that county within the sanitary district bears to the assessable base of the sanitary district.

paragraph.text: The Commission may waive the guarantee required under subsection (d) of this section, if the Commission determines that:

subparagraph.text: the waiver would not seriously affect the sale of the bonds of the sanitary district; and
money market conditions justify the sale of the bonds of the sanitary district without the guarantee.

paragraph.text: The waiver of the guarantee under paragraph (1) of this subsection on one issue of bonds may not be construed to be a waiver of the guarantee of future bond issues.

If a bond issued by the Commission is destroyed, lost, or mutilated, the Commission may execute and deliver to the holder or registered owner of the bond a new bond with the same date, number, maturity, and tenor:

subparagraph.text: on conditions to evidence ownership and the destruction or loss of the bond that the Commission determines; or
in exchange and substitution for and cancellation of the mutilated bond and any interest coupons.

paragraph.text: The Commission may require indemnity and payment of charges in connection with the exchange or substitution of a bond.

If the destroyed, lost, or mutilated bond was guaranteed by Montgomery County and Prince George’s County, the new bond issued in substitution shall be endorsed with a guaranty identical to the guaranty on the destroyed, lost, or mutilated bond.
The endorsement shall be signed as provided in § 22–104 of this subtitle.

To retire and pay the interest on bonds issued under this subtitle, each year the county councils of Montgomery County and Prince George’s County shall impose against the assessable property that is in the sanitary district a tax sufficient to pay the principal of and interest on the bonds, as and when due and until paid in full.
The tax is to be determined, imposed, collected, and paid over to the Commission as provided in this section.

Each year the Commission shall determine the amount necessary to pay the principal and interest on bonds issued to provide funds for the construction, remodeling, enlargement, or replacement of any office or operating building.

subparagraph.text: The Commission shall set aside the amount determined under paragraph (3) of this subsection from water service charges, sewer usage charges, house connection charges, and any other charges imposed by the Commission as the Commission determines to be fair and equitable.

The amount set aside shall be deducted from the amount that the Commission determines to be necessary to be raised by direct taxation under this section on certification to the county councils of Montgomery County and Prince George’s County.

subsection.text: At least 30 days before the taxable year for property taxes, the county executives of Montgomery County and Prince George’s County shall certify to the Commission the total valuation of assessable property within the sanitary district in each county.

paragraph.text: The Commission shall determine the amount necessary, for the next taxable year, to pay:

subparagraph.text: interest on all outstanding bonds;
principal of all serial bonds maturing during the year; and
the proportionate part of principal of all outstanding sinking fund bonds as determined by the usual table of redemption of bonds by annual deposit in a sinking fund on interest.

paragraph.text: After deducting all amounts in hand applicable to payment of interest and principal on the bonds, the Commission shall certify to the county councils of Montgomery County and Prince George’s County the number of cents per $100 necessary to raise the amount determined under paragraph (1) of this subsection.

Each year the county councils of Montgomery County and Prince George’s County shall impose a tax in the amount determined under subsection (c)(1) of this section on all assessable property within the sanitary district.
The taxes imposed under this section shall:

subparagraph.text: have the same status as county taxes; and
be imposed and collected by the tax collecting authority for each county as county taxes.

subsection.text: Every 60 days, each county shall pay to the Commission the taxes collected under this section.

paragraph.text: The amount collected by the Commission for benefits imposed against property for water supply and sewer construction under Title 25, Subtitle 2 of this article shall be set aside in a separate fund known as the Current Bond Fund.

subparagraph.text: The Current Bond Fund shall be used to pay interest on all outstanding bonds.
The balance of the Current Bond Fund shall be prorated monthly and applied to:

sub-subparagraph.text: the payment of the principal of maturing serial bonds; and

the payment into the joint Sinking Fund Account, as provided under § 22–108 of this subtitle, of the proportionate part of the principal of outstanding sinking fund bonds as the outstanding par value of both types of bonds bear to each other.

subsection.text: To determine the amount necessary to be imposed under § 22–106 of this subtitle, the Commission shall deduct the amount to its credit in the Current Bond Fund account from the amount necessary to be raised in any 1 year for interest on all outstanding bonds.

paragraph.text: From the money received from the taxes imposed under § 22–106 of this subtitle together with the amount in hand to the credit of the Current Bond Fund or the amount applicable to the payment of interest and principal on the bonds, the Commission shall:

subparagraph.text: pay all interest on the bonds as and when due; and
pay or reserve a sufficient amount of money to pay the serial bonds becoming due during the taxable year.

paragraph.text: After making the distributions required under paragraph (1) of this subsection, the Commission shall deposit in one or more banks in Montgomery County or Prince George’s County, to the credit of both counties and the Commission, as a joint fund to be known as the Sinking Fund Account, the amount raised for the payment of the proportionate part of the principal of the sinking fund bonds.

subsection.text: The Commission and Montgomery County and Prince George’s County shall invest money in the Sinking Fund Account in any bonds in which the U.S. Treasury Department authorizes national banks to invest savings or trust funds.

If receipts from the tax or other sources are inadequate to pay the principal of the serial bonds becoming due during the taxable year and to deposit the principal payment on the sinking fund bonds, the deficiency shall be added to and collected in the following year’s tax levy.
Before the first taxable year for property taxes, the Commission may pay the interest on any bonds it issues out of the proceeds of the sale of the bonds.

section.text: To ensure the prompt payment of interest and provision for the payment of the principal on bonds issued under this subtitle:

paragraph.text: the prompt and proper performance of the acts required under §§ 22–106 and 22–108 of this subtitle is specially enjoined; and
a person who is required to act under §§ 22–106 and 22–108 of this subtitle:

subparagraph.text: shall perform the acts required under those sections;
shall pay over any funds as required under those sections; and
may not use any part of the funds for any other purpose than for the payment of principal and interest on the bonds.

paragraph.text: Subject to paragraph (2) of this subsection, the Commission may borrow money in anticipation of taxes, sale of bonds, or other revenue of the fiscal year in which the loan is made or the next succeeding fiscal year to:

subparagraph.text: pay the principal and interest of bonds due or to become due within 4 months;
pay the interest becoming due on any bonds within 4 months and not otherwise adequately provided for; or
meet payments required to be made to employees and laborers and not otherwise provided for.

paragraph.text: The loan shall be payable not later than the end of the fiscal year after the year in which the loan is made.
The Commission shall issue negotiable notes for all money borrowed under subsection (a) of this section.
The notes may be renewed and money may be borrowed on new notes to pay any indebtedness.
The notes and loans shall mature within the time limit for the payment of the original loan.
The Commission shall authorize, by resolution, the notes and set:

subparagraph.text: the actual or maximum face amount of the notes;
the actual or maximum rate of interest to be paid on the amount borrowed; and
the actual or approximate maturity of the notes.

paragraph.text: The Commission shall determine the form and manner of execution of the notes.
Subject to paragraph (2) of this subsection, the Commission may determine the manner in which the notes may be disposed of.

The aggregate amount of notes outstanding at any one time may not exceed an amount equal to the total principal of and interest on bonds of the sanitary district due and payable in the fiscal year in which the notes are issued.

section.text: Each year the Commission shall:

paragraph.text: determine the amount necessary to pay the principal and interest requirements of the bonds; and
set the water service charge of the sanitary district at a rate sufficient to pay:

subparagraph.text: the cost of the service; and
the requirements of bonds, issued and outstanding, that are to be paid out of the water service.

section.text: The amount of water service charges and sewer usage charges collected each year for the payment of principal and interest due on outstanding bonds shall be deducted from the amount that the Commission has determined is necessary to be raised by an ad valorem tax on certification to the county councils of Montgomery County and Prince George’s County.

paragraph.text: Subject to written approval of the county executives and county councils of Montgomery County and Prince George’s County, the Commission, on behalf of the sanitary district, may:

subparagraph.text: borrow money for any purpose for which bonds of the Commission are to be issued; and
issue negotiable bond anticipation notes of the Commission for any money borrowed in anticipation of the issuance of the bonds or of other revenues for capital expenditures.

paragraph.text: The aggregate amount of all bond anticipation notes outstanding under this section at any one time may not exceed $85,000,000.

The aggregate amount of bond anticipation notes issued under this section in anticipation of the issuance of bonds that are subject to the 7% limitation under § 22–103(a) of this subtitle, together with the aggregate amount of bonds then outstanding that are subject to the limitation, may not exceed the 7% limitation.
Except as otherwise provided for emergent purposes under subsection (d) of this section, bond anticipation notes, including any renewals under item (ii) of this paragraph:

subparagraph.text: shall mature within 5 years from the date the notes are first issued; or
if issued for a period of less than 5 years, may be renewed for successive periods not to exceed 1 year each.

paragraph.text: The notes shall be payable within 5 years after the date of the first issue.

subsection.text: The notes shall:

paragraph.text: be issued in denominations determined by the Commission;
bear interest as provided in § 22–102(d) of this subtitle;
be payable at or before maturity; and
be in the form and executed in the manner that the Commission determines.

subparagraph.text: Except as provided in paragraph (2) of this subsection, bond anticipation notes shall be sold at public sale.
Renewal notes may be exchanged for outstanding notes on terms that the Commission determines.

paragraph.text: Subject to paragraph (3) of this subsection, the Commission may sell the notes at a negotiated sale if:

subparagraph.text: the Commission determines that, for economic, engineering, or financial administration purposes, the requirements for the funds require the sale of the notes at an immediate or earlier time than is possible through the procedures of a public sale; and
the amount of bond anticipation notes sold at negotiated sale, issued or outstanding at any one time, does not exceed $10,000,000.

paragraph.text: Before concluding a negotiated sale, the Commission shall negotiate with at least two recognized banking institutions that purchase bond anticipation notes and obtain the terms most favorable in the Commission’s interest.
Bond anticipation notes sold at a negotiated sale:

subparagraph.text: shall mature within a period not exceeding 180 days; and
may be renewed not more than one time for an additional period not to exceed 180 days.

paragraph.text: Except as provided in paragraph (2) of this subsection, bond anticipation notes shall be paid from the proceeds of the bonds in anticipation of which they are issued.

subparagraph.text: The Commission may retire the notes from funds available for the payment of the bonds authorized by the Commission.
The amount of the bonds authorized shall be reduced by the amount of the retired notes.

paragraph.text: Bond anticipation notes issued under this section are general obligations of the Commission.
The full faith, credit, and taxing power of the Commission shall be pledged for the repayment of the notes.

Montgomery County and Prince George’s County shall guarantee the bond anticipation notes as to payment of principal and interest substantially in the manner and form and with the effect provided for the guarantee of the construction bonds of the Commission issued under § 22–102(a)(1) of this subtitle.
The Commission may waive the required guarantee.

subsection.text: Bond anticipation notes issued under this section, including the interest on the notes, are forever exempt from taxation by the State and counties and municipalities in the State.

The powers and authority granted under this section are in addition and supplemental to the powers and authority granted under any other law and shall be liberally construed to effectuate the purposes of this section.
The Commission may borrow money and issue refunding bonds to refund bonds issued and outstanding by the Commission if:

paragraph.text: the county executives and county councils of Montgomery County and Prince George’s County approve the plan for the issuance of refunding bonds; and
the Commission determines that issuing refunding bonds will result in total savings in debt service costs, directly or through any debt restructuring.

subsection.text: The Commission shall authorize the issuance of refunding bonds by resolution that may include:

paragraph.text: the date of the refunding bonds;
the maturity dates of the refunding bonds, which may not exceed 40 years from the date of issue;
the interest rates on the refunding bonds, which may not exceed 10% annually;
the denominations of the refunding bonds;
the form of the refunding bonds, which may be coupon or registered;
registration or conversion privileges;
the manner of executing the refunding bonds;
the manner of payment at places in or outside of the State;
terms for redemption before maturity;
terms for replacement of mutilated, destroyed, stolen, or lost bonds; and
any other terms, conditions, or covenants.

subsection.text: Refunding bonds issued to refund outstanding bonds for which front foot benefit charges have been imposed shall mature on or before 1 year after the date set for the payment of the final installment of the front foot benefit charge.

paragraph.text: Refunding bonds may be:

subparagraph.text: exchanged for bonds being refunded;
sold at public sale; or
subject to paragraph (2) of this subsection, sold at a negotiated sale in an open meeting.

paragraph.text: Refunding bonds may be sold at a negotiated sale if the Commission determines:

subparagraph.text: that a public sale would be impracticable to effectuate the purpose of the refunding bonds; and
the price, terms, and conditions are in the best interest of the Commission.

paragraph.text: At least 45 days before the sale or exchange of any refunding bonds, the Commission shall deliver its plan on the issuance of the refunding bonds to the county executives and county councils of Montgomery County and Prince George’s County.

Except as provided in paragraph (3) of this subsection, the Commission may not sell or exchange the refunding bonds unless the plan under paragraph (1) of this subsection is approved by the county executives and county councils of Montgomery County and Prince George’s County.

subparagraph.text: On or before 30 days after the delivery of the plan, the county executives and county councils of Montgomery County and Prince George’s County shall approve or disapprove of the plan.
Failure of a county executive or county council of Montgomery County or Prince George’s County to act within 30 days is deemed as approval of the plan by that county.

paragraph.text: The county executives and county councils of Montgomery County and Prince George’s County may waive the time period requirements under this subsection.

subsection.text: If an officer whose signature or facsimile signature appears on a refunding bond or coupon ceases to be an officer before the delivery of the refunding bond, the signature or facsimile is valid and sufficient as if the officer remained in office until delivery.

Refunding bonds issued to refund bonds guaranteed as to payment of principal and interest by Montgomery County or Prince George’s County may be guaranteed in the same manner and form as under § 22–104 of this subtitle.
Refunding bonds authorized under this section are:

paragraph.text: in addition to any other bonds authorized under this subtitle; and
included in computing the amount of bonds that may be issued under the 7% limitation under § 22–103 of this subtitle.

subsection.text: Refunding bonds authorized under this section are forever exempt from taxation by the State and counties and municipalities in the State.
The powers granted under this section are not subject to the provisions of any other law in conflict with the powers.

The Commission may determine the amount of proceeds from the refunding bonds to deposit in a trust fund established in the name of the Commission with a trust company or other banking institution as trustee.

paragraph.text: Money in the trust fund may be invested and reinvested in direct obligations of, or obligations the principal of which and the interest on which is guaranteed by, the United States.
The Commission may provide for the use of money in the trust fund to pay all or part of the principal, interest, and redemption premium of the bonds being refunded and of the refunding bonds.

The proceeds of the refunding bonds shall be invested and applied so that the principal, interest, and redemption premium on the bonds being refunded is paid in full on maturity, redemption, or interest payment dates.

subsection.text: On or after the earliest redemption date, the Commission may call for redemption any bonds being refunded that are subject to redemption before the stated maturity dates.

paragraph.text: The Commission may issue refunding bonds in one or more series.

subparagraph.text: The Commission shall determine the principal amount of each series required to achieve the purpose for the issuance of the refunding bonds.
The principal amount of the refunding bonds may be greater than the principal amount of bonds being refunded.

subsection.text: In addition to or in lieu of any other money or security that the Commission may provide for the payment or security of the refunding bonds, the Commission may make all or part of the refunding bonds payable from money in and secured by the trust fund.

paragraph.text: To retire and pay interest on refunding bonds issued under § 22–114 of this subtitle, each year the county councils of Montgomery County and Prince George’s County shall impose a tax on the assessable property within the sanitary district sufficient to pay:

subparagraph.text: the interest on the bonds as it becomes due; and
the principal and redemption premium, if any, of the bonds at their maturity or redemption.

paragraph.text: If the series of refunding bonds is issued to refund stormwater management bonds, the county council of the respective county provided with the proceeds of the bonds being refunded shall impose the tax.
The counties shall determine, impose, collect, and pay the tax to the Commission as provided under § 22–106 of this subtitle.
The provisions of § 22–106 of this subtitle apply to the refunding bonds issued under § 22–114 of this subtitle.

The Commission shall make adequate provision for extending to its rate payers the benefit of savings in debt service costs derived through the issuance of any refunding bonds issued under § 22–114 of this subtitle.

subsection.text: Any provision of law requiring the setting and collecting of front foot benefit charges for the payment of the principal of and the interest on the outstanding bonds being refunded shall apply to the payment of the refunding bonds issued under § 22–114 of this subtitle to refund outstanding bonds.
The powers granted under this section are not subject to the provisions of any other law in conflict with the powers.
This subtitle shall be liberally construed to carry out its purposes.

The purpose of this subtitle is to authorize the Commission to issue bonds in a manner that provides flexibility without imposing additional debt burdens on the assessable tax base of the sanitary district, so as to yield overall savings to the residents of the sanitary district.
This subtitle does not apply to debt issued by the Commission under Subtitle 1 of this title.
The Commission may issue and sell revenue bonds to finance or refinance any of the Commission’s costs of a project authorized under this division.

paragraph.text: Revenue bonds may finance:

subparagraph.text: necessary expenses of preparing, printing, selling, and issuing the bonds;
funding of reserves;
payment of interest related to financing a project in the amounts and for the period that the Commission determines; and
initial program development costs.

paragraph.text: Commission funding sources, other than revenue bond proceeds, may finance initial program development costs or other project costs only if those costs are reimbursed from project revenues.
The Commission may issue bonds under this subtitle only if the Commission authorizes the issuance by resolution.

The resolution may authorize one or more officers of the Commission to determine or specify by bond order the matters that this subtitle requires to be determined or specified, or as may be necessary or advisable to accomplish the purposes of this subtitle.

subsection.text: Bonds issued under this subtitle, and their principal, interest, and any premium:

paragraph.text: are limited obligations of the Commission;
are payable solely from the revenues identified in the authorizing resolution or from other money made available for the payment; and
do not constitute a pledge of the faith and credit of the Commission or of any entity with taxing power.

subparagraph.text: Except as provided in subparagraph (ii) of this paragraph, bonds issued under this subtitle shall be dated, bear interest, and mature at the time that the Commission determines.
The bonds shall mature no later than 50 years after their date of issue.

paragraph.text: The bonds may bear interest at variable rates of interest, in a manner and amounts that the Commission determines.
The bonds shall be payable in the manner and at the times and places that the Commission determines.
The bonds may be made redeemable before maturity at the option of the Commission at a price and under terms and conditions that the Commission determines.

subparagraph.text: The Commission shall determine the forms and manner of execution of the bonds.
The bonds may be executed by facsimile signature.

paragraph.text: If an officer whose signature appears on a bond ceases to be an officer before the bond is delivered, the signature of the officer is valid and sufficient as if the officer had remained in office until delivery.

section.text: Bonds issued under this subtitle are negotiable instruments under the laws of the State.

subsection.text: The Commission may sell bonds issued under this subtitle:

paragraph.text: at public or private sale; and
in a manner and for a price that the Commission determines to be in the best interests of the Commission.

subsection.text: Article 31, §§ 9, 10, and 11 of the Code do not apply to the issuance and sale of bonds authorized by this subtitle.
The proceeds of each bond issuance under this subtitle shall be used solely for the projects for which the bonds were issued.
The proceeds shall be distributed in the same manner and under any restrictions stated in:

paragraph.text: the authorizing resolution of the Commission; or
the trust agreement securing the bonds.

If the proceeds of the bonds are less than the cost of the project for which the bonds were issued, by resolution, the Commission may issue and sell additional bonds in the same manner as the earlier issue to fund the amount of the deficit.
Unless otherwise provided in the authorizing resolution or in the trust agreement securing the bonds, the additional bonds shall be:

subparagraph.text: considered to be of the same issue as the earlier issue; and
entitled to payment from the same funds as the earlier issue, without preference or priority of the earlier issue.

subsection.text: If the proceeds of bonds issued under this subtitle exceed the cost of the project for which the bonds are issued, the surplus shall be used as the Commission determines.

section.text: As determined by the Commission, bonds issued under this subtitle may be secured by or made payable from:

paragraph.text: letters of credit;
lines of credit;
bond purchase agreements;
bond insurance policies;
guaranty agreements; and
similar credit arrangements.

subsection.text: The Commission may provide by resolution for the issuance of revenue refunding bonds to refund bonds issued under this subtitle.
To the extent applicable, revenue refunding bonds issued under this section shall conform to the requirements of this subtitle.

section.text: Bonds issued under this subtitle are not subject to the limitations of §§ 22–102(b) and 22–1035 of this title.

subsection.text: The Commission may enter into a trust agreement to secure bonds issued under this subtitle.
The trustee under the trust agreement may be a bank or trust company that has the powers of a trust company in or outside the State.
The trust agreement may pledge or assign all revenues from one or more projects as specified by the Commission.
The trust agreement may provide for the protection and enforcement of the rights and remedies of the bondholders, including:

paragraph.text: covenants setting forth the duties of the Commission regarding:

subparagraph.text: construction, acquisition, improvement, installation, maintenance, operation, repair, and insurance of a project; and
custody, safeguarding, and application of all money;

paragraph.text: the establishment and funding of reserve funds;
requirements that a project be constructed and paid for under the supervision and approval of consulting engineers employed or designated by the Commission; and
statements of the rights and remedies of the bondholders and of the trustee, which may restrict the individual right of action of bondholders.

subsection.text: Bonds issued under this subtitle, including their interest and any profit from their sale or exchange, are exempt from taxation by the State and its counties and municipalities.

If bonds are issued under this subtitle with the expectation that their interest may be excluded from the gross income of the bondholders, the Commission shall enter into all agreements and make all certifications necessary or advisable to show compliance with the applicable provisions of federal tax law.

The Commission shall develop surveys, plans, specifications, and estimates for water supply and sanitary sewer systems in the portions of the sanitary district that the Commission considers necessary.
The Commission shall divide the sanitary district into water or sanitary sewer districts that in the Commission’s judgment:

paragraph.text: best serve the needs of the communities in the sanitary district; and
promote the convenience and economy of the installation and operation of water supply and sanitary sewer systems.

subsection.text: The Commission may proceed with construction that the Commission considers advisable in any district.
If the Commission initiates construction without petition or request from an interested party, the Commission may give reasonable notice that the Commission considers advisable.

paragraph.text: The Commission may extend its water supply or sewer systems into any area outside of the sanitary district that is contiguous to or in the vicinity of the sanitary district if the property owners of the area agree to the conditions imposed by the Commission.
Except as provided in this division, the powers and authority in this subsection may not be restricted by any other general, special, or local law.

subsection.text: The Commission may not install, operate, or exercise any authority over stormwater management in Montgomery County.

A privately owned or municipally owned water supply or sanitary sewer system or part of a system, water main, sewer, water purification or sewage disposal plant, or connection with these facilities may not be constructed or installed, except as provided in this section.

A municipality or the property owners or residents of a locality in the sanitary district may construct and operate a water supply or sanitary sewer system or part of a system at their own expense if the Commission decides that it is inexpedient or impracticable to build the system due to remoteness from the Commission’s general system or for other reasons.

paragraph.text: A system constructed in accordance with subsection (b) of this section shall be constructed under plans and specifications submitted to and approved by the Commission.
The construction, maintenance, and operation of the system shall be under the supervision and general control of the Commission.

subsection.text: All construction and operating records for the system, including cost records, shall be filed with the Commission.

The Commission may take over the system or a part of the system, water main, sewer, water purification or sewage disposal plant, or connection with these facilities in the same manner as provided in § 23–103 of this subtitle.
Except as provided in this division, the powers and authority in this section may not be restricted by any other general, special, or local law.
The Commission may purchase a municipally or privately owned water supply or sewer system if the Commission:

paragraph.text: extends its general water supply or sewer system to the municipally or privately owned water supply or sewer system and is ready to connect with the system; or
considers the purchase to be expedient, advisable, and proper for the adequate operation of the system under the Commission’s jurisdiction.

subsection.text: If the Commission and the owner of a municipally or privately owned water supply or sewer system fail to agree to the purchase price or conditions of purchase of the water or sewer system, the Commission may acquire the system by condemnation, as provided in this division.

If a privately owned water or sewer system is the subject of a condemnation proceeding under this division, a jury in the proceeding shall determine the fair market value as provided for in § 12–105(b) of the Real Property Article.

paragraph.text: If the Commission condemns a privately owned system, the Commission shall take the system free and clear of all debts and liens.

subparagraph.text: The Commission shall make a party defendant any person that has a recorded lien or encumbrance against the privately owned system.
The circuit court may determine the respective amounts due the defendants.

subsection.text: After the payment into the court or to the proper parties:

paragraph.text: the Commission may take possession of, maintain, and operate the private system; and

all properties along the line of any water main or sewer of the private system shall stand in the same relation, bear the same benefit assessment, and be subject to the same regulations and penalties as though the private system had been constructed and put into operation by the Commission under the provisions of this division.

subsection.text: A building or premises properly connected with the acquired private system at the time of its purchase is not subject to the connection charge specified under Title 25, Subtitle 3 of this article.

paragraph.text: If the Commission considers that a privately owned water or sewer system is unfit, in whole or in part, for incorporation with the Commission’s system, the Commission shall:

subparagraph.text: disregard the existence of the system or unfit part of the system; and
extend the Commission’s system to serve the area served by the existing system or unfit part of the system.

paragraph.text: All of the provisions of this division relating to systems constructed by the Commission apply to an extension under paragraph (1) of this subsection.

subsection.text: After the payment for the acquisition is made to the court or to the municipality:

paragraph.text: the Commission may take possession of, maintain, and operate a municipally owned water or sewer system; and

all properties along the line of any water main or sewer of the municipal system shall stand in the same relation, bear the same benefit assessment, and be subject to the same regulations and penalties as though the municipal system had been constructed and put into operation by the Commission under the provisions of this division.

subsection.text: A building or premises properly connected with the acquired municipal system at the time of its purchase is not subject to the connection charge specified under Title 26, Subtitle 3 of this article.
If outstanding bonds exist for a municipal system acquired by the Commission:

paragraph.text: the municipality may use the amount paid by the Commission for the system for the purchase or redemption of any bond or debt that may be outstanding against the system; or
the Commission, as a part of the compensation for the system, may assume the payment of any outstanding bond.
In this section the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Authorization for service” means an application by a property owner or developer to the Commission for water or sewer service that requires the construction of subdivision lines.
“Development” means a project for the construction of:

subparagraph.text: two or more residential dwelling units; or
a commercial or industrial structure.

paragraph.text: “Health hazard” means an owner–occupied residential property with a failing well or septic system as certified by the State or a local health department.

“Payment security” means security to guarantee payment to the utility contractor, subcontractors, and suppliers that provide labor, materials, or construction equipment for the construction of subdivision lines.
“Performance security” means security to guarantee completion of the construction of subdivision lines.

subparagraph.text: “Subdivision lines” means the water and sewer pipelines or facilities necessary to provide service to a development, including service connections to individual lots or properties in a development.
“Subdivision lines” does not include pipelines or facilities that constitute major projects as defined in § 23–301 of this title.

paragraph.text: Subject to paragraph (2) of this subsection, this section does not apply to:

subparagraph.text: authorizations for service for which:

sub-subparagraph.text: application was made with the Commission on or before June 30, 1999; and
the Commission entered into a contract for construction of subdivision lines with notice to proceed issued by the Commission to its contractor on or before June 30, 2001; or

subparagraph.text: authorizations for service for the relief of health hazards.

paragraph.text: Each part of a multipart authorization for service shall be considered a separate authorization under paragraph (1) of this subsection.

subsection.text: Notwithstanding any other provision of law and except as provided in subsection (b) of this section, the owner or developer of a development in the sanitary district shall construct all subdivision lines for the development at the expense of the owner or developer.
Before constructing subdivision lines, the owner or developer of a development shall enter into an agreement with the Commission that:

paragraph.text: requires the subdivision lines to be constructed under plans and specifications submitted to and approved by the Commission;
requires the owner or developer to comply with all applicable laws and requirements for the construction of the subdivision lines;
provides for the inspection of the subdivision lines by the Commission before the line is placed in service;
requires the property owner or developer to provide:

subparagraph.text: performance security payable to the Commission in an amount acceptable to the Commission, taking into account potential cost escalation; and
payment security payable to the Commission in an amount equal to the amount of the performance security; and

paragraph.text: provides that before the subdivision lines are placed in service, the property owner or developer shall provide the Commission with a release of liens, on a form acceptable to the Commission, signed by the utility contractor and notarized, stating that the utility contractor, subcontractors, and suppliers have been paid.

subsection.text: Acceptable forms of performance security and payment security under subsection (d) of this section are:

paragraph.text: a certified check;
a cash deposit;
a certificate of deposit;
an irrevocable letter of credit from a financial institution acceptable to the Commission and in a form acceptable to the Commission;
a bond executed by a surety company authorized to do business in the State; or
any other form of security acceptable to the Commission.

subparagraph.text: A utility contractor, subcontractor, or supplier providing labor, materials, or equipment for the construction of the subdivision lines that has not been paid may file a claim against the payment security within 180 days after completion of construction of the subdivision lines under the procedure required in the payment security.
If a procedure is not specified in the payment security, the procedure shall be as established by regulations adopted by the Commission.

paragraph.text: The Commission may not release or reduce the amount of the payment security until:

subparagraph.text: all claimants have been paid; or
180 days have passed since completion of construction and no claims have been made.

paragraph.text: If property abuts on a street or right–of–way in which a water main or sanitary sewer is installed, the Commission shall provide a service connection from the water main or sanitary sewer to the property line of the abutting lot.
The service connection shall be constructed by and at the expense of the Commission and shall be paid for in accordance with this division.

When the Commission declares a water main or sewer complete, after notice, every abutting property owner may hook up spigots, hydrants, toilets, and waste drains with the water main or sewer, as appropriate, within the time set by the Commission.

If the fixtures described in paragraph (1) of this subsection do not exist or if the Commission determines that they are improper or inadequate, the property owner shall install satisfactory equipment.
Any cesspool, sink drain, outhouse, or well that is polluted or a menace to health shall be abandoned and left in a way that it cannot be used or pose a risk to the public health.
The Commission shall determine the disposition of these facilities.

After the construction or acquisition of a water main or sewer, the Commission may order a property owner or occupant who refuses to connect to the water main or sewer to hook up to the water main or sewer if:

subparagraph.text: a condition exists that appears to be a menace to the health of the occupants of the property or the occupants of a nearby or adjoining property;
the property on which the condition exists abuts the water main or sewer;
the Commission gives the owner or occupant 10 days’ notice and an opportunity to be heard; and
the Commission determines the condition to be a menace to the health of the occupants of the property or the occupants of a nearby or adjoining property.

If the Commission determines that a condition exists as provided in paragraph (1) of this subsection, the Commission shall pass an order that requires that the property hookup be made in not less than 30 days or more than 90 days of the issuance of the order.
The property owner or occupant may not refuse to comply with the order or violate any of the other provisions of this section.
As provided in the Administrative Procedure Act, the property owner or occupant may seek judicial review of the decision of the Commission.

subsection.text: Except as provided in subsection (e) of this section, this section does not apply to streets, roads, alleys, sidewalks, or public property in the jurisdiction of Montgomery County.

paragraph.text: The Commission shall make taps in installations of the Commission at a charge that the Commission considers reasonable.
The Commission may construct and make water service connections of 2 inches or larger and charge for the connections at the actual cost to the Commission.

subsection.text: The Commission may authorize the construction of service connections by a master plumber, who is registered in the sanitary district, under the supervision of the Commission.

paragraph.text: If the Commission, by resolution, authorizes service connections to be made by a master plumber, under regulations and after issuance of a written permit by the Commission, the master plumber may enter on and cut into a street under the jurisdiction of a public authority to the same extent that the Commission may enter on and cut into the street.

subparagraph.text: The master plumber shall first post with the Commission an indemnity bond in an amount set by and with sureties approved by the Commission.

The bond shall indemnify the Commission and any State, county, or municipal authority having jurisdiction over the street against all loss, cost, or damage that may be caused by the master plumber’s entering on and cutting into the street.
The master plumber shall deposit with the Commission in cash a sum set by the Commission to cover the cost of resurfacing the cut.
The only permit required shall be a permit issued by the Commission in accordance with this section.
The master plumber shall notify the authority having control of the street to be entered and cut of the time and nature of the work to be done.

subsection.text: Before cutting into a street, road, alley, sidewalk, or public property under the jurisdiction of Montgomery County, a master plumber shall secure a permit from the county and pay a fee and comply with regulations established by the county.
The Commission shall adopt regulations to implement this section.

section.text: The Commission may grant water or sewer service connections, hookups, or authorizations for service or otherwise extend water and sewer service to a new development in the Prince George’s County portion of the sanitary district only if the development is in conformance with adopted and approved plans, programs, and policies of the county or other regulations that the county may include in an adopted and approved comprehensive water and sewer plan, amendment, or revision.

subsection.text: In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.

paragraph.text: “Major project” means an extension, project, or program of water and sewer facilities.
“Major project” includes:

subparagraph.text: a sewer main at least 15 inches in diameter;
a water main at least 16 inches in diameter; and
a sewage or water pumping station, force main, and storage or other major facility.

paragraph.text: “Major project” does not include a sewer main or water main that:

subparagraph.text: provides only local service;
is 2,000 feet or less; and
is built to avoid unnecessary and uneconomical duplication when a major project is constructed.

subsection.text: “Program” means a 6–year projected program by the Commission of capital improvements for water and sewer facilities.

In this subtitle, the requirements and responsibilities of the county executives and county councils or successor forms of governments shall be performed separately or jointly by the branches of the respective county governments as provided by charter or other law.

The designation of a specific branch of county government is not intended to expand, limit, modify, or vary the powers and duties of the county executives and county councils of Montgomery County or Prince George’s County.

section.text: A Program shall include:

paragraph.text: the major projects that the Commission determines may be required in each of the next 6 fiscal years:

subparagraph.text: in the sanitary district; and
