subparagraph.text: is responsible for the bill; and
shall pay the bill to the Commission on demand.

subsection.text: In this section, “charitable institution” means an institution:

paragraph.text: that is located in Montgomery County or Prince George’s County; and
whose purpose is primarily charitable.

subsection.text: Except as provided in subsection (c) of this section, if a charitable institution does not discriminate against the entrance or care of residents of Montgomery County or Prince George’s County, the Commission:

paragraph.text: shall supply without cost up to 100 gallons of water per day for each resident of the charitable institution; and
may not charge the charitable institution a fee for sewer usage for the water supplied under item (1) of this subsection.
The charitable institution shall install and maintain a water meter at its own cost.
The Commission may charge the charitable institution for:

subparagraph.text: the cost of reading the water meter; and
sewer usage and water used in excess of 100 gallons per day for each resident of the charitable institution.

subsection.text: This section may not be construed to invalidate a contract between the Commission and a municipality located in the sanitary district without the consent of the municipality.
Except as provided in subsection (c) of this section, the Commission shall charge and collect its service rate for water, including a ready to serve charge, for all water used by:

paragraph.text: the State;
Montgomery County;
Prince George’s County; and
a municipality in Montgomery County or Prince George’s County.

subsection.text: Notwithstanding any other law, a fire department or rescue squad that is recognized by Montgomery County or Prince George’s County or that is maintained and operated by a municipality in Montgomery County or Prince George’s County is exempt from all Commission water and sewer usage charges and meter service charges.
This section applies only in Prince George’s County.
There is an Office of Prince George’s County Ombudsman in the Commission.
The Prince George’s County Executive, with the approval of the Prince George’s County Council, shall appoint an Ombudsman.

subparagraph.text: Prince George’s County shall:

sub-subparagraph.text: pay the Ombudsman’s salary;
provide to the Ombudsman any benefits available to other employees of Prince George’s County; and
provide funding for the Office of the Ombudsman.

subparagraph.text: The county may pay for any legal expenses incurred by the Ombudsman, as provided in the county budget.

paragraph.text: The Prince George’s County Council shall determine the salary of the Ombudsman.

While holding office, the Ombudsman may participate in any Commission program of group health, life, or disability insurance to the same extent and under the same terms as other Commission officers and employees.

subsection.text: The Ombudsman may represent the interests of a Prince George’s County residential or commercial customer who files a written claim with the Commission for:

paragraph.text: a refund of a payment on a bill for water and sewer usage charges that exceeds the amount that is properly and legally payable; or
a reduction in a bill for water and sewer usage charges that exceeds the amount that is properly and legally payable that has not yet been paid.

subsection.text: The Ombudsman:

paragraph.text: shall:

subparagraph.text: receive a copy of, and review, any written claim filed with the Commission under § 25–106(b) of this title;
investigate the merits of the claim;
attend any hearing held in accordance with § 25–106(c)(2) of this title and present any findings and recommendations on the merits of the claim during the hearing; and
prepare a written statement of findings and recommendations on the claim and provide copies of the statement to the Commission and the claimant; and

paragraph.text: may represent the customer in any appeal process.

subsection.text: Notwithstanding any other provision of this division, as to Prince George’s County residential customers, if all undisputed bills for water and sewer usage charges are paid when due, the Commission may not interrupt service during the pendency of a written claim filed for a reduction in a bill for water and sewer usage charges that exceeds the amount that is properly and legally payable.

section.text: The Commission and Anne Arundel County may enter into a contract for the Commission to construct, operate, and maintain a water system in Anne Arundel County for the purpose of supplying water to:

paragraph.text: the corrective institution of the District of Columbia, as authorized by Chapter 434 of the Acts of 1953, or its successor, if any; and
residents of Anne Arundel County who may be reasonably served from the water system.

section.text: To carry out this subtitle, the Commission may:

paragraph.text: enter on a public roadway as provided in § 27–101 of this article without receiving a permit from or paying a fee to Anne Arundel County;
acquire property in Anne Arundel County in the same way as provided for acquiring property in Prince George’s County in Title 21, Subtitle 2 of this article; and
adopt regulations.

section.text: Except as provided in Commission regulations, a person may not use, handle, tamper with, obstruct, interfere with, deface, or destroy any part of the water system constructed by the Commission under this subtitle, including pipes, fittings, fireplugs, pumps, engines, appliances, wires, or other fixtures or equipment.
The Commission may construct, operate, and maintain a water system to the Howard County boundary line to supply water to the residents of Howard County.

subsection.text: The Commission may contract with Howard County and any person to furnish water.
The parties to a contract under this section may determine by agreement the costs, rentals, service charges, or other fees entered into under the contract.

paragraph.text: If the Commission and any person who wants water service cannot agree on the reasonableness of the charge for the service, the Public Service Commission may determine the amount of the charge.
The Public Service Commission’s determination is final and binding on all parties concerned.

subsection.text: The Commission may contract with the Howard County Department of Public Works for the maintenance and operation of parts of the Howard County Department of Public Works’ water system that are supplied from the Commission’s water system.
If the contract under subsection (a) of this section requires the Commission to maintain and operate parts of the Howard County Department of Public Works’ water system:

paragraph.text: the operating control of those parts of the Howard County Department of Public Works’ water system belongs exclusively to the Commission; and
the Commission shall collect fees and charges incident to the maintenance and operation of the water system or the use of water in accordance with § 25–504(b), (c), and (d) of this article.

subsection.text: If Howard County is supplied with water from the Commission’s system, the Commission may adopt regulations requiring:

paragraph.text: the use of water saving devices;
curtailing of water use during water restriction periods; and
compliance with health requirements of the Commission’s plumbing regulations.

subsection.text: Howard County shall comply with the regulations adopted by the Commission for those parts of the Howard County Department of Public Works’ water system supplied with water by the Commission.

section.text: Except as provided in Commission regulations, a person may not use, handle, tamper with, obstruct, or interfere with any part of the Howard County Department of Public Works’ water system that is supplied with water from the Commission’s water system, including pipes, fittings, fireplugs, pumps, engines, appliances, wires, or other fixtures or equipment.

subsection.text: The Commission may provide a sewage collection and disposal system for the Patuxent River drainage area in Howard County.

paragraph.text: The Commission may contract with Howard County regarding:

subparagraph.text: sewage disposal; and
the terms and conditions on which sewage disposal service may be performed.

paragraph.text: The cost of sewage disposal under this section may not be apportioned or levied on any property in Montgomery County or Prince George’s County.

subsection.text: The Commission may:

paragraph.text: enter on a public roadway to install, maintain, and operate the Commission system; and

construct a water main, sewer, or an appurtenance of a water main or sewer in a public roadway in Montgomery County and Prince George’s County, subject to the regulation and permit provisions of §§ 27–102 and 27–108 of this title.

subsection.text: When the Commission disturbs a public roadway, the Commission shall:

paragraph.text: notify the State, county, or municipality that has authority over the public roadway of the Commission’s plans;
repair and leave the public roadway in the same or a superior condition to that existing before the public roadway was disturbed; and
pay all costs for returning the public roadway to the same or superior condition.

subsection.text: In addition to the authority over the construction and location of underground construction in the sanitary district, the Commission may regulate the construction of an overhead line, pole, or other public utility along a public roadway in the sanitary district.

In Montgomery County and Prince George’s County, the county executive and county council may adopt regulations concerning the Commission’s entry into or use of a public roadway for which a permit is required.
The regulations adopted under this section:

paragraph.text: shall be adopted after consultation with the Commission;

may include provisions for the review and approval of the required permits to be issued by the Commission under § 27–108 of this title for the construction or location of pipes, conduits, tracks, lines, poles, or facilities of a public utility in the public roadways of the county;
subject to reasonable provisions for control by the county of the construction, disturbing, or repair of the public roadway, may not:

subparagraph.text: be administered so as to constitute a taking of a franchise right that a public service company or a utility company has in a public roadway; and
divest the Commission of its right to use a public roadway for the installation of a Commission facility;

paragraph.text: subject to this title, may not prohibit the installation in a public roadway of a facility being constructed by the Commission to provide service to the sanitary district in the other county; and
may not be inconsistent with this title.
The review and approval procedures authorized by subsection (b)(2) of this section:

subparagraph.text: may require review and approval by the county before the Commission issues the permit; and
may not result in any cost to the Commission or to the public utility.

paragraph.text: A permit issued by the Commission under § 27–108 of this title is not effective unless the appropriate county approves the permit.
The Commission:

subparagraph.text: shall give a county advance notice of the date, time, and extent to which the Commission plans to cut into a public roadway, sidewalk, or other public property of the county; and
if required by a regulation adopted under this section, shall:

sub-subparagraph.text: submit a copy of proposed construction plans to the county before construction begins; and
apply for and obtain a permit from the county at no cost to the Commission.

paragraph.text: The county shall promptly process the Commission’s permit application.
The issuance of a permit under this section constitutes approval of the Commission’s proposed construction as specified in the permit.
If the construction under this section is an emergency, the Commission shall notify the appropriate county as soon as practicable after the cut.

subsection.text: On prior notice, the county may:

paragraph.text: make all necessary final repairs to restore property to a condition satisfactory to the county; and
charge all costs for the final repairs to the Commission or to the public utility that made the entry on the property.

subsection.text: Sections 27–101 and 27–102 of this title do not limit the Commission’s authority to enter into contracts or agreements with a unit of federal, State, county, or municipal government or with the District of Columbia concerning the matters described in §§ 27–101 and 27–102 of this title, if the agreement or contract is necessary, advisable, or expedient in connection with the construction, maintenance, and operation of the Commission’s water and sewer systems.

Sections 27–101 and 27–102 of this title do not impair the rights of the State Highway Administration concerning Commission or utility use of a State highway, including a road that is constructed in whole or in part with federal funds.

paragraph.text: In this section the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Homeowner corporation” means a homeowner association with 5,000 or more members that has:

subparagraph.text: filed a written request with the Commission to receive the information required by this section; and
provided the Commission with a map of the homeowner corporation’s geographic boundaries.

paragraph.text: “System repair” means work to install, maintain, or operate the Commission system that involves cutting into a public roadway, sidewalk, or other improvement on public property of a county or municipality located in the sanitary district.

On or before September 1 of each year, the Commission shall submit to each county, municipality, and homeowner corporation located in the sanitary district a plan of system repairs scheduled for the next 3 years.
The Commission shall submit the plan of scheduled system repairs to the person designated by the county, municipality, or homeowner corporation.

subsection.text: For each scheduled system repair, the plan shall include:

paragraph.text: the anticipated system repair date and time;
the system repair location; and
an analysis of the impact that the system repair will have on the affected counties, municipalities, and homeowner corporations.

subsection.text: Before submitting the plan of system repairs, the Commission shall consult with the affected counties, municipalities, and homeowner corporations located in the sanitary district.

paragraph.text: If a county requires the relocation or removal of a Commission facility, the county shall give notice to the Commission of the requirement within a reasonable time.
On receiving notice, the Commission shall provide the county with an estimate of the cost of removing or relocating the facility.
On completion of the removal or relocation of the facility, the Commission shall provide the county with an itemized statement of the actual cost of removal or relocation.

For the relocation or removal of a facility for which the Commission is required to pay because of any road construction or improvement required by either Montgomery County or Prince George’s County, the governing body of the county in which the construction or improvement is made shall pay one–half of the actual cost of the construction or improvement in that county.

subparagraph.text: Unless the county disputes a charge in the itemized statement of actual costs, the county shall pay the costs within 6 months after receipt of the statement.
If the itemized statement as submitted or finally agreed on is not paid within 6 months after submission or agreement, the itemized statement shall bear 6% interest until paid.

paragraph.text: If there is a dispute over a charge in the itemized statement of actual costs, within 3 months after receipt of the statement, the dispute shall be referred to an arbitrator selected by the Commission and the county.
If the Commission and the county do not agree on an arbitrator, the Commission and the county shall each appoint an arbitrator, who jointly shall appoint a third arbitrator.

If a dispute goes to arbitration, the itemized statement as finally determined shall bear 6% interest after 6 months from the date of the finding by the arbitrator or arbitrators until the statement is paid.
In this section the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Construction contractor” means a person that performs or is hired to perform road construction work.
“Road construction work” means the construction, repair, paving, repaving, or grading of a public roadway.

subsection.text: Before beginning road construction work on a public roadway in the sanitary district in which a water, sewer, or stormwater management structure is installed, a construction contractor shall give notice to the Commission and the county of the proposed construction work.
The notice:

paragraph.text: shall include the proposed construction schedule and information about the location of construction to accomplish the purposes of this section;
except in emergency road repair situations, shall be given to the Commission and the county at least 7 days before road construction work begins; and
in an emergency road repair situation, shall be given to the Commission and the county as promptly as feasible under the emergency situation.

subsection.text: Unless allowed by the Commission or the county, as appropriate, a person may not disturb, remove, pave over, or repave over a manhole, valve, fitting, or other Commission water or sewer structure or county stormwater management structure.

paragraph.text: Before a person begins underground construction in a public roadway in the sanitary district, the person shall file with the Commission a construction plan that shows the location and depth of the proposed main, conduit, or pipe in the public roadway.
Construction may not begin before the Commission approves the plan.
Unless the Commission approves the change, a change may not be made in the physical location of the main, conduit, or pipe shown on the plan.
The Commission may remove or change the location of a conduit, main, or pipe that interferes with the operation of the Commission’s water and sewer systems if:

subparagraph.text: the conduit, main, or pipe is constructed without the Commission’s approval; or
the physical location of the conduit, main, or pipe is changed from that shown on the plan approved by the Commission.

paragraph.text: The person that constructed the interfering conduit, main, or pipe, or the person’s successor, shall pay the expenses of the removal or change in location.
The Commission is not liable for damage to the interfering conduit, main, or pipe because of construction or maintenance of the Commission’s water and sewer systems.

If a person has a building, conduit, pipe, track, or other physical obstruction on a public roadway in Montgomery County or Prince George’s County that blocks or impedes the Commission’s water or sewer system, on reasonable notice from the Commission, the person shall promptly adjust, accommodate, or remove the obstruction at the person’s expense and in a manner that fully meets the Commission’s needs.
The Commission may condemn an easement in a franchise or right in accordance with Title 21, Subtitle 1 of this article.

subsection.text: The Commission may charge a reasonable fee for any permit that the Commission is required to obtain and for engineering services that the Commission is required to perform under this section.
A person may not erect a pole or other structure in the sanitary district for the purpose of carrying wires overhead without first obtaining a permit from the Commission.
The Commission may:

paragraph.text: require that plans for the location or construction of the pole or structure be filed with the Commission; and
charge a reasonable fee for the permit.

section.text: The Commission is exempt from the payment of any fee or charge under § 5–403(b) and (c) of the Natural Resources Article.

subsection.text: There is a Commission police force.

paragraph.text: A Commission police officer may exercise the powers of a law enforcement officer in the State on property that is owned, leased, or operated by or under the control of the Commission.
A Commission police officer may not exercise law enforcement powers on any other property unless the officer is:

subparagraph.text: engaged in fresh pursuit of a suspected offender;
requested or authorized to do so in a political subdivision by the chief executive officer or chief police officer of the political subdivision;
needed for the orderly flow of traffic to and from property owned, leased, or operated by or under the control of the Commission; or
ordered to do so by the Governor.

paragraph.text: After consulting with the Secretary of State Police and the Police Training Commission, the Commission shall adopt regulations to carry out this section, including standards for character, training, education, human relations, experience, and job performance for Commission police officers.
To the extent practicable, the Commission shall adopt standards that are similar to the standards of the Department of State Police.

Standards adopted on or after October 1, 2002, on minimum hiring qualifications of Commission police officers do not affect the status of an individual who was a qualified Commission special police officer on October 1, 2002.

subsection.text: In this section, “enforcement official” means an employee of the Commission authorized by the Commission to issue a citation for a Commission infraction under this section.
This section applies to the violations of the following:

paragraph.text: regulations governing sewer cleaning adopted under § 24–201 of this article;
regulations governing plumbing adopted under § 17–403, Title 24, Subtitle 1, § 26–102, or § 26–204 of this article;
regulations governing erosion and sediment control for utility construction adopted under § 17–403 of this article and § 4–105 of the Environment Article;
regulations governing gas fitting adopted under § 17–404 of this article;
regulations governing required permits for public utility construction adopted under §§ 27–101, 27–107, and 27–108 of this article;
regulations governing the Commission Pretreatment Program adopted under § 17–403 of this article and § 9–332 of the Environment Article; or
any other regulation adopted in accordance with § 17–406 of this article.

subparagraph.text: A person who violates any provision of a regulation listed in subsection (b) of this section has committed a Commission infraction and on delivery of a citation by the Commission under subsection (d)(1) of this section shall pay to the Commission a civil fine in the amount of:

sub-subparagraph.text: for a first violation of the regulation, $250;
for a second violation of the regulation, $500;
for a third violation of the regulation, $750; and
for a fourth or subsequent violation, $1,000.

subparagraph.text: Each day that a violation of the regulation remains uncorrected is a separate Commission infraction subject to an additional citation and fine in the amount of $250.
The payment due date for the fine may not be less than 10 or more than 20 calendar days after the date of delivery of the citation.
The recipient of the citation may pay the fine before the payment due date specified in the citation.

paragraph.text: After verifying a Commission infraction the enforcement official shall deliver the citation to any person charged with committing the Commission infraction in accordance with the enforcement procedures of the regulations.
The citation shall be on a form adopted by the Commission and shall include:

subparagraph.text: the date of delivery of the citation;
the name and address of the person charged;
the specific provision of the regulations that has been violated;
the nature of the Commission infraction;
the location and time that the Commission infraction occurred;
the amount of the civil fine assessed for the Commission infraction;
the manner, location, and time in which the fine may be paid to the Commission;
a statement that each day that a violation continues is a separate Commission infraction subject to additional citation;
the name, business address, title, and telephone number of the enforcement official who issued the citation; and
notice of the person’s right to a trial for the Commission infraction and instructions and time limits for that election.

paragraph.text: A person who receives a citation for a Commission infraction under this section may elect to stand trial by filing with the Commission a notice of the person’s intent to stand trial.
The notice of intent to stand trial shall be given at least 5 days before the payment due date specified in the citation.

On receipt of the notice of intent to stand trial, the Commission shall forward to the District Court having venue a copy of the citation and a copy of the notice of intent to stand trial that was filed by the person who received the citation.
On receipt of the citation and the notice of intent to stand trial, the District Court shall schedule the case for trial and notify the defendant and Commission of the trial date.
The District Court shall remit to the Commission all fines, penalties, or forfeitures the Court collects for Commission infractions.

If a person who receives a citation for a Commission infraction fails to pay the fine by the payment due date specified in the citation and fails to file a notice of the person’s intent to stand trial for the offense:

subparagraph.text: the person is liable for the assessed fine; and
the Commission shall send a notice of the Commission infraction to the person’s last known address.

If the fine is not paid within 35 days after the date of the notice, the Commission may request adjudication of the case through the District Court, which may include the filing of a demand for judgment on affidavit.
On receipt of the request for adjudication, the District Court shall schedule the case for trial and summon the defendant to appear.

paragraph.text: If the defendant fails to respond to the summons and the Commission has made a proper demand for judgment on affidavit, the District Court shall enter judgment against the defendant in favor of the Commission in the amount then due.
For the purpose of this section, a Commission infraction is a civil offense.
The adjudication of a Commission infraction:

subparagraph.text: is not a criminal conviction; and
does not impose any of the civil disabilities ordinarily imposed by a criminal conviction.

subsection.text: In a proceeding for a Commission infraction before the District Court, the violation shall be prosecuted in the same manner and to the same extent provided for municipal infractions under Article 23A, § 3(b)(7), (10), and (12) through (15) of the Code.

paragraph.text: Except as provided in paragraph (2) of this subsection, a person who violates a watershed regulation adopted under § 17–403 of this article has committed a Commission infraction.
A Commission infraction does not include a violation of a watershed regulation declared by law to be a criminal offense.
The Commission may:

subparagraph.text: establish a schedule of preset fines for each conviction of a Commission infraction under this section;
impose a preset fine not to exceed $50 for each conviction of a Commission infraction under this section; and
impose a preset fine not to exceed $100 for a repeat offense.

paragraph.text: The recipient of a citation for a Commission infraction shall pay the fine to the Commission within 20 calendar days after the receipt of the citation.

subparagraph.text: A Commission police officer may issue a citation to any person charged with committing a Commission infraction.
The Commission shall:

sub-subparagraph.text: retain a copy of the citation; and
include on the citation a certification attesting to the truth of the matter specified in the citation.

paragraph.text: The citation also shall contain:

subparagraph.text: the name and address of the person charged;
the nature of the Commission infraction;
the location and time that the Commission infraction occurred;
the amount of the civil fine assessed for the Commission infraction;
the manner, location, and time in which the fine may be paid to the Commission; and
notice of the person’s right to a trial for the Commission infraction.

paragraph.text: A person who receives a citation for a Commission infraction under this section may elect to stand trial by filing with the Commission a notice of the person’s intent to stand trial.
The notice of intent to stand trial shall be given at least 5 days before the payment due date specified in the citation.

On receipt of the notice of intent to stand trial, the Commission shall forward to the District Court having venue a copy of the citation and a copy of the notice of intent to stand trial that was filed by the person who received the citation.
On receipt of the citation and the notice of intent to stand trial, the District Court shall schedule the case for trial and notify the defendant of the trial date.
The District Court shall remit to the Commission all fines, penalties, or forfeitures the Court collects for Commission infractions.

If a person who receives a citation for a Commission infraction fails to pay the fine by the payment due date specified in the citation and fails to file a notice of the person’s intent to stand trial for the offense, the Commission shall send a notice of the Commission infraction to the person’s last known address.
A person who fails to pay the fine within 15 days after the date of the notice is liable for an additional fine not to exceed twice the original fine.

subparagraph.text: If the fine is not paid within 35 days after the date of the notice, the Commission may request adjudication of the case through the District Court, which may include the filing of a demand for judgment on affidavit.
On receipt of the request for adjudication, the District Court promptly shall schedule the case for trial and summon the defendant to appear.

paragraph.text: If the defendant fails to respond to the summons and the Commission has made a proper demand for judgment on affidavit, the District Court shall enter judgment against the defendant in favor of the Commission in the amount then due.

subsection.text: A person found by the District Court to have committed a Commission infraction shall pay a fine not to exceed:

paragraph.text: $50 for a first offense; or
$100 for a repeat offense.
For the purpose of this section, a Commission infraction is a civil offense.
The adjudication of a Commission infraction:

subparagraph.text: is not a criminal conviction; and
does not impose any of the civil disabilities ordinarily imposed by a criminal conviction.

subsection.text: In a proceeding for a Commission infraction before the District Court, the violation shall be prosecuted in the same manner and to the same extent provided for municipal infractions under Article 23A, § 3(b)(7), (10), and (12) through (15) of the Code.
In this section, “Commission Pretreatment Program” means any program adopted under the authority of § 9–332 of the Environment Article and § 17–403 of this article to:

paragraph.text: meet national and local pretreatment requirements; and
eliminate the contribution of each pollutant discharged from an industrial user into a publicly owned treatment works that:

subparagraph.text: causes pass through or interference with the publicly owned treatment works; or
contaminates sewage sludge.

paragraph.text: The Commission may issue a written complaint if the Commission has reasonable grounds to believe that a person has violated a provision of the Commission Pretreatment Program.
A complaint issued under this subsection shall:

subparagraph.text: specify the provision of the Commission Pretreatment Program that allegedly has been violated; and
state the alleged facts that constitute the violation.

paragraph.text: After or concurrently with service of a complaint under this section, the Commission may issue an administrative order that requires the person to whom the order is directed to:

subparagraph.text: take corrective action within a time set in the order;
file with the Commission a written report about the alleged violation;
appear at a hearing before the Commission at a time and place the Commission sets to answer the charges in the order; or
file a written report and appear at a hearing before the Commission at a time and place the Commission sets to answer the charges in the order.

paragraph.text: Any order issued under this subsection is effective immediately when it is served.
A complaint or order issued by the Commission under this section shall be served on the person to whom the complaint or order is directed:

subparagraph.text: personally; or
by certified mail, return receipt requested to the person’s last known address as shown on the Commission’s records.

paragraph.text: If service is made by certified mail, the person who mails the document shall file with the Commission verified proof of mailing.

If the Commission is unable with due diligence to serve process under paragraph (1) of this subsection, a complaint or order shall be served by publication reasonably tailored to provide actual notice to the person to whom the complaint or order is directed.
An order issued under this section that requires filing of a report, attendance at a hearing, or both shall be served at least 10 days before the earlier of:

subparagraph.text: the time set for the hearing, if any; or
the time set for the filing of the report, if any.

paragraph.text: Within 10 days after being served with an order under subsection (c)(1)(i) or (ii) of this section, the person served may request in writing a hearing before the Commission.
The Commission shall give notice and hold a hearing under this section in accordance with the Administrative Procedure Act.
In connection with a hearing conducted under this section, the Commission, on its own initiative or at the request of the person to whom the complaint or order is directed, may:

subparagraph.text: subpoena any person or evidence that is essential for proper consideration at the hearing; and
order a witness to give evidence.

paragraph.text: If a person fails to comply with a subpoena or order issued under this subsection, on petition of the Commission or the person to whom the complaint or order is directed, a circuit court may compel:

subparagraph.text: obedience to the order or subpoena; or
testimony or the production of evidence.

subsection.text: The Commission may designate a hearing officer to conduct a hearing required under this section and issue the final order and decision of the Commission.

paragraph.text: Unless the person served with a corrective action order under subsection (c)(1)(i) of this section makes a request for a hearing in accordance with subsection (e)(1) of this section, the order is a final order.

If the person served with a corrective action order under subsection (c)(1)(i) of this section makes a request for a hearing in accordance with subsection (e)(1) of this section, the order becomes a final corrective order in accordance with the decision of the Commission following the hearing.
If the Commission issues an order under subsection (c)(1)(ii), (iii), or (iv) of this section, the Commission may not issue an order that requires corrective action until after the later of:

subparagraph.text: the conclusion of the hearing, if any; or
the review of the report, if any.

paragraph.text: After the time provided in paragraph (3) of this subsection, if the Commission finds that a violation of the Commission Pretreatment Program has occurred, the Commission shall issue an order that requires correction of the violation within the time set in the order.

An order issued under paragraph (4) of this subsection is a final corrective order and the person to whom the order is directed is not entitled to a hearing before the Commission as a result of the order.

If the terms of the final corrective order are violated or if a violation is not corrected within the time set in the order, the Commission shall take action to secure compliance with a final corrective order, including filing suit to require correction of the violation.

subsection.text: In an action for an injunction under § 29–104 of this title to enforce the compliance with or restrain the violation of a provision of the Commission Pretreatment Program or an administrative order issued under this section:

paragraph.text: a finding of the Commission after a hearing is prima facie evidence of each fact the Commission determines; and

on a showing that a person is violating or is about to violate a provision of the Commission Pretreatment Program or an administrative order issued under this subsection, the court shall grant the injunction without requiring a showing of a lack of an adequate remedy at law.

In addition to any other judicial remedy and after an opportunity for a hearing, the Commission may impose a penalty for a violation of a provision of the Commission Pretreatment Program stated in the complaint or an administrative order issued under this section.
The Commission shall provide the person subject to a penalty under paragraph (1) of this subsection a written notice stating that:

subparagraph.text: the Commission intends to assess a penalty against the person;
the person may request in writing a hearing before the Commission no later than 10 days after receipt of the notice; and
the failure to file a written request for a hearing no later than 10 days after receipt of the notice shall be considered a waiver of the right to a hearing.

paragraph.text: The penalty imposed on a person under this subsection:

subparagraph.text: may not exceed $1,000 for each violation or $50,000 total; and
shall be assessed with consideration given to:

sub-subparagraph.text: the extent to which the existence of the violation was known to but uncorrected by the violator and the extent to which the violator exercised reasonable care;
any actual or potential harm to human health or to the environment, including injury to or impairment of the Commission sewage collection and treatment systems or the natural resources of the State;
the degree of interference with or injury to the general welfare, health, or property rights of the public;
the extent to which the geographic location of the system creates the potential for harm to the environment or to human health or safety;
the cost of cleanup and restoration of natural resources;
the available technology for controlling, reducing, or eliminating the conditions that caused the violation; and
the extent to which the current violation is part of a recurrent pattern of the same or similar type of violation committed by the violator.

paragraph.text: Each day a violation continues is a separate violation under this subsection.
A penalty imposed under this subsection is:

subparagraph.text: payable to the Commission; and
collectible in any manner provided at law for the collection of debts.

paragraph.text: If a person who is liable to pay a penalty imposed under this subsection fails to pay it after demand, the amount, together with interest and any costs that may accrue, shall be:

subparagraph.text: a lien in favor of the Commission on any property, real or personal, of the person; and
recorded in the office of the clerk of court for the county in which the property is located.

subsection.text: A person aggrieved by a final decision of the Commission in connection with an order issued under this section may seek judicial review as provided for in the Administrative Procedure Act.
On application of the Commission that is verified by oath of a member or employee of the Commission, the circuit court of a county, by injunction, may:

paragraph.text: require the compliance with or restrain the violation of any order, notice, or regulation of the Commission under this division;
require compliance with or restrain the violation or attempted violation of a provision of this division; or

require the entry of an employee or agent of the Commission within a designated area on the private premises and into any building in the sanitary district where the Commission shows a violation of this division.

subsection.text: The court may not require the Commission to post a bond.
If the respondent in a petition for injunction under this section is a nonresident of the State, service of process shall be made in accordance with the Maryland Rules.
As to §§ 27–101(a) and (b), 27–102, and 27–103 of this article:

paragraph.text: Montgomery County may apply the provisions of this section if an application is verified by oath of an employee of Montgomery County; and
the court may not require Montgomery County to post a bond.

section.text: Except as provided in regulations adopted by the Commission, a person may not use, handle, tamper with, obstruct, interfere with, deface, or destroy any property owned or used by the Commission in the construction or operation of the Commission’s systems.

subsection.text: A person may not leave unburied for a period longer than 24 hours a dead animal or fecal matter in the sanitary district or on a watershed from which the Commission gets its water supply.

The Commission may bury a dead animal or fecal matter left unburied more than 24 hours and charge the cost of the burial to the owner or the person on whose property the dead animal or fecal matter was found.
A person who violates any of the following provisions is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to imprisonment not exceeding 30 days or a fine not exceeding $1,000 or both:

paragraph.text: § 17–403 of this article (Commission regulations, except for those specified in subsection (c) of this section and §§ 29–101(b) and 29–102(a) of this title);
Title 22, Subtitle 1 of this article (general obligation bonds and notes);
§ 23–102(a) of this article (construction of private or municipal systems);
§ 23–202 of this article (service connections);
§ 26–103 of this article (tampering with Commission system in Anne Arundel County);
§ 26–205 of this article (tampering with Commission system in Howard County);
§§ 27–101(c) and 27–108 of this article (public utilities construction);
§ 29–105 of this title (unlawful use of Commission property, except for the regulations governing publicly owned watershed property); or
§ 29–106 of this title (leaving dead animals or fecal matter unburied).

subsection.text: A person who violates the provisions of Title 20, Subtitle 2 of this article as they relate to the minority business enterprise utilization program by committing a prohibited act listed under § 14–308 of the State Finance and Procurement Article, on conviction, is subject to the penalties provided under that section.
A person who violates emergency water use restrictions adopted in accordance with § 17–403 of this article is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to a fine not exceeding $500.
A person who violates Title 18, Subtitle 1 of this article (Personnel Management) is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to a fine not exceeding $500.
A person who violates § 19–102(b) of this article (ethics) is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to imprisonment not exceeding 1 year or a fine not exceeding $1,000 or both.
A person may be convicted of a second or subsequent violation of a provision of this Division II or a regulation adopted under this Division II.
